headline: MUSIC: SONGS OPEN A WORLD FOR THE RETARDED BLIND
abstract: THE 20 to 30 retarded ''young adults'' of the Jewish Guild for the Blind, who ranged in age from 21 to 35, sat in front of the auditorium three years ago, rocking back and forth, being led to and from the microphone, haltingly reciting their memorized lines and nervously singing Broadway tunes, radio hit songs and holiday melodies. But the sound - which was all they could be aware of - was less distressing than the sight - which became so affecting it was easier to look down rather than watch. Pain, isolation, and incapacity were visibly thrown into relief by the awkward attempts at song.

abstract: India's Supreme Court directed the northern state of Bihar today to speed up its investigation of the policemen who are alleged to have deliberately blinded 31 prisoners awaiting trial.

headline: NATIONAL THEATER OF DEAF OFFERING 'ILLIAD' IN BENEFIT
abstract: In a gesture of celebration and salute, the National Theater of the Deaf will present ''The Iliad, Play by Play'' - an adaptation by Shanny Mow of Homer's ''Iliad'' - at the Public Theater tomorrow to benefit the Actors Fund.   The celebration marks the growing success of the 13-year-old touring company; it performed in its 50th state last November. The salute is to hearing actors. During a dinner that will follow the performance, awards will be given to various people who have helped deaf actors in one way or another, including Jason Robards, Jacques d'Amboise, Merrill Brockway, Joe Layton and the feathery Big Bird of television's ''Sesame Street.''

headline: Future Events Antiques and Irises
abstract:
Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:
From the Other Side
Jan. 21 -The 18th-century furniture, artifacts, silver, books and manuscripts that turned the late Marjorie Wiggin Prescott's houses in Greenwich, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., into homes for her and her husband, the late Sherburne Prescott, will be on view from 6 to 8 this evening at a cocktail party arranged by the English-Speaking Union at Christie's on Park Avenue. Guests of honor will be Sir Anthony Parsons, Britain's representative at the United Nations, and Lady Parsons. Mrs. Prescott's home furnishings also came from England and will be auctioned as the Prescott Collection of Fine English Furniture at Christie's this month and in February. Mrs.  Prescott was also the author of ''New England Son,'' a biography of her father, Albert Henry Wiggin, president of the then Chase National Bank. Proceeds of tonight's gathering will support the English-Speaking Union's educational, cultural and social programs, including exchange scholarships for British and American students.  Tickets at $25 may be reserved through TR 9-6800, ext. 24.

headline: Phone Companies on Coast Told To Provide Free Devices for Deaf
abstract: California telephone companies have been ordered to start taking bids to provide free special service for deaf customers.   The order, issued this week by the state's Public Utilities Commission, is expected to result in a 15-cent increase in the monthly telephone bills of all customers. Officials estimate that 90,000 special devices for the deaf will be needed by the end of 1983.

headline: JURY AWARDS 2.8 MILLION FOR BLINDING IN INFANCY
abstract: A 27-year-old New Jersey man, blinded shortly after birth through an unauthorized test of oxygen levels in his incubator, was awarded $2,887,000 by a Manhattan jury in a malpractice suit he brought against New York Hospital. The plaintiff, in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, was Daniel Burton Jr. of Union City.

headline: Sports of the Times; Jim Plunkett's Blind Parents
abstract: JIM PLUNKETT is on a roll. After two seasons in oblivion, the 32-year-old quarterback took the Oakland Raiders to Super Bowl XV and was selected as the most valuable player in their 27-10 triumph. For that, he collected a black and silver Toyota automobile and a Seiko watch from Sport magazine at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria last week. And while he is a celebrity, he is hoping to complete a pass at the Raiders' treasury for a new contract that might double his $180,000 annual salary.   After all, the quarterback Jim Plunkett replaced early last season, Dan Pastorini, made nearly $360,000.  ''I want to make the most of my situation,'' Jim Plunkett was saying now, alluding to his potential income from motion pictures, books, commercials, endorsements and corporate sponsors, ''but without compromising my integrity and dignity.''

headline: Europeans Urged to Aid Disabled
abstract: About 200 blind people demonstrated outside the European Parliament today demanding increased Common Market support for the disabled. The demonstration was held to coincide with discussion of a parliamentary report on the community's approximately 20 million disabled; the report urges member states and the commission to provide increased financial aid and facilities for them.

headline: Notes on People; SINGING AND COMMUNICATING IN HIS OWN SPECIAL WAY
abstract: He is deaf and can't speak, but when the New York City Gay Men's Chorus gives a concert at Bond's International Disco on Times Square Sunday night, Bruce Hlibok plans to be right there singing away in a style that is uniquely his own.   Mr. Hlibok, who appeared in the play ''Runaways,'' will use a special combination of standard signed English and American Sign Language.

headline: BANKING
abstract: To the Business Editor:    In your article, Edward J. McColgan, executive vice president and chief financial officer of the New York Bank for Savings is quoted in reference to relatively simple banking conditions in the early 1960's, as saying, ''At that time, even a blind man could make money.'' I would hope that Mr. McColgan would be prepared to apologize for making such a disparaging comment.   WARREN FRIEDMAN, Cincinnati, Ohio, March 11, 1981

headline: Speaking Personally; WHEN A PICTURE IS WORTH MORE THAN A THOUSAND WORDS
abstract: DAN, my 5-year-old son, often does things that remind me of myself at that age. Yesterday, I watched him play in the backyard with our neighbor's deaf son.   They were digging holes in the sandy dirt beneath a cluster of pine trees. Dan makes roads that lead to the castles that Tommy builds. To complement this newly constructed world of theirs, they invent their own version of sign language as imaginatively and naturally as children do everywhere when confronted by a wordless silence.

headline: COMMUNITY INVOLVED IN EDUCATION OF DEAF
abstract:
WINSTED WHILE driving to Northwestern Connecticut Community College to visit his son, a deaf man was pulled over by a Winsted police officer. After gesturing that he could not hear, the driver was astounded when the officer repeated the charge - in sign language - and presented him with a speeding ticket.

That the policeman could communicate this way is not regarded as unusual by residents of this small Connecticut town near the Massachusetts border. The Chief of Police and other officers have studied sign language at the community college, as have several merchants, teachers, waitresses, bank tellers and hospital employees. 

The community's continuing interest in the education of the deaf has helped support a post-secondary school program being offered at the college. Called Career Education for the Deaf, the seven-year-old program allows hearing-impaired students to be put into regular college classes and provides them with interpreters, tutors and notetakers.

headline: DANCING GIVES DEAF AN UPBEAT REACTION
abstract: This particular dance number, called ''Broadway Lights,'' is jazzy, fast-paced, high-stepping. Step, kick, arms to the right, arms to the left. The entire auditorium is throbbing to the beat.   The teen-aged performers are right in step. Back, back, stay.  Turn. Back, back, stay. This might be a feat under ordinary circumstances, but these circumstances are not ordinary. None of the performers can hear the music: They are all profoundly deaf.

headline: Harold G. Roberts Dead; Devoted Career to Blind
abstract: Harold G. Roberts, executive director of Helen Keller International and a leader for 35 years of agencies that assist the blind, died Saturday at his home in Brookfield, Conn. He was 64 years old.

headline: Advertising; KENYON & ECKHARDT AIDS DEAFNESS RESEARCH GROUP
abstract: The Deafness Research Foundation in New York, which says it is the only organization that raises money for deafness research, is ''going public'' with the help of public service advertising by Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising.   And that brought John J. Morrissey, chairman of the agency, to New York from his Detroit office yesterday with three television commercials, two radio commercials and a print ad.

headline: EX-POSTAL EMPLOYEE LEAVES MILLIONS TO HELP THE SIGHTLESS
abstract: Clinton Teubert, a retired postal worker who spent a lifetime saving pennies, ended it with an unexplained postscript of kindness: he left most of his $3 million fortune to the blind.   ''His only desire and happiness was making money,'' recalled Glenn Ratliff, who worked for many years with Mr. Teubert at the Huntington Post Office. ''And when he got his hands on it, he didn't let it go.''

headline: HEAD OF GUILD FOR BLIND SEEKS TO 'REINTEGRATE' THE DISABLED
abstract: Since its founding in 1914, the Jewish Guild for the Blind has been taking in blind people, teaching them skills and generally caring for them. It also serves a variety of multihandicapped people in its handsome, spacious quarters at 15 West 65th Street and at its Home for Aged Blind in Yonkers.   John F. Heimerdinger, the guild's executive director, would like to see much of that change. He feels that many of the handicapped would benefit from participating in outside programs, ideally in their own communities, instead of always being with people just like themselves.

headline: Patents; ULTRASONIC BEAM AIDS BLIND
abstract: WASHINGTON A WARNING cane for the blind that sends ultrasonic signals to detect obstacles was patented this week for the Polaroid Corporation of Cambridge, Mass. Gilbert M. Elchinger, an employee, obtained patent 4,280,204.

headline: COUNSELING LIFTS HOPES OF DEAF
abstract: CAMDEN A DEAF person who needs a lawyer, doctor, insurance agent or realestate broker faces a dilemma that his hearing friends do not: How to convey his needs to someone with whom he cannot communicate.   All too frequently, said Stephen Bellitz, a counselor for the deaf, an interview or screaming process turns into a period of great frustration for both parties.   ''The deaf person has a gap to bridge,'' Mr. Bellitz explained in a recent interview. ''He usually can't get right down to discussing his problem - whether it's medical, legal or marital - without stumbling over the language barrier.''

headline: F.A.A. to Allow Blind to Keep Their Canes at Airliner Seats
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it was changing its rules to permit blind passengers to keep flexible travel canes at their seats on airliners.

headline: Sports of The Times; Mike Glenn's Commitment
abstract: MIKE GLENN of the Knicks lived in two worlds when he was growing up. During the day he went to school where people communicated with their voices and their ears, and after school he played with his friends who communicated with their hands and their eyes.   His father was a math teacher and basketball coach at the Georgia School for the Deaf. Glenn learned sign language as early as he learned to talk.

headline: Sound; PERIL: SONIC EXCESS
abstract: As any Puritan knows, danger lurks in our pleasures, and the trouble is that sometimes the dangers are real. After this column reported on the current popularity of lightweight earphones (June 21), we received a cautionary letter from Dr. Jane Reger Madell, warning of possible injury to the ear. The risk, Dr. Madell points out, does not lie in the use of earphones as such, but rather in listening at excessive loudness levels. Too often, it seems, earphones tempt their users to sonic excess.   Dr. Madell has done some field work on this. As a member of an institution serving people with hearing impairments, she grew concerned about the sudden proliferation of earphones used with portable sound equipment as more and more people in this city and others go about their business in a state of sonic immersion.  Equipped with a precisely calibrated sound-level meter, she stopped wired-for-sound pedestrians on the streets, asking if she might measure the loudness level of their earphones. As it turned out, a lot of ambulatory music is played at loudness levels upward of 100 decibels (db) with some as high as 120 db, which is close to the sound level of unmuffled jackhammers heard from across a street.

headline: BRAILLE BOOKBINDING TRADITION AT TEMPLE
abstract: WHAT might a college student in Pakistan, a psychologist and educator in Michigan and a student in a Westchester vocational course have in common? They are blind, and in the course of their studies have used textbooks bound at the Braille bookbindery at Temple Israel in New Rochelle.   Since 1935, the volunteer staff at the bindery has hand-bound Braille books, free of charge, for anyone requesting the service.  Last year, 475 Braille volumes were completed at the bindery and sent to individuals and organizations nationwide, including the Library of Congress, The Jewish Braille Institute, The Institute for Contemporary Psychotherapy and the National Foundation for the Blind.    The 36 volunteers meet Tuesday mornings at the bindery - a large well-equipped room on the first floor of the temple, where bundles of sheets in Braille are stacked in the corner, ready to be bound into finished volumes.

headline: LECTURER OVERCOMES BLINDNESS AND DEAFNESS
abstract: Geraldine Lawhorn never hears the soothing Bach she plays on her piano. She never sees the eager faces of the students who sit in her classroom or the smiles of people who attend her lectures.   Miss Lawhorn is deaf and blind. But she knows when she hits a sour note on her piano or bombs with one of her audiences. It is an instinct she has developed over the years.

headline: Notes on People; Playboy in Braille
abstract: When a stopgap money bill for the Library of Congress was being considered by members of a House-Senate conference this week, Senator Mack Mattingly, a Republican of Georgia, saw a chance to do something about a magazine of which he disapproves.

headline: Blind Student Aided by Ex-Justice Stewart
abstract: For two hours yesterday, Potter Stewart, the recently retired Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, helped a blind second-year law student by reading parts of a law textbook at the Washington studios of Recordings for the Blind Inc.   The 66-year-old Mr. Stewart, who left the Court July 1 after 23 years, recorded part of ''The Rights of Aliens'' for William Poyner, a student at the Antioch School of Law in Washington.

headline: Sale of Celebrities' Castoffs Benefits Blind
abstract: It was raining, but that did not keep more than 200 people from lining up outside the Lighthouse for the Blind auditorium on 59th Street yesterday to buy castoff clothes from the wardrobes of such celebrities as Ethel Merman, Lauren Bacall and Betty Furness.   The association is holding its 10th annual Posh Sale of luxury items donated by fashion designers, artists and entertainers, in the hope that sales will outstrip last year's total of $160,000.

headline: DISPUTE IN WESTCHESTER ON DEAF CHILD ACCEPTED
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether public school systems may be required, under the terms of a 1975 Federal law, to provide sign-languate interpreters to assist deaf children in the classroom.   The case is an appeal by a northern Westchester school district from a Federal appeals court decision requiring it to provide a signlanguage interpreter for a deaf third grader. The appeals court based its ruling on the Education for All Handicapped Children Act, which gives handicapped children the right to a ''free appropriate public education'' and requires school districts to prepare an ''individualized education program'' to accomplish that goal for every handicapped child.   Because the case gives the Justices their first opportunity to define what Congress meant by the word ''appropriate,'' it has considerable nationwide significance.

headline: Connecticut Journal
abstract: ''THE umbrella doesn't quite cover us anymore,'' was the way David Hays, founder of the National Theater of the Deaf, described the decision to break away from the O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford to ''pursue our separate fortunes.''   ''We have grown to almost the same size as the center, financially,'' Mr. Hays continued, ''and although we don't anticipate severe budget cuts, we want the flexibility to face them as they come with our own board of trustees.''   ''We have been a wonderfully successful artistic theater or we wouldn't be here,'' Mr. Hays asserted. ''The exposure to fine actors in the company took the stigma out of sign language to the extent that Jane Fonda and Louise Fletcher used it in accepting their Oscars.''   Among those who have been trained at the Center are Phyllis Frelich, star of the Tony Award-winning ''Children of a Lesser God'' and Linda Bove of ''Sesame Street.''

headline: Suit by Deaf Wrestler
abstract: A 21-year-old student at Longmeadow (Mass.) High School filed a Federal class-action suit against state athletic regulations that bar anyone older than 19 from interscholastic competition.

headline: Study Finds Vitamin E Saving Infant Eyesight
abstract: High doses of vitamin E given to premature babies in the first 24 hours after birth can help prevent blindness sometimes caused by the extra oxygen they need to stay alive, researchers have reported.   The infants studied suffered from retrolental fibroplasia, one of the most important causes of childhood blindness, the research team said in the current issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline: 'SIGNED' INTO DRAMA
abstract: WHEN Alan Champion arrived in New York from St. Louis a year and a half ago, he wanted to be a song-and-dance man, so he headed for Broadway. But Mr. Champion also brought with him the skill of sign language, and before long, he was auditioning as an interpreter of live theater performances for the deaf.   Now the course of Mr. Champion's theatrical career has been diverted. After doing a solo sign-language interpretation of Ibsen's ''The Wild Duck'' at Adelphi University last season, Mr. Champion, who is 26 years old and hails from Tulsa, Okla., was named resident interpreter for the university's main stage, the Olmsted Theater.  There, he and another professional interpreter, Nancy Frishberg, a linguist, will be ''signing'' a matinee of Shakespeare's ''Twelfth Night'' on Saturday.

headline: ICE-SKATING COURSE FOR BLIND OFFERED
abstract: OLD BRIDGE THE Department of Parks and Recreation in this Middlesex County community has extended its free therapeutic ice-skating program to include blind residents throughout the state.   The program, now in its third season, has helped the neurologically impaired, the emotionally disturbed, slow learners and other handicapped persons.   This season's program, which began Oct. 17 and ended last Monday, will resume next month. Sessions are held on Saturdays from 9 to 10 A.M.

headline: Headliners; The Russian Treatment
abstract: Physicians in this country generally say there is no known treatment for retinitis pigmentosa, a vision-destroying disease.  Doctors in the Soviet Union, however, are of another opinion and so is 12-year-old Todd Cantrell.

headline: YELLOWSTONE'S BIGHORN SHEEP STRICKEN BY BLINDING AILMENT
abstract: Officials of Yellowstone Park in northwestern Wyoming are trying to determine what type of disease is causing blindness among a herd of bighorn sheep in the northern portion of the park.   A spokesman for the superintendent's office, Linda Miller, said about 27 sheep had been affected and 4 had died.  Miss Miller said autopsies had been performed and eye tissue sent to a veterinary diagnostic laboratory at Montana State University in Bozeman.

headline: Notes on People; Helping the Deaf 'Talk to Each Other' by Phone
abstract: It was during a shopping expedition for a pocket computer of his own that the proverbial light bulb went on above the head of Dr.  Harry Levitt of the Graduate School of the City University of New York.   Now he has been awarded the $10,000 first prize in what Johns Hopkins University calls its ''first national search for applications of personal computing to aid the handicapped.''

headline: The Doctor's World; 'CURE' FOR AN EYE AILMENT ILLUSTRATES THE PUBLIC'S VULNERABILITY TO CLAIMS
abstract: THE hereditary eye disorder called retinitis pigmentosa starts with night blindness. To imagine its effects, picture yourself awakening at 3 A.M. and, guided by the dim rays coming through a window from a street light, walking across your dark bedroom, only to stumble on an unseen chair.   To a child with retinitis pigmentosa - R.P. in medical jargon - vision may seem better some days than others. But when enough cells die in the periphery of the retina in the back of the eye, the child sees the world through a ''tunnel'' whose diameter is different in different cases.   Many youngsters with the disease cannot keep up with their homework and become separated from their friends as they change classes.  Others maintain good central vision and do well in school.

headline: JUSTICES TO HEAR APPEAL OF FURLOUGHED NEW YORK POLICE IN BIAS SUIT
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether proof of intentional discrimination was needed to establish violations of two key Federal civil rights laws.   The Court accepted an appeal by a group of furloughed black and Puerto Rican police officers in New York City from adverse rulings in the latest phase of their 10-year-old employment discrimination suit against the city.   The suit charged that the Civil Service examinations that the city used from 1968 to 1970 to establish the eligibility lists for appointment to the police force discriminated against blacks and Puerto Ricans. The plaintiffs charged that the tests, on which white candidates scored measurably higher than the minority applicants, asked irrelevant questions about politics, current events and the like that did not measure job performance.

headline: DEAF BOY DIAGNOSED AS RETARDED IN ERROR IS GIVEN $2.5 MILLION
abstract: New York State was ordered yesterday to pay $2.5 million to a 19-year-old man who spent nearly nine years in facilities for the mentally retarded when in fact he was only deaf.   Judge Edward J. Amann Jr. of the State Court of Claims ruled that as an infant, Donald Snow Jr. of Selden, L.I., was misdiagnosed as an imbecile and was sent to Willowbrook State Hospital on Staten Island.

headline: About New York; A CLASS LESSON SPEAKS LOUDER THAN WORDS
abstract: Sam Dui Lu and Michael Watson are friends. Anyone can tell the two like each other by the way they sit cross-legged on the floor and giggle and whisper and giggle again. Michael leans over and hums secrets into Sam's ear, and Sam leans over and does the same.   Sam is deaf, and Michael knows it, but since neither of them, at age 3, seems exactly sure what that means, they whisper anyhow, convinced that making sibilant sounds in someone's ear is an amusing concomitant of friendship.

headline: AID FOR AGED BLIND
abstract:
ON a recent morning, Milton Feld, director of the Home for the Aged Blind in Yonkers, returned to his office after having driven several residents to Mercy College. It was not one of his usual tasks, but no one else was available that morning, and he felt that it was important for the residents to attend the classes, which they had been auditing regularly throughout the semester.

''We try to encourage this,'' he explained. ''Our objective is to enable them to be as independent as possible.'' The Home for the Aged Blind was founded in the 1920's by the Jewish Guild for the Blind as a residence for blind children. As the services of the guild expanded to include social and vocational guidance, its philosophy evolved and by the late 1920's it was believed that a child's needs were best served in a home, rather than in an institutional setting. The children were gradually relocated, and elderly blind residents were admitted in their place.

headline: HIGH COURT WILL LET DEAF LAWYER UTILIZE VIDEO DISPLAY TUBE
abstract: The Supreme Court, bending its own rules, announced today that it would allow a deaf lawyer to set up a special computer-assisted system in the courtroom to enable him to argue a case later this year.   Without comment, the Court granted Michael A. Chatoff's proposal to install a video display screen in the courtroom from which he will be able to read the questions the Justices ask during the argument. Mr.  Chatoff, a 35-year-old graduate of Brooklyn Law School, can speak but cannot hear. With the help of a note-taking assistant, he successfully argued in two lower Federal courts the case now before the Supreme Court.

headline: COURT RULING SEEN AS BENEFIT FOR DEAF
abstract:
VALHALLA AUNITED STATES Supreme Court decision last week to permit computerassisted technology into the courtroom for a deaf lawyer who is defending a Westchester school girl's right to have a classroom interpreter ''is a breakthrough for the right of deaf people to be heard,'' according to Janet Acevedo, who trains interpreters at Westchester Community College.

Michael A. Chatoff is representing Amy Rowley and her parents, Clifford and Nancy Rowley, in a suit to force statewide school provision of individual sign language interpreters for certain deaf children during classroom time. Amy is in the fourth grade in the Hendrick Hudson School District in Cortlandt and has had the help of an interpreter, Fran Miller, who is paid by the district.

Miss Acevedo, coordinator of the interpreter-training program at the college, explained that Mr. Chatoff could not use a signer because it is not a language he understands. Most adults who lose their hearing in their mature years, as he did, she said, have not acquired the signing skills that Amy learned as a child.

headline: Cheerful Expressions
abstract: The crowd doesn't reach the decibel level as it does at Carrier Dome in Syracuse, but there is a respectable amount of bellowing when the cheerleading squad at the Montana School for the Deaf and Blind asks the crowd to support the boys high school basketball team.   The five female cheerleaders at the school in Great Falls all suffer from impaired hearing, two of them seriously. And many of the 60 or 70 fans at an average home game also suffer from varying degrees of deafness. For that reason, the cheerleaders, along with chanting the conventional yells, supplement them in sign language.

headline: ABOUT NEW YORK
abstract: This is a story about running, and about altruism, about being handicapped, or maybe about not being handicapped at all. It is a sports story, and it is a love story.   Some of the people who live on the quiet side streets around Kissena Park in Flushing, Queens, already know this story, or at least part of it. They have seen Joe Pardo, the muscles throbbing in his legs, the rubber soles of his shoes slapping the ground, running around the stretches of lawn and the golf course.

headline: DEAF-BLIND CENTER FACES BUDGET CUTS
abstract:
SANDS POINT AMONG the many services to the handicapped facing drastic cuts in the Reagan Administration's proposed budget is the Helen Keller National Center for Deaf-Blind Youths and Adults, nestled in an area here of affluent homes and estates.

Martin Adler, the director of an institution that he describes as ''the only national center for rehabilitation of the deaf-blind,'' said the proposal called for slashing $1.4 million from its current allocation of $3.2 million. This would mean, he said, that there would be hardly enough left to pay for salaries in a situation where the ratio of staff to clients, one-to-one plus support aides, is necessarily so high.

In an interview with Mr. Adler and Robert Smithdas, the center's deaf-blind director of community education, the director saw a glimmer of hope in a bill before Congress that would exempt the center from the across-the-board cuts in discretionary funds that most services to the handicapped are expected to suffer.

The measure is sponsored by by Representative John LeBoutillier of Westbury, the freshman Republican whose Sixth Congressional District on the North Shore includes Sands Point, and Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, a Middletown, N.Y., Republican.

headline: EDUCATION
abstract: THE Supreme Court of the United States is scheduled to hear oral arguments today in the case of Amy Rowley, a deaf fourth grader from Peekskill, N.Y., to decide whether public school systems may be required to provide sign language interpreters in the classroom.   Educators across the nation are looking to the case for a definition of what Congress meant in 1975 when it passed a law requiring all school districts to provide a ''free appropriate public education'' to handicapped children.   Does an ''appropriate'' education mean one that enables a child to become, as a Federal District Court posed the issue, ''a functioning member of society''? Or does it mean giving a handicapped child such as Amy, who had been performing in the top half of her class when her parents requested an interpreter, what the court called ''an opportunity to achieve his full potential''?   The case comes when educators throughout the nation are grappling with the practical implications of the law, the Education for All Handicapped Children Act, which called for sweeping changes in the instruction of handicapped children, who have been long neglected by school systems.

headline: FIRST DEAF LAWYER GOES BEFORE SUPREME COURT
abstract: In a stirring plea on behalf of a 10-yearold deaf girl from northern Westchester County, a 35-year-old graduate of Brooklyn Law School today became the first deaf lawyer to argue before the United States Supreme Court.   With the help of a computerized video display screen, the lawyer, Michael A. Chatoff, who can speak but not hear, communicated with the nine Justices during oral arguments by reading their questions and then speaking back to them.   ''This is a tough world, and it is going to be as tough for Amy as it is for every other child,'' said Mr. Chatoff in halting, dissonant speech, as the Justices leaned forward in their seats to be able to hear. ''If she's going to be able to compete she must receive an education equal to those of other children.''

headline: Deaf Will Get Sign Aid At Opera 'Susannah'
abstract: The New York City Opera will present ''Susannah'' in a sign-interpreted performance for the deaf Tuesday at 8 P.M.  Two interpreters will be on the left side of the stage. All available front orchestra seats are being held for sale to the hearing-impaired.

headline: CITY OPERA TO BE ALIVE WITH THE SIGNS OF MUSIC
abstract: The New York City Opera, whose performance tonight of "Susannah" will be the first in the city to be interpreted in sign language, is wrestling with an unusual concept: To Give the deaf an idea of the sound of music, what clues can be provided through the "look" of music?   The performance is the season's third and last of Carlisle Floyd's English-language opera set in rural Tennessee in the 1930's. As the Rev. Olin Blitch, Little Bat, Sam and Susannah sing on stage, two young sign-language "artistic interpreters" will be spotlighted downstage right.   To make visual music as well as verbal sense of the songs, plot, rhythms and phrasings, they have also experimented with gestures, eye expressions and body language. Their vocabulary - not unlike silent singing or dancing in place from the waist up - stops short of standing on tiptoe and reaching manually for the high notes.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: An article in Metropolitan Report on March 24 about the first deaf lawyer to argue before the United States Su- preme Court incorrectly identified the developer of a video display screen that was used in the courtroom. It was invented by Translation Systems Inc.  of Rockville, Md.

headline: Briefing
abstract: Eggs That Go Beep   The magic of miniaturized electronics has opened the spring ritual of the Easter egg hunt to a group that could never participate before. Next Saturday on the grounds of the Washington monument, the National Park Service and C&P Telephone Company employees will ''hide'' artificial eggs that emit a soft beeping sound, and blind children will hunt for them, with prizes for the most successful. No color, but a lot more fun than no hunt at all.

headline: De Tocqueville on Tape
abstract: Partly because of his own handicap - he is hard of hearing - Senator Charles H. Percy will soon begin tape-recording Alexis de Tocqueville's 700-page classic, ''Democracy in America,'' for a blind woman.   Mr. Percy, who is abroad in connection with his position as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, had been thinking for some time about becoming a volunteer for the New York-based Recording for the Blind Inc., his office said yesterday.

headline: California High Court Backs Damages for Child Born Deaf
abstract: A girl born deaf to parents who say she should not have been born at all is entitled to damages, the State Supreme Court ruled Monday.   The decision reversed a Fresno County Superior Court ruling and ordered that court to consider special damages in behalf of Joy Turpin, the second child of James and Donna Turpin.

headline: LASER USE REPORTED EFFECTIVE IN AVERTING BLINDNESS IN ELDERLY
abstract: A new laser procedure has proved highly effective in treating the leading cause of newly developed cases of blindness among the elderly, the National Eye Institute reported today.   The results are so promising that the institute took the unusual step of disclosing them at a news conference to spread the word quickly. It has also terminated further clinical tests and today urged all potential patients to seek the laser treatment promptly.   The nonsurgical treatment, which takes 10 minutes, is almost useless if not applied within a few weeks of the onset of symptoms.  The disease, called senile macular degeneration, can cause loss of vision when tiny blood vessels grow into and displace the macula, the thumbtack-sized structure that controls central vision in the retina.

headline: Hard of Hearing Group Receives Service Award
abstract: The state's Department of Health has cited the New York League for the Hard of Hearing for its 72 years of work in rehabilitating the hearing-impaired.   Irving S. Berelson, president of the league's board, received the citation last week from Bernard Zazula, director of the Health Department's Bureau for Handicapped Children.

headline: FOR A DEAF CHILD, A 'FRIENDLY TOWN'
abstract: From the stoop of his mother's house in the South Bronx, Desmond Foster can see vacant lots and buildings hollowed by fire. But that is not all there is to his world. From the time he was 7 years old, Desmond, who is deaf, has also seen the green hills and clear streams of the country in summer, where he goes to visit a family in the Lower Hudson Valley.   Desmond, now 12, goes to the country through the Fresh Air Fund, an independent, nonprofit group that sends underprivileged children from New York City to camps or to stay with families in the country for two to four weeks.

headline: CASEWORKER TO HISTORY'S VICTIMS
abstract: When Susan Thames Pettiss was in the fifth grade in Mobile, Ala., she was asked what she would like to be when she grew up. ''My mother wasn't a circus acrobat or President of the country, so I said I would like to be a plain lady like she was,'' she recalled the other day.   Dr. Pettiss, who retired this month as director of blindness prevention for Helen Keller International because she will soon be 70, turned out in fact to be anything but ''a plain lady.'' Participant in History   Rather, she became a witness and often a direct participant in several major historical events of the last four decades. She was in Europe when World War II ended and helped countless refugees build new lives. She was in South Vietnam to plan for reconstruction of essential services ''after we had won the war,'' she said, when the Tet offensive was started by the other side. She was a student at an American university when the protests of the late 1960's erupted, and she marched in opposition to the war. She was in Afghanistan, helping establish a program to prevent blindness in children, when Soviet troops invaded.

headline: MRS. REAGAN VISITS BLIND YOUTHS IN PARIS
abstract: Nancy Reagan visited the National Institute for Blind Youth today and, as usual when on public display, she looked happier and considerably more relaxed with the children than she does with adults.   From the moment she walked in the door, where she was greeted by Monique Petit, the director of the institute, she unbent from the protocol formality observed on most occasions. She took the hand of Patrick Lucas, an 11-year-old blind student who accompanied her throughout the visit, patted his arm as he stood beside her while she received a briefing on the school, and generally looked at ease.   When she was told that Patrick had something of a reputation as a singer, she said, ''Later on we'll get in a corner and he'll sing.  Right, Patrick?'' Patrick looked doubtful. Mrs. Reagan continued, ''You sing and I'll hum, just you and me alone.'' Patrick, who has an English mother and French father and speaks English, grinned, shook his head and said, ''No.'' Whenever Patrick fell behind during the tour, Mrs. Reagan would look back, take his hand, or call, ''Patrick, Patrick.''

headline: DEAF, BLIND, AND NOW Ph.D.
abstract: Shut off from the seeing and hearing world by blindness and deafness, Adeline Becht has proved herself in the classroom and is ready to take on the clinic.   The 48-year-old Portland woman graduated today from the University of Oregon with two doctoral degrees in clinical and counseling psychology.

headline: EXCERPTS FROM JUSTICES' OPINION IN CASE OF A DEAF GIRL AND SCHOOL DISTRICT
abstract: Following are excerpts from today's Supreme Court ruling that Federal law does not require schools to provide sign-language interpreters for deaf children. The majority opinion was written by Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist, and the dissenting opinion by Associate Justice Byron R. White. For the Majority Justice Rehnquist   This case presents a question of statutory interpretation.  Petitioners contend that the Court of Appeals and the District Court misconstrued the requirements imposed by Congress upon states which receive Federal funds under the Education for All Handicapped Children Act. We agree and reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.   The Education for All Handicapped Children Act of 1975 provides Federal money to assist state and local agencies in educating handicapped children, and conditions such funding upon a state's compliance with extensive goals and procedures.

headline: EFFECT OF HANDICAPPED RULING UNCLEAR
abstract: The Supreme Court's decision yesterday that a Peekskill, N.Y., school district does not have to provide a sign-language interpreter to a deaf fourth grader was greeted yesterday with expressions of relief from school boards across the country and with disappointment by groups representing the deaf and other handicapped youngsters.   The decision marks the first time the nation's highest court has ruled on a law, passed by Congress in 1975, that requires all school districts to provide a ''free appropriate public education'' to handicapped children.   As lawyers reviewed the decision late yesterday, it remained unclear what its impact would be on the 4.4 million handicapped children across the country who are now in special education programs. Learning Could Be Impeded   For 10-year-old Amy Rowley of Peekskill, however, the immediate impact of the decision will be that she will lose her personal signlanguage interpreter, a loss that Nancy Rowley, Amy's mother, said could impede her daughter's ability to learn.

headline: SCHOOLS BACKED ON LIMITING AID TO HANDICAPPED
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal law entitles handicapped children to a public education from which they can derive ''some educational benefit.'' But the Court said that local school districts are not obliged to provide services that such children need to reach their full academic potential.   In a 6-to-3 decision, the Court overturned rulings by two Federal courts in New York that had ordered a Westchester County school district to provide a sign-language interpreter for a deaf fourth grader.   The lower courts interpreted a Federal law, the Education for All Handi- Excerpts from opinions, page B4. capped Children Act of 1975, to require local schools to give each handicapped child ''an opportunity to achieve his full potential.'' Under that standard, the lower courts said, the Hendrick Hudson Central School District had to provide the fourth grader, Amy Rowley, with a sign-language interpreter in the classroom.

headline: MOTHER OF DEAF PUPIL CRITICIZES DECISION
abstract: CORTLANDT ''DO the judges read or do their homework? -they're just ignorant,'' said Nancy Rowley last week, after learning the Supreme Court had ruled that the Hendrick Hudson Central School District did not have to provide a sign-language interpreter for her 10-year-old daughter, Amy, who is deaf.   The decision marked the first time the nation's highest court had ruled on a law, passed by Congress in 1975, that requires school districts to provide ''free appropriate public education'' to handicapped children.   ''I just can't believe it,'' Mrs. Rowley said. ''This is a setback - way back - for deaf people and perhaps all the handicapped. Are they going to take away Braille books for the blind and ramps for people in wheelchairs?''

headline: POSTAGE SUBSIDY CUTS WILL HURT THE BLIND
abstract: To the Editor:    Few would disagree with the desire to reduce Federal spending by eliminating waste and ineffective programs. Those concerned over the reduction or demise of social programs have been assured that the truly disenfranchised would not suffer.

headline: ABOUT NEW YORK
abstract: The Matilda Ziegler magazine is, in a very small way, an institution, and like many institutions, it has also become a kind of friend. People write it letters, recall the first time they ever received it or learned to read it; last December it got nearly 50 Christmas cards.   In this, its 75th year, it has been deluged with letters, not about the quality of its articles or the slant of its editorial policy, just long chatty letters about how things are getting on back home.   Most of them are from people who have read The Ziegler for years, and for whom it was, initially, something more than a magazine. They are the people who first found in its pages, blank except for a collection of raised dots, an entree to the interests and issues of sighted people that had been denied them because they were blind.

headline: DEAF AND SAFE DRIVERS
abstract: To the Editor:    In your July 13 Topics item ''Walkman vs.

headline:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
WHITE PLAINS
abstract:
IT first appears to be an ordinary swimming class. Two instructors in sleek tank suits are putting their students through the paces, showing them the proper way to crook an arm, the efficient means of treading water. There are exclamations of sudden understanding, a few frustrated laughs when a point is not well taken.

On closer examination, however, it becomes apparent that this is not just any lesson. Before they enter the pool, the pupils are guided around its decks, and are told what material the lane dividers are made of so that they might recognize them by touch. When they do submerge, they are oriented as to their positions in the water.

This is a class for the blind and visually impaired. Available free of charge, it is held Thursday evenings through Aug. 19 at the White Plains Y.M.C.A., and is sponsored by the Y and the Westchester Lighthouse for the Blind. Participants register through the Lighthouse, a nonprofit agency serving more than 500 people in the county.

headline: Glenn's Devotion
abstract: Mike Glenn hasn't forgotten where he came from. The 6-foot-3-inch guard of the Atlanta Hawks grew up in Rome, Ga., where his father was a mathematics teacher and the basketball coach at the Georgia School for the Deaf. Glenn played with his father's team in practices and easily picked up sign language.

headline: POSTAL FUNDS IN LIMBO
abstract: To the Editor:    The letter in The Times from officials of the Jewish Braille Institute of America (July 6) gives the impression that Postal Service subsidies that provide free mail for the blind and discounts for nonprofit mail classes are on the verge of being eliminated.  While the officials' concern is understandable, pronouncing the end of these subsidies is very much premature.

headline: RATIONING MEDICINE
abstract: The Supreme Court recently handed down what will probably become a landmark decision when it denied deaf 11-year-old Amy Rowley a full-time sign-language interpreter to help her at school. What it did, in effect, was to lay down a principle for rationing scarce social services for those who need but cannot afford them. The principle and its corollaries are likely to be influential far beyond the world of the handicapped.   We Americans don't like the concept of rationing. That fact probably explains why we have tried to avoid the basic problem opened up by the vast expansion of Government-financed social services begun in the Johnson Administration and continually expanded until these still-young parsimonious 1980's.

headline: A Complete Explanation
abstract: B unny Louise Torres was born at Beth Israel Medical Center the other day while her deaf mother, Jackie, conveyed her own reactions with finger-spelling, and Mindy Burstein, using sign language, relayed the obstetrician's instructions every step of the way. It was not an unusual assignment for Miss Burstein, who is believed to be the only full-time sign-language interpreter on the staff of a hospital in the city.

headline: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
abstract: Traveling Exhibition For Visually Handicapped   An exhibition for people who might never visit museums has been organized by the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Directed at the visually handicapped, the show will travel around New York City from Sept. 8 to June 29.

headline: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
abstract: Sense of Delight   E usevio Vega of the Bronx couldn't see his 18th birthday very well yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. But circling the Fragrance Garden for the Blind, he could taste the special day - in sweet marjoram, fennel, pineapple sage and a dozen other herbs.

headline: POLITICAL ACTION URGED FOR DEAF
abstract: HARTFORD Deaf people and those who are hearing-impaired are realizing that ''politics is the business of survival,'' said Betty Hudson, Governor O'Neill's special assistant for human services, during a workshop here sponsored by the National Registry of Interpreters for the Deaf last week.   ''You're either going to play the political game or you're going to risk losing,'' Mrs. Hudson told members of the organization.  ''Because we're now facing potential cuts to human services budgets, the handicapped must become politically vigilant. The times require it for all groups who have spent the past decade trying to enter the mainstream of human life.''

headline: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
abstract: Rockwell Kent Centenary   A retrospective celebrating the centenary of the birth of Rockwell Kent, a graphic artist noted for his compelling realism, will be mounted in the Central Research Library of the New York Public Library, from Sept. 24 through Nov. 30.   One of America's best-known graphic artists, Kent became a polemicist for such causes as Sacco and Vanzetti, for which he illustrated a print entitled ''August XXIII, MCMXVII,'' the date of their execution.

headline: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS
abstract: 'Joseph' Performance To Be Signed for Deaf   A sign-interpreted performance for deaf audiences of ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat'' will be sponsored by the Theater Development Fund next Tuesday at the Royale Theater, 242 West 45th Street.   The show, with music by Andrew Lloyd Webber and lyrics by Tim Rice, will be simultaneously signed by two interpreters.

headline: Ultrasonic Cane
abstract: A new use was proposed in July 1981 for the ultrasonic range finders used in Polaroid cameras. The Polaroid Corporation of Cambridge, Mass., obtained a patent to use the equipment in a warning cane for the blind.

headline: THEATER OF THE DEAF RELOCATING
abstract:
WATERFORD THE National Theater of the Deaf is looking for a new home, in many ways one not unlike the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center where it was created 15 years ago.

Its founder and artistic director, David Hays, said that the Theater of the Deaf would relocate sometime before April, when its lease expires at the O'Neill.

Although Mr. Hays expects to remain in Connecticut, he declined to say where he is looking. ''This is a varied state,'' he said, ''and it's hard to imagine that we'd have to go elsewhere. But we're not limiting the search.''

headline: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
abstract: THE 22-foot-high red steel tower will never be seen by those for whom it was built. It sits in the courtyard of the new $9 million State Library for the Blind and Handicapped in Trenton, which was dedicated last Friday.   On top of the column, in large raised dots of Braille - the written language of the blind - the words ''Earth, sky and imagination'' have been inscribed. Closer to the ground, at about hand level, the artist, Tal Streeter of Millbrook, N.Y., has written an essay in Braille. To find out what it says, a sighted viewer must ask a blind person.   ''Some blind people spend so much of their time being read to by sighted people that being asked to translate turns out to be quite a switch for them,'' said Robert G.Hawkins, assistant director of the library.

headline: HEARING AIDS: SMALLER, EVEN FASHIONABLE
abstract: Designer glasses, move over.  Two Purdue University professors, David Goldstein and Carl Binnie, predict designer hearing aids may be next to enjoy a sales boom.   ''We're in the earliest stage of a new trend in hearing aids,'' said Professor Goldstein, who with Professor Binnie directs the hearing clinic at Purdue. Both are professors of audiology and speech sciences and provide professional training in audiology at the clinic.

headline: DEAF STUDENTS JOIN THE HEARING WORLD
abstract:
RIVERHEAD THE Cleary secondary program at Mercy High School will hold its first graduation ceremony next June and eight deaf students are expected to receive their high school diplomas. All eight, according to Sister Maura Costello, coordinator of the program for 25 deaf students who are ''mainstreamed'' into classes at the 575-student parochial school here, are interested in going to college or obtaining further career training.

Although Cleary is a private school, the secondary program, which started three years ago, is state-financed. Thirteen on the Cleary school staff -Sister Costello, three teachers of the deaf, a speech teacher, a counselor and seven interpreter-tutors - join about 20 teachers at Mercy High School to provide a comprehensive program of academic and supportive services to the deaf students here, who are bused from all over Suffolk County.

''Some of these students have previously gone to schools for the deaf,'' Sister Costello said, ''but here they have the experience of the hearing world, and yet they have each other for support.  Everyone gets mainstreamed for at least one subject, even if it is only physical education.

headline: Operetta to Be Signed
abstract: The 2 P.M. Saturday performance of ''The Merry Widow'' at the New York City Opera will be interpreted in sign language. Two interpreters in costume will be at the left side of the stage; all available front orchestra seats are being set aside for people with hearing impairments. Information: 870-5637.

headline: Education Program for Deaf Infants
abstract: Because the excellent article ''Deaf Students in a Hearing World'' (Oct. 17) focused on mandatory education for deaf children from the age of 3, readers may not have realized that there is an educational program for hearing-impaired children below 3.   The Cleary School's Deaf Infant Program (state-funded and free to parents) emphasizes parent-child communication and the development of language during those first three years so crucial to learning.

headline: BOOKLET SIMPLIFIES INSPECTION OF CARS
abstract: A few years ago Don Fried, then a law student living in San F rancisco, was in the market for a used car, a subject he knew very l ittle about.   ''They'd tell me the cars were in good shape,'' he recalled, ''but the mechanics I hired to check the vehicles always found either major things wrong with the car or a lot of little things.'' After spending ''a lot of weekends and several hundred dollars on mechanics,'' he finally ended up buying a brand-new car. The experience led Mr.  Fried, now a lawyer and a consumer advocate, to check on publications, including state and government books, on the subject of cars.

headline:
A CHRISTMAS APPEAL: GIVE TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND;
WILL FOR INDEPENDENCE DESPITE HER HANDICAPS
abstract:
''IWAS in shock for almost a week - I couldn't sleep,'' said Nancy J, describing what happened after her apartment was vandalized last month.

Such an experience can be painful for anyone, but it was especially so for Nancy J, who is 31 years old and still not completely adjusted to the total blindness that overcame her three years ago.

''I went home. There was a mess in the house. I couldn't tell what happened. My neighbors heard me scream and came over and told me.'' Her mattress had been cut open. Food was spread over the floors and walls. Her cane was broken and food for her guide-dog stolen. Her coffee-maker, radio, and alarm clock were gone.

headline: ERNIE D'S ESCAPE FROM LIMBO
abstract: It's the varsity against the much younger and shorter junior varsity, but the Jayvees have an equalizer: they have Ernie D, who, feeling younger by the minute, has the ball.   The new basketball coach at the Rhode Island School for the Deaf aims at the basket now from 20 feet out, but passes off instead of shooting. The pass is one of those special-delivery types, the kind of traffic-threader that helped Ernie DiGregorio become rookie of the year in the National Basketball Association nine long seasons ago.   This one goes to 12-year-old Nick Testone, a roving forward with a yellow elastic brace on his right knee. He is wearing the brace not because the knee needs it but because, as the coach said later, ''They're all actors.'' The youngster bobbles the pass, but recovers to sink the layup.

headline: AILEY TEACHING DANCE TO BLIND TEEN-AGERS
abstract: ''Reach up, come forward and out to the side,'' Alvin Ailey called out in the huge, bright studio at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center. ''To the right. To the left. Now everybody hug. Who do you want to hug? Well, hug them.''

headline: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
abstract: Gifts for a Hero   S ince 29-year-old Reginald Andrews, an unemployed father of eight, rescued a blind man from beneath a subway car last Monday on his way home from a job interview, his fortunes have turned upside down. There was the phone call from President Reagan, a job from Jamac Frozen Foods on West 16th Street and, suddenly, money in the bank.

headline: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
abstract: ATECHNOLOGICAL innovation pioneered by a small Massachusetts company has made books and magazines substantially more accessible for Long Island's 4,500 blind residents, through the efforts of the Suffolk Cooperative Library System, the Xerox Corporation and New York State.   During the last year, eight Long Island libraries have acquired the device, the highly sophisticated Kurzweil Reading Machine, which can read aloud nearly all printed material, according to Pamela Barr, director of the Suffolk Cooperative Library System's division on reading for the handicapped. The machines are available for anyone with a visual impairment.   The Reading Machine was developed by the Kurzweil Reading Company in Cambridge, Mass., and is manufactured by the Xerox Corporation. It sells for $30,000 and consists of three table-top components: a keyboard with 30 different functions, a computer and a scanner that resembles a small office copying machine.

headline: HELPING THE DEAF TO MANAGE MONEY
abstract:
GROTON THREE years ago, Lyle Kennedy and his sister, Margaret, were getting to know each other again. Even though each had married and moved apart, they were now getting together at least once a month.

Their attempts to grow even closer were halted when Margaret died two Christmases ago. For Mr. Kennedy, the loss was particularly hard because his sister was deaf and he felt as though he had lost his last chance to get to know her better.

headline: SUBWAY CARS HELD PERILOUS FOR THE BLIND
abstract: Spokesmen for New York's major organizations for the blind said yesterday that two models of the city's subway cars posed a serious danger to the blind, the visually impaired and the elderly.   The cars are the virtually identical R-44 and R-46 models, which run on the BMT and IND lines. In recent weeks, blind people have been in two subway accidents, one of them fatal, that involved these cars.

headline: RECOVERY IS IN THE EYE OF THE BEHOLDER
abstract:
LIVINGSTON KEN REYNOLDS looked at the nurses in the 3700 wing at St. Barnabas Medical Center here, where he had been a kidney-transplant patient three years earlier.

''I'm so glad to see you,'' he said, ''and this time I really mean it.'' After being blind for six years, the 39-year-old diabetic from the town of Middlesex could see for the first time the nurses who had cared for him after transplant surgery in 1979.

His case is an extraordinary one, said his physician, Dr. Martin Jacobs of the St. Barnabas nephrology staff.  The spirited Mr. Reynolds has been a lifeguard, wrestling coach, physical-education instructor and a business and photography teacher in the Middlesex school system.

headline: PROGRAM BRINGS OUT THE BEST IN GIFTED DEAF TEEN-AGERS
abstract:
OMAHA KAREN MALISZEWSKI is a tall, slender strawberry-blonde 13-year-old who excels in mathematics, spelling and art. Except for math, Karen's grades do not reflect the fact that she has been identified as gifted, with an I.Q. of 140.

But she will never be quite like the 1,100 other students at Lewis and Clark Junior High School in Omaha. Along with an estimated 410,000 children in the United States age 18 and under, Karen is deaf.

headline: NEW CHIEF OF BLINDNESS SOCIETY
abstract: Lisa Semple, executive director of the Fresh Air Fund since 1975, has been named executive director of the National Society to Prevent Blindness, the society announced.   She succeeds Virginia S. Boyce, who retired at the end of December after 45 years with the voluntary health agency, serving for the last 10 years as its executive director. Mrs. Semple assumed her duties on Jan. 1.

headline:
PATENTS;
Classroom Signals For Deaf Students
abstract: A method to improve the teaching of deaf students in a class with students with normal hearing was patented this week by Prof. Robert Sapora, who teaches English at Western Maryland College in Westminster.

headline: Obligation to Deaf
abstract: The question before the United States Supreme Court was: What did the Federal Education for All Handicapped Children Act of 1975 mean when it said handicapped children were entitled to a ''free appropriate public education''?   Lower courts had interpreted it to mean that the Hendrick Hudson School District in New York State must provide a sign-language interpreter for a deaf fourth-grader, Amy Rowley, so she could reach her full learning potential.

headline: INCREASE IN HEARING LOSS AMONG INFANTS PUZZLES DOCTORS
abstract: MEDICAL experts at three major hearing treatment centers report that the number of cases of severe hearing loss in infants has increased dramatically in the past year. The doctors are concerned and puzzled about the cause.   Dr. Jane Madell, director of audiology for the Manhattan-based New York League for the Hard of Hearing, said in an interview that a recent study of the league's records showed that 24 infants under the age of 18 months with profound hearing impairment were brought in for diagnosis and treatment in the last six months. There were only five such cases in the previous six months.

headline: FOOD NOTES
abstract: A Taste of Mississippi   As it has many times before, food recently bridged the gap between two distant cultures. Not two different countries but two different states: New York and Mississippi.   One of the Mississippi cooks wasn't even sure she wanted to come to New York. One of the New York eaters wasn't sure he would like Mississippi food because he ''didn't think they knew how to cook down there.''

headline: The Editorial Notebook; Who Will Pick Up Maureen and Louie?
abstract: One very cold night last week a blind woman with a Seeing Eye dog got on the Ninth Avenue bus. With the dog curled at her feet, the woman faced the other passengers and asked if anyone was getting off at 12th Street. Could such a person put her in a cab? A young man promised to help. ''She's so brave,'' said the woman at my right.  ''We can see, and we walk around frightened, while she goes out like that, with just the dog. It's wonderful.''

headline: HANDLING DEAFNESS IN A MODERN WAY
abstract:
AT the office for the Disabled in White Plains, September Polk, a staff interpreter, answers the phone. A light attached to the console indicates that the call requires the use of special equipment. She places the receiver in a cradle extension, and types on the phone keyboard: ''Office for the Disabled. This is September Polk. May I help you? - GA (Go Ahead).''

The message from the caller appears on the console screen, followed by the letters, GA - the signal that tells Miss Polk that it is her turn to respond. She conveys the information the caller needs and concludes the call. The telecommunication device is only one way in which this county office is able to aid and inform the hearing impaired of Westchester.

''Many people in the world today find deafness mystifying,'' said Miss Polk, who is not hearing impaired. ''Throughout history, people have associated the inability to hear and speak clearly with a lack of intelligence. Even the legendary Aristotle declared that 'if one has no speech, one has no soul.' The deaf feel that they must constantly disprove the notion that they are mentally impaired. Some fight actively to dispel that belief.''

headline: A Law to Cure Blindness
abstract: A quirk in state law keeps some New Yorkers blind when they could be cured by the implantation of corneal tissue from a dead donor.  There's no easier way to cure some people's blindness than to amend the law.

headline: CABBIES IN VIOLATION OF A HUMAN RIGHTS LAW
abstract: To the Editor:     Mary Cantwell raised an important issue in her Feb. 10 Editorial Notebook article, ''Who Will Pick Up Maureen and Louie?'': cab drivers' refusal to serve people with Seeing Eye dogs.   his practice is a blatant violation of the New York State human rights law, which prohibits discrimination in the access to a place of public accommodation because of a disability.

headline: DEVICES THAT HELP THE DEAF AT HOME
abstract: FOR Marge Solomon, deaf since infancy because of typhoid fever, making a telephone call was an impossible task that her Brooklyn neighbors had to handle for her. ''I hated asking them to do me a favor every time,'' she said. ''I was not an independent person.''   But for several years now, the 63-year-old Mrs. Solomon has placed her own calls at home, using a typewriterlike telecommunications device for the deaf (known as a T.D.D. to those who use and sell them), which is connected to a conventional telephone. It allows her to conduct conversations in print over phone lines with others who have similar equipment.

headline: ORGANIZATIONS THAT ASSIST THE DEAF
abstract: Additional information on services for the deaf is available through these organizations and agencies:   Deafnet, Deaf Communications Institute Inc., Deaf Community Center, Bethany Hill, Framingham, Mass. 01701; 617-875-3617 (voice or telecommunications device for the deaf), 213-886-6193 (voice or T.D.D.). An electronic mail network.

headline: COMPANIES THAT SELL THE DEVICES
abstract: These are some of the companies that sell communication and noisealerting devices for the deaf: T.D.D.'s and Signaling Equipment   Converse Communications Center, P.O. Box 94, West Hartford, Conn.  06107; 203-236-6266 (voice or T.D.D.).Medco Surgical Supply Inc., 220-30 Jamaica Avenue, Queens Village, N.Y. 11428; 212-740-9100 (voice), 212-740-9120 (T.D.D.).

headline: 27 YEARS OF TRAINING DOGS TO HELP THE BLIND
abstract:
GUIDING Eyes for the Blind of Yorktown Heights has helped more than 2,500 people achieve greater mobility through the use of highly trained guide dogs. ''With a guide dog, the blind person receives more attention,'' said Geoff Lock, general manager of the nonprofit organization. ''If they are unaccompanied by sighted people, more courtesy is extended to them out of respect for the working relationship of the dog and human being.''

For 27 years, Guiding Eyes has tried to change what Mr. Lock says is a common pattern of treatment accorded the blind. ''As if it isn't bad enough to be sightless,'' he said, ''imagine being made to feel invisible. Sales personnel, acquaintences and even some relatives talk to others who accompany the disabled person, even about them, as if he or she wasn't there, making them feel all the more dependent.''

headline: Tax Help for the Blind
abstract: Filling out a tax form is hard enough, but what if you couldn't read the instructions? Yesterday at the Lighthouse on East 59th Street, the New York Association for the Blind provided trained volunteers and I.R.S. employees to help with the infamous forms due in less than a month. Help continues today from 1 P.M. to 8 P.M.   Chi-yim Siu of Yorkville is annoyed that the Federal Government does not allow him to submit a form in Braille.

headline: ADVOCATES FOR BLIND DIVIDED ON SUBWAY SAFETY
abstract: Groups representing the blind have divided on whether the Transit Authority should install a new kind of barrier to help prevent passengers standing on station platforms from falling between subway cars.   The barriers would be placed on trains made up of the newest cars on the system, the R-44 and R-46 models, which are used on the BMT and IND divisions. Unlike older-model cars, there are no gates between these cars when approached from the platform.

headline: 'PARZIVAL' STAGED BY AND FOR THE DEAF
abstract: At the beginning of ''Parzival,'' the medieval German poem, a boy is in a deep, quiet forest. He is kept in seclusion by his mother, who fears that if he sees a knight, he will be tempted to become one and will eventually die in combat. One day, however, some knights pass through the forest, and Parzival is indeed enthralled. He follows them and eventually becomes a knight, but he must face many severe tests - encounters with beasts, knights and women - before he becomes a truly strong man.   This weekend, at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn, the story of Parzival, based on the work by Wolfram von Eschenbach, will be performed by the National Theater of the Deaf.  From time to time, the actors will break away from the story to give short, speeches based on their own experiences as deaf children growing up in a hearing world.

headline: RELATING TO THE DISABLED
abstract: PEOPLE tend to raise their voices when they first speak with Sandy Seltzer - because she is blind. ''It just points up the immense ignorance of the able-bodied where it comes to dealing with the disabled,'' said Mrs. Seltzer, who lives in Mineola. She believes she is the only person on the Island who has carved a career out of teaching the able-bodied to overcome fear, discomfort and an extreme lack of knowledge in relating to the handicapped - be they family, friends, business associates, schoolmates or customers.

headline: OF THE DEAF, FOR ALL
abstract: To the Editor:    The Times's excellent March 18 review of the National Theater of the Deaf's ''Parzival'' was marred by a misleading headline, stating we are a theater for the deaf.

headline: Famous Anonymous Donor
abstract: Somewhere in the city, thanks to the late Arthur Godfrey, are two people who are a step closer to having their sight restored.

headline:
PATENTS;
Phone Ring Detector Has a Visual Display
abstract: A new telephone ringing detector for the deaf, which has a visual display, was patented this week for Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. Richard G. Sparber of Wheaton, Ill., obtained patent 4,379,210.

headline: GIFT ESTABLISHES FIRST HOME FOR NATIONAL DEAF THEATER
abstract: The National Theater of the Deaf will have a home for the first time, thanks to a gift of $250,000 from Irving Stark, a retired businessman from East Norwalk, Conn. The contribution will establish the Hazel E. Stark Center of the National Theater of the Deaf in Chester, Conn.   The company is a professional touring troupe of actors, some of whom are deaf, who perform using a synthesis of spoken English and American sign language. Since its founding in 1967, the National Theater of the Deaf has used the facilities of the O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn.

headline: Simultaneous Translations
abstract: A lot was going on simultaneously when Robert J. Smithdas read his poetry at the New York Society for the Deaf on East 14th Street, where the Hebrew Association of the Deaf holds its weekly social.   The poet, blind and deaf from age 4, read softly from a Braille edition of ''Shared Beauty.''

headline: WHERE THE CHEERS ARE ONLY SEEN
abstract:
WHITE PLAINS WITH two outs and a runner on third, Janice Bryan knows she must not let another run score if her softball team from the New York School for the Deaf is to have a chance of winning. On her next pitch, the batter hits a hard line drive that seems destined for center field, but Miss Bryan picks the ball out of midair to end the inning.

On an adjacent field, a track meet is taking shape. A referee waves his arm and a runner begins his approach to the long jump; another runner is warming up for the hurdles and a group prepares for the pole vault.

The softball team falters in the fifth inning and goes down to defeat, 8-2. The track team of the School for the Deaf puts in a strong performance but finishes second among four teams. There are pats on the back, groans of discontent and hints of fatigue on the athletes' faces. There are no words of consolation.

headline: SIGNS TALK TO BLIND
abstract: The West 55th Street offices of the Jewish Guild for the Blind now have emergency-door exit signs that speak. The 29 signs, installed in the Guild's building last month, utter the words, ''Fire, this way out,'' in a synthesized but commanding voice, according to John Heimerdinger, executive director of the nonprofit organization.

headline: FOR DEAF CHILDREN, SPECIAL CLASSES IN SELF-DEFENSE
abstract: ''What is crime?'' Kerry O'Brien, a social worker with the Victim Services Agency, asked the students gathered for a special assembly at St. Joseph's School for the Deaf.   ''It's bad men doing bad things,'' said one boy. ''It's robbery,'' said another. ''It's rape,'' said a girl. ''Kidnapping,'' said a boy. ''Killing,'' said a girl.

headline:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Award to Philanthropist
abstract:
I n recognition of the millions he has given the World Health Organization's blindness prevention programs, Ryoichi Sasakawa, the flamboyant Japanese businessman, was scheduled to be given the Helen Keller International Award last night at the Pierre Hotel.

His other causes have included assisting the work of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon in the United States and the work of the United Nations, which reports he has given $38,831,182 since 1971.

headline: HARD OF HEARING
abstract: I woke up deaf in the right ear one morning, waited a few weeks for the problem to clear up and, when it didn't, went uptown to Manhattan's mink belt to see a doctor. There at Madison Avenue and 57th Street where coffee and toast can cost you $7.50, a panhandler struck on my deaf side.   At least he looked like a panhandler. I couldn't hear a word he was saying, but he had that familiar expression you see on panhandlers' faces when they're cold, stone sober, and I naturally figured he was saying, ''If only I had the subway fare to Wall Street, I could corner the market in rubies before lunchtime.''

headline: RIFT BESETS GUIDE DOG AGENCY
abstract: INFIGHTING has split the supervisory ranks of the Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind and threatens to destroy the Smithtown-based agency, the only provider of guide dogs in the metropolitan area.   For more than a year now, several board members and administrators of the foundation have been accusing one another of such alleged misdeeds as altering records, improper use of company cars, intimidating blind students, wasting money and failure to perform duties properly.   The dispute is now in State Supreme Court, where one faction seeks the dissolution of the foundation's 29-member board of directors and the other side counters that those seeking to disband the board should instead be removed from office.   By requesting a court-ordered dissolution of the board of directors, the petitioners may effectively put the organization out of business. Short of that, there is the possibility that unfavorable publicity generated by the lawsuits could cause donations - the lifeblood of the foundation - to dry up.

headline: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
abstract: Aid for the Sightless   T he Staten Island Hospital has set a pace for cornea donations that, if equaled by other hospitals, could wipe out the four-month waiting list at the New York Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration, at 210 East 64th Street.   In 1982 the eye bank received requests from 3,800 candidates for cornea transplants, but could supply only 1,079.

headline: GARDEN CREATED FOR DEAF-BLIND
abstract:
THREE years ago, Alvina Wiles suggested to her Sands Point Garden Club that it honor the 100th birthday anniversary of Helen Keller with a garden where, through the senses of touch and smell, deaf and blind people might enjoy and learn from plants with various textures and fragrances.

Last week the Helen Keller Sensory Garden, with specially chosen plants and shrubs, was dedicated at the Helen Keller National Center for Deaf-Blind Youths and Adults in Sands Point.

The garden consists of a series of connected walkways and patios.  The surfacing materials vary in texture and form from one area to another, so that the deaf and blind clients may learn their way about by sensing these differences. Paths of coarse-textured bricks connect patios or sitting areas surfaced with smooth concrete, pebbletextured patio blocks or bluestone slabs.

headline: Sports of The Times; Look of Eagles
abstract: JOE LAZARRO was telling about arriving at a local golf club near his home in Waltham, Mass., and, not having come with a group, asking the starter to fill him with any threesome. The group he was put with knew nothing about Joe, but they immediately noticed something odd.   Joe had come with another fellow who placed the ball on the tee for him, then, while Joe was holding the club, the other fellow fit the club head against the ball. Joe, without the golfer's customary waggle, took the club head back slowly and then came down, whacking the ball straight down the fairway.

headline: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
abstract: THE nursery-school table is covered with sheets of paper covered with brilliant color. The 3-year-olds dip sponges in the pans of paint and fervently dab on more.   ''Do you want blue, Karla?'' asks Ellyn Gadue.  ''Yes, blue, blue,'' says Karla Gilbride, with the decisive air of a tiny, blond Picasso.  Blue is an abstract concept to Karlla: She cannot see her painting, or Miss Gadue, the day camp counselor, or the five other children, three of whom cannot see her. The two others are legally blind, seeing dimly or in patches.   They all paint, with concentration and delight.  In another building the 11- and 12-year-old boys bang cheerfully on all the varied accouterments of a rhythm section. They are mischievous, conspiratorial, brash and shy by turns. They, too, are all blind or legally so.

headline: Defying the Odds
abstract: Some athletes compete to discover their limitations. Willie Brown plays basketball to defy them.  Brown, who is 18 years old, is a senior at the Georgia School for the Deaf in Cave Spring. He is expected to become the first deaf player to score more than 2,000 points in his high school career. He is also pursuing a near-impossible dream: He wants to play major college basketball and become a pro. No deaf person has ever done that. But there are a few people that think Willie Brown can.

headline: SCHOOL FOR THE DEAF MARKING CENTENNIAL
abstract:
WEST TRENTON ACENTURY ago, 68 deaf New Jersey children journeyed to Trenton by railroad and horsedrawn carriage and became the first class at what is still the state's only residential school for the deaf.

This week, many former students will come by airplane, as well as by automobile, train and bus, to attend the 100th anniversary convention of the school's Alumni Association. It will be held at the Hilton Inn in East Windsor Township Thursday and Friday and at the school on Saturday.

The New Jersey School for the Deaf, as it was known until 1965, was renamed the Marie H. Katzenbach School for the Deaf in honor of the late president of the State Board of Education. She took a special interest in the education of the handicapped.

headline: WARNING LIGHTS FLASH FOR EARPHONE USERS
abstract: Like other insidious ailments, hearing loss lies in wait for a long time and sneaks up slowly on its victims. Sometimes it takes years of traumatic exposure to high sound levels before any symptoms become manifest. Yet the vogue for portable sound equipment - such as Walkman-type radios and tape players - has already produced an alarming increase of clinically verified hearing damage, especially among rock addicts who like their music loud.   On the whole, the audio industry has reacted to what has become a public health problem in the same way the automobile industry reacts to traffic casualties. The trouble, the industry claims, lies not with the product but with its improper use. They point out that there are no ill effects if the volume is kept at reasonable levels - which is rather like saying that there won't be many traffic accidents as long as everyone drives cautiously.

headline: THEATER OF THE DEAF GETS A PICTURE-POSTCARD HOME
abstract: The National Theater of the Deaf opened its new home, the Hazel E.  Stark Center, in Chester, Conn., yesterday.
