Situated in a picturesque spot along the Pattaconk Brook, the Stark Center was established with a $250,000 gift from Irving Stark, a retired businessman from East Norwalk, Conn.   ''We finally have a home,'' David Hays, founder and artistic director of the theater, said. ''It is justterrific. It is just the right size. This town is so pretty; it's like the backlot of M-G-M.  The people here have welcomed us with open arms.''

headline: Blind Demonstrate For Subway Gates
abstract: About 50 people, most of them blind, began a 24-hour vigil yesterday in front of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority headquarters in Manhattan demanding that safety gates be installed on 1,200 subway cars.   In at least three incidents since last December blind people have fallen between the cars, the R-44 and R-46 models, which lack gates.

headline: Blind Sailor Sets Out From Coast to Hawaii
abstract: Hank Dekker has set sail for Hawaii, with a Braille compass, Braille charts and other equipment needed by a blind sailor.   Mr. Dekker, 41 years old, lost his sight because of glaucoma 11 years ago.

headline: IF PRESIDENT REAGAN WORE A HEARING AID
abstract: To the Editor:     An Aug. 23 news item tells us that President Reagan has admitted suffering a further hearing loss as a result of damage done years ago. This prompts me to suggest that the President do himself a favor and millions of Americans with hearing problems a great service, namely wear a hearing aid - which he probably needs, judging by his having to ask reporters to repeat questions at news conferences.

headline: REAGAN BEGINS TO WEAR A HEARING AID IN PUBLIC
abstract: President Reagan has begun wearing a custom-made, technologically advanced hearing aid in his right ear after experiencing increased difficulty hearing high-pitched sound.   Mr. Reagan, who is 72 years old, began wearing the device last week, according to the White House. He wore it today in public for the first time, at a meeting of business and education leaders on the subject of adult literacy.   The hearing aid is fitted into the ear canal and is barely visible.

headline: MAKERS OF HEARING AIDS SEE WIDER ACCEPTANCE
abstract: Hearing aids have never been something that people want to be seen wearing. But when President Reagan wore one in public for the first time Wednesday, the industry that makes the devices got a boost in its long battle for public acceptance.   In fact, only 12.4 percent of the nation's more than 20 million hearing- impaired people wear hearing aids, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. What the President now carries in his ear is the latest in technology built by Starkey Laboratories of Minneapolis, one of the leading makers of hearing aids in the United States.

headline: We Hear You, Mr. President
abstract: In a country that worships youth and fitness, age and its inconveniences are often treated like dirty little secrets. If people lie about their age, it is because they fear being perceived as over the hill. If they hide their infirmities, it is because they fear being perceived as less than whole. By wearing a hearing aid in public, President Reagan helps to relieve the pressure to do either.

headline: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Collection for the Blind
abstract: ''This,'' said John Ross, fingering a   delicate 19th-century French tortoise-shell fan, ''would be fun for someone who uses Braille.''    He was showing off the Metropolitan Museum's new collection for the blind, opening this month with such touches as labels in large type and Braille.

headline: PROGRAM AIDS THE HEARING IMPAIRED
abstract:
ABOUT 6 percent of Connecticut's population, some 180,000 people, is hearing impaired, state officials say. But West Hartford is the only school system in the state that provides academic programs for adults who are deaf or hearing-impaired.

 The classes, offered through the school system's Adult Education Program, can lead to a general education degree, which is equivalent to a high school diploma. There are also courses for self-enrichment, such as physical education and crafts.

headline: IT'S ABOUT TIME MEDICARE HEARD THE MESSAGE
abstract: To the Editor:   The Sept. 8 news story on President Reagan wearing a hearing aid in public concludes with Dr. John House saying that one out of three people over 60 have hearing problems. ''Maybe the President doing this will help others realize that they can ease their problems with a hearing aid.''

headline: UNDETERRED BY TWO HANDICAPS
abstract:
WHEN a friend cautioned Robert J. Smithdas, an educator, writer and poet from Port Washington, against wallpapering his kitchen because he might have difficulty matching patterns, Mr. Smithdas, like any self-respecting do-it-yourselfer, went right ahead and did it anyway. The job is perfect.

 ''All I did was pick a paper without a pattern,'' Mr. Smithdas said. ''The actual hanging was easy.''

Mr. Smithdas enjoys a challenge. He does not ''like being told I can't do something - especially without having tried it first.'' And because he has been blind and deaf since early childhood, when meningitis took his vision and hearing, his life has been filled with challenges.

headline: 'BORN' AT 19
abstract: In a legal sense, Joe McKinney didn't exist until he was 19 years old. Before then he was a nameless nomad who could neither hear nor speak.

headline: TechnologySteven J. Marcus Implant in Ear Aids the Deaf
abstract: AT Kolff Medical Inc. of Salt Lake City, they call it the Ineraid artificial ear. Biostim Inc. of Princeton, N.J., calls its device the Bioear. A joint venture of the House Ear Institute in Los Angeles and the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company currently dominates the field with its House-3M Cochlear Implant. And Nucleus Ltd., an Australian entry in the American market, offers a Multichannel Cochlear Implant.   The four companies, combining advances in medicine and microelectronics, are seeking to provide some hearing to people whose deafness is too profound to be helped by ordinary hearing aids.

headline: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
abstract: Opera for the Deaf    Operagoers at the New York City   Opera's recent performance of ''The Cunning Little Vixen'' were treated to an example of a new theatrical language - American Sign Language. A balletic, theatrical form of sign language, it was ''spoken'' by a pair of graceful interpreters whose animated performance often added insight for the hearing audience as well as benefiting the deaf and hearing-impaired.

headline: TOWN HELPS WOMAN GAIN HER EYESIGHT
abstract: Margie Brady had lived in the shadows since she was born without irises 30 years ago. But thanks to a gift from a generous town, ''everything is clear'' for Miss Brady today, she said.   ''It's like being born again,'' said Miss Brady, whose vision was corrected this week from legal blindness to near normal with a combination of lenses, prisms and shades that act as a telescope and eye protecter.

headline: Seales Is Legally Blind
abstract: Sugar Ray Seales, a former Olympic boxing champion and successful professional middleweight, is legally blind, with no vision in his left eye and only 10 percent vision in his   right eye, his ophthalmologist says.  ''Given the degree of Mr. Seales's blindness, I doubt that he can   ever be gainfully employed in any occupation requiring sight,'' said   Randolph Lindblad, the ophthalmologist.

headline: SEALES, NEARLY BLIND, STILL LOVES THE RING
abstract: The winner of a 1972 Olympic gold medal and a veteran of 452 amateur and professional fights, Sugar Ray Seales today is nearly blind.   Why did he keep fighting after major eye operations in 1980 and 1981? ''Hey, after my second operation, I was knocking guys out,'' Seales said. ''There were no problems at that point. I was getting paid, I had meat in the freezer, everything was just right.   ''I had 80 pro fights, but never fought for the world title. I know I'd have been a champion.''

headline: ELECTRONIC SYSTEM TO GUIDE THE BLIND MEETS SOME OPPOSITION
abstract: Blind students at the University of New Mexico have started testing a new electronic travel system that its inventors say could significantly improve the mobility of people with little or no eyesight.   But the undertaking is already evoking vigorous opposition from the New Mexico affiliate of the National Federation of the Blind. The group objects that the system is ''insulting to the blind'' because it seems to imply that they can function only with the help of complicated technological devices. The federation affiliate is asking the university to abandon the project.

headline: BABBLING OF BABIES IS STUDIED
abstract: The babble of babies, often dismissed as mere noisemaking, can provide clues to possible learning or hearing disorders, according to Michael Lewis, a professor of pediatrics at the Rutgers Medical School of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. He is studying such sounds to help teach parents and doctors how to detect potential problems.   The absence of any babble or of babble resembling the parents' native language can indicate hearing disabilities or physical handicaps in the mouth and throat, Professor Lewis said in an interview.

headline: ADJUSTMENTS Hearing in Court
abstract: Should Alec Naiman have been allowed to serve as a juror in the drug- selling trial of Hector Guzman? Mr. Naiman met all the traditional qualifications, but there was a problem: He can neither hear nor speak. For that reason, the defense attorney exercised his peremptory right to bar Mr. Naiman from the jury.

headline: LIVING WITH BLINDNESS AND CONQUERING ITS MYTHS
abstract:
-page headlines. When retirement gives way to a comeback, it's back to the headlines as it was when Sugar Ray Leonard announced his plans to return to boxing after a 13-month retirement due to an eye injury. As an avid sports fan, former high school athlete and a professional person who is blind, I have followed Leonard's plans with special interest and concern.

Leonard retired in October 1982, five months after undergoing surgery to correct a partly detached retina of the left eye. According to his ophthalmologist, Dr. Ronald Michels, Leonard's left eye has been restored to 20/ 20 vision. Now Leonard's return to the ring, scheduled for Saturday night, has been postponed because of surgery to his right eye, although he still says he will fight again.

headline: SURGEONS TO START IMPLANTING ELECTRONIC DEVICE TO AID DEAF
abstract: A tiny artificial ear designed to help 65 percent of the nation's deaf people will be implanted in 20 people within a year and the first operation will be performed in three to four weeks, according to a surgeon at the University of Utah.    Dr. James Parkin, acting chairman of the university Medical School's department of surgery, said at a news conference Wednesday that he had already chosen the first candidate for an implant of the device, Ineraid. The Food and Drug Administration approved the implants Tuesday.

headline: PREMATURE CHILDREN SHOW RISE IN A BAFFLING EYE DISORDER
abstract: DOCTORS in the United States and abroad are increasingly concerned about the incidence of a disorder in premature newborns that often leads to blindness.    The number of infants involved is not great compared with many other afflictions, but the tragedy is real and growing.   From relatively few cases a decade ago, the estimated number of infants legally blinded by the disorder, called RLF, for retrolental fibroplasia, has risen to more than 500 a year in this country.   An additional 1,500 children each year lose part of their eyesight to RLF. And the numbers may be higher, because doctors are not required to report the disorder to any data- gathering body.

headline: BLIND UROLOGIST DISCIPLINED FOR PERFORMING SURGERY
abstract: Six months after Dr. John R. Bongiovanni was blinded in an automobile accident in March 1980, he was back at his urology practice, making diagnoses, prescribing treatments and even performing minor surgery.   In performing the surgery, though, he violated three provisions of state law, the New York Board of Regents has ruled. The Regents, who have the final say in the licensing of physicians, imposed disciplinary restrictions upon the doctor, including the limiting of his license to practice.

headline: IMPLANT BRINGS SOUND TO DEAF AND SPURS DEBATE OVER ITS USE
abstract: WHEN the doctor addressed him by name, the patient quickly turned his head. Everyone was overjoyed, because the man had been totally deaf for more than a year. Now he had been brought back into the world of sound at least sufficiently to respond to the human voice, although he did not quite recognize the sound as ''Charles.''    This scene at Bellevue Hospital last week illustrates the hopes as well as the limitations of cochlear implants, electronic devices implanted surgically in the inner ear, to aid people whose hearing is profoundly impaired. The cochlea is a structure of the inner ear, shaped like a snail shell, where the vibrations of sound are translated into nerve impulses.   Although the field is still considered in its infancy, cochlear implants have become the focus of considerable enthusiasm - and controversy - in the medical community. Such implant operations are being done more widely today than ever before.

headline: Eye Doctor Sentenced
abstract: A judge has sentenced a doctor to four years in prison and fined him $70,000 for filing false insurance claims for needless eye operations in which he blinded patients. ''To tamper wrongfully with this precious gift for financial gain is just plainly unthinkable,'' Judge Henry Shatford of Superior Court said Tuesday in sentencing Dr. Jose Minaya, a Los Angeles ophthalmologist.

headline: HANDICAPPED DISCOVER MUSIC'S JOYS
abstract:
MELISSA MERCED of Bridgeport, blind since birth, looks forward to her weekly piano lesson. 

 ''It makes me feel real good about myself,'' the 13-year-old said. 

Cecily Miller, 25, of Rowayton, who has cerebral palsy and is legally blind, has been taking piano and singing lessons since 1982. 

''It's the highlight of her week,'' said her mother, Anne Rich. ''She plays piano with only one hand, but it gives her a purpose. And the socialization is important, too.''

headline: PERSONAL HEALTH
abstract: DR. DeWITT STETTEN JR.  was a leading scientist at the National Institutes of Health when a progressive disease of the retina rendered him legally blind. Even with corrective lenses, he could barely see at 20 feet what people with normal vision can see at 200 feet away. Although unable to read or drive, Dr. Stetten was not told about aids to improve the quality of his life by any of the seven ophthalmologists who treated him during 15 years of increasing visual loss.    Distressed by the apparent disinterest of ophthalmologists in blindness, Dr. Stetten wrote in The New England Journal of Medicine about his own discoveries of some of the hundreds of devices and programs that can improve the lives of blind people. His comments drew letters from hundreds of people with similar experiences.

headline: WHEN OFFERING HELP
abstract: REACTIONS to blind people vary   from avoidance to oversolici tousness to acting as if the person cannot hear or speak. Irving R. Dickman, author of the pamphlet ''Living With Blindness,'' offers these guidelines to help make you truly helpful to a person who cannot see:     * It is always proper to offer your help, but do not feel insulted if the blind person refuses your offer.     * Do not assume you know how to help; ask the person what you can do. But also do not hesitate to issue a warning of immediate danger, such as a overhanging obstacle that would be missed by the person's cane.

headline: BLACKS' HIGH GLAUCOMA RATE TOUCHES OFF A HEALTH ALERT
abstract: The American Academy of Ophthalmology has issued a health alert that glaucoma has become the leading cause of blindness in blacks, who are eight times as likely to suffer from the eye disease as whites.   An estimated two million Americans are afflicted with the disease, in which abnormally high pressure in the eyeball damages the optic nerve.

headline: Blind Swimmers Set World Marks
abstract: Trischa Zorn of Mission Viejo, Calif., and Barbara Eiler of Macomb, Ill., two blind swimmers, each broke a world record today while winning two gold medals each at the third International Games for the Disabled.   Miss Zorn, a sophomore at the University of Nebraska, where she was the first handicapped athlete to earn an athletic scholarship, captured the Class B2 (less than 1-3 normal vision) 100-meter freestyle in 1 minutes 10.14 seconds, bettering the previous standard of 1:12.31.

headline: Helen Keller Week Declared
abstract: President Reagan has declared next week ''Helen Keller Deaf-Blind Awareness Week,'' calling on the nation to help foster independence and job opportunities for people who are both deaf and blind. Next Wednesday will be the 104th anniversary of the birth of Miss Keller, who overcame blindness and deafness and became a model for others.

headline: JUDGE WHO IS BLIND RELYING ON 'WHAT'S INSIDE' FOR TRUTH
abstract: A blind judge who has worked eight years in the nation's busiest court system says he does not have to see his witnesses to be fair because ''it's what's inside that counts'' in determining truthfulness.   Associate Circuit Judge Nicholas T. Pomaro of Cook County was blinded in childhood by a rare disease. He presides over civil, felony, misdemeanor and traffic cases.

headline: Bank of Japan To Alter Notes
abstract: The Bank of Japan has announced that it will start circulating new bank notes Nov. 1 to make its money counterfeit-proof. A Bank of Japan official said Friday that the bank would use a special ink to thwart forgers who have adapted sophisticated printing and photocopying techniques in recent years.

headline: TRACK JOY SHARED WITH BLIND
abstract: Carl Simon remembers being a hot-shot high school track star who figured he knew everything there was to know about a 400-meter race. Blessed with a Herschel Walker-like body and the confidence of youth, he figured that ability could overcome whatever experience denied.   But there were some things he didn't know, and lessons that he had not yet learned.   Last summer, at the end of his junior year at Vashon High School in St. Louis, Simon was asked by one of the school's physical-education instructors to be a guide for blind runners. He accepted, and his life hasn't been the same since.

headline: How to Prevent Chain Snatchings
abstract: For a moment, James McHugh held    the subway door open with his foot. He reached in where Elaine White was standing and snatched the gold chain from her neck.

headline: NEW RULES ON PHONE CUTOFFS
abstract: TELEPHONE companies will be    subject to new rules and their   customers will gain new rights on Sept. 10, when regulations adopted by the New York State Public Service Commission take effect.   The rules, which will be formally announced Monday, are modeled after guidelines already in effect for gas and electric customers and will apply to all calls within New York State, regardless of the carrier. They will make it more difficult for a phone company to disconnect service, particularly for the sick, elderly, blind and disabled, and will require companies to offer deferred payment arrangements and to clarify customer bills.   A copy of the rules can be obtained from the Consumer Service Division, New York State Public Service Commission, 3 Empire State Plaza, Albany, N.Y. 12223.

headline: DEWHURST ADAPTS TO LANGUAGE OF DEAF THEATER
abstract: On a hot summer afternoon in a converted old mill above a Connecticut brook, a group of actors is gathered in a room that is strangely still. The makeshift stage is full of characters in motion, but only one voice is speaking, that of a curly haired young man watching the others from a corner. Otherwise there is silence, save for the noisy splashing of the brook and the droning of a fly.    Following the action intently is Colleen Dewhurst, the actress. At the moment, her role is that of director, and when the actors have run through their scenes, they will gather around for her to give them notes on their work. However, in this case her comments will be delivered in sign language by the interpreter sitting at her side.   For the actors working with Miss Dewhurst are deaf; they have been acting out their parts in sign language. The actual words of the text are spoken aloud by the curly haired young man and another hearing performer, a young woman.

headline: HEARING-AID SYSTEM PLEASING THEATERGOERS
abstract: For years, the hard of hearing could sometimes be heard speaking out loud in theaters, asking their companions to repeat what was said on stage. Through the Infrared Listening System, installed over the last five years in 24 theaters and concert halls in New York City, those with hearing disabilities can tune in to every word as it is spoken.    In fact, they can hear so clearly in theaters that are equipped with the sound system that occasionally their companions - with no hearing impairment - have been overheard asking    them    what was said on stage. As one serendipitous result, the lightweight headsets are sometimes rented by those with normal hearing. They use them to compensate for a theater's acoustical problems or for a linguistic difficulty presented by an individual play or actor.

headline: LIFELINE FOR THE BLIND
abstract: To the Editor:      The Sept. 6 ''Critic's Notebook'' by Christopher Lehmann-Haupt, about the Library for the Blind and Physically Handicapped and about Recordings for the Blind, Inc., distressed and saddened me.   As a young writer who depends on both services, I admit that every title is not always available, as Lillian Hellman complained, and that the reading and recording quality is sometimes flawed, as Ved Mehta noted.

headline: Unwanted Help
abstract: When the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque began testing an electronic guidance system for the blind late last year, the state's biggest organization representing the blind objected. The group, the New Mexico affiliate of the National Federation of the Blind, said the system would do more harm than good by discouraging the blind from developing their own senses to get around.

headline: COLLEGE IN QUEENS TEACHES THE DEAF
abstract: The other day, Claudia Gregory received an award from her teachers at La Guardia Community College. They told her she was a very special student who answered voices that told her she had a very special song to sing.     Miss Gregory smiled and ran her right hand up her left arm in small, choppy stops. ''I have upgraded myself,'' she said, voicing the words she had expressed with her hands.

headline: Rosh ha-Shanah Services For the Deaf
abstract: The sound of the shofar will be communicated to the deaf at Rosh ha- Shanah services today.

headline: Disabled Woman's Abortion Postponed by Chief Justice
abstract: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger issued a temporary postponement today of an abortion planned for a retarded, deaf and blind woman who was apparently sexually assaulted in a Maryland state institution.   A lower court had authorized the abortion for the woman, Wendy Marie Baker, 19 years old, at the request of her guardian.

headline: Sun May Have Figured In Carolina Midair Crash
abstract: The setting sun may have blinded one of the pilots, leading to a midair crash of two light airplanes that rained debris over a playground crowded with young football players, officials said today.    No one was hurt by the flying wreckage in the crash Thursday.

headline: Ho, Ho, Hoe
abstract: The Wonder Special Events   Company has trained people to   be Santa Clauses in the Washington area for several years.

headline: BLIND PASSENGER ON PLANE CITED IN SEAT DISPUTE
abstract: A blind woman arrested after refusing to leave her seat near an airplane emergency exit pleaded not guilty today to a disorderly conduct charge, saying airline policies restricting seating for the disabled were discriminatory.   ''All we want to do is be able to travel like other passengers,'' said Judy Sanders, 37 years old, of Minneapolis. ''We're not asking to fly the plane. We just want the responsibility to do what we know we can handle, and that is most things in life.''

headline: Caution on Vitamin E For Premature Is Urged
abstract: Giving high doses of vitamin E to premature infants to prevent eye disease and blindness is ineffective and could be dangerous, two new studies have found.   High doses of vitamin E increased the risk of infection, intestinal disease and hemorrhaging, according to the two studies reported Monday at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Ophthalmology.

headline: ISRAELI DANCERS WITH A DIFFERENCE
abstract: ''For me, it's not a matter of the deaf and the hearing, but the meeting of two worlds, Moshe Efrati says, talking of the Kol Demama Dance Company, the Israeli troupe of deaf and hearing modern dancers that opens on Tuesday at City Center. ''We are two peoples living on the same planet but with different stimulations.''    Mr. Efrati, a dancer-choreographer with Israel's Batsheva Dance Company from 1963 to 1971, began to work with deaf dancers in 1967. ''I worked for five or six years with silence, and then I needed sound,'' he says. Having formed the Demama Company of deaf dancers, he started working with the hearing, integrated the two groups in 1975, and in 1978 formalized that integration by founding the Kol Demama Dance Company.

headline: GIVING AID WHEN TIMES TURN HARD
abstract: At the bank on 13th Avenue in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, people pass and ask, ''Where is Mr. W?'' or, ''Have you heard how Mr. W is doing?''     Customers write to his wife, they send get-well cards and ask how he is feeling. Mrs. W writes back, thanking them for their interest and reporting on her husband's progress. She never lets on about the pain and problems they have faced since May, when Mr. W was taken to the hospital from the bank, where he worked as a security guard, and was diagnosed as having glaucoma.    ''He's such a proud man,'' said Mrs. W. ''He never told me his eyes were getting worse.''

headline: APARTMENT HOUSE FOR THE BLIND, OCCUPIED 4 YEARS, STILL UNFINISHED
abstract: Four years after the opening of a model, federally financed apartment building for 200 blind and handicapped tenants in Manhattan, some areas of the lobby floor are still under construction, the much-advertised library for the blind and bowling alley have yet to open and relations between the landlord and the tenants are barely civil.   For months, the auditorium in the 12-story building, Selis Manor, at 135 West 23d Street in the Chelsea section, had a sign saying: ''Danger. Under Construction.'' Tenants were told that the room was unsafe for them to use.    What they say irritates them, however, is that while the room has been closed to them, it was opened for voter registration and for the landlord's St. Patrick's Day and Valentine's Day parties.

headline: DISABLED TO HELP STATUE OF LIBERTY
abstract:
A veterans group has promised to donate $1 million to help make the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island more accessible to the disabled. 

The pledge, from the Disabled American Veterans, a lobbying and service group based in Washington, will go toward a $2.5 million plan to remove barriers and create programs for the blind, deaf and immobile at the sites.

The plans include installing new elevators in statue's base, a copy of the statue for the blind to feel its shape, subtitles on audio-visual shows and live television cameras so wheelchair- bound visitors can see the view from the statue's crown.

headline: SANTA, IN GESTURES, DELIVERS THE MESSAGE OF CHRISTMAS
abstract:
ELIZABETH RIGNEY is 7 years old and unlike many children her age, she had never been to see Santa Claus. Elizabeth, a Guilford resident, is hearing impaired, and has never heard that question familiar to so many children: ''And what do you want Santa to bring you for Chistmas?''

 Last week, she not only went to see Santa, but she also was able to communicate with him. This was a Santa who talked to her by signing, the hand-signal language of the deaf and hearing impaired.

headline: A SANTA FOR DEAF YOUNGSTERS
abstract: A college student who said he learned sign language to cheat in high school is now putting his skills to good use: communicating with deaf children as a Santa Claus at a shopping mall.   David Shaffer, a student at Sinclair Community College in Dayton, has been spending about 12 hours each Saturday playing Santa for both the hearing and the hearing-impaired.    ''For many of the kids it's the first time the Santa visit is enjoyable instead of intimidating,'' said Paul J. Schiffer, advertising marketing manager of the Salem Mall. The mall, a 110-store shopping center in suburban northwest Dayton, began the program for the hearing-impaired this year. Mr. Schiffer estimated that of the 8,000 children who have thus far visited Santa Claus at the mall, about 250 of them have been hearing- impaired.

headline: BRAILLE MUSIC SURVEYED
abstract: John Henry, a blind, 39-year-old American harpsichordist, has devoted the last four years to compiling the first international survey of Braille music. For many years, he said, he felt the need for such a survey, which he describes as a practical reference work, not a comprehensive catalogue.    Mr. Henry says he considers the survey, ''Braille Music: An International Survey,'' a direction finder, a Braille Geiger counter or Braille guide dog. He emphasizes that it is not meant to advise the reader where to go, but rather, ''if you point it in the right direction, it will get you there quickly.''

headline: Postal Service's Phone Line Takes Comments From Deaf
abstract: Deaf people who have access to special message machines may now telephone the Postal Service with inquiries or complaints.

headline: Technology;   Phone Device For the Deaf
abstract: IN what could be an important development for   the nation's 2 million deaf people and 14 million   others who are hard of hearing, a scientist at the General Electric Company has invented a device that enables a hearing-impaired person to use the telephone.   The device cannot teach these people to speak - often a problem for deaf people who have never heard themselves. And, unlike an artificial ear recently approved by the Food and Drug Administration, the device does not try to give a handicapped person a sense of hearing.    What the mechanism does, rather, is to convert tones generated by a Touch-Tone telephone to letters that a hearing-impaired person can see.

headline: Refusing Blind Riders Costs Cabby License
abstract: A taxi driver who refused to give a ride to a blind couple and their guide dogs has lost the right to operate his cab.   The driver, John Brandi, permanently lost his permit to drive his cab by order of the Police Department, although he has a restricted permit that allows him to lease it to other drivers.

headline: TELEPHONE FOR THE DEAF USES TELEVISION IMAGES
abstract: Prof. Morton Nadler of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University hopes to succeed with the telephone where Alexander Graham Bell failed - by creating a means of communication for the deaf.   Professor Nadler is building a telephone that allows the deaf to communicate using sign language. Television images of the speaker are to be transmitted through telephone lines and displayed on a screen at the receiving end. The device would have cameras and screens at both ends for two-way communication.

headline: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   A Display of Gratitude
abstract: The jammed hallway at La Guardia   Community College was filled with a tangle of sounds yesterday morning - the shrieks of impatient children, the hum of curious students, the measured confidence of one older woman remarking to another: ''We may be looking at the next President of the United States, you know.'' They were waiting for a special guest - Governor Cuomo.

headline: A Princely Performance
abstract: ''I felt the vibrations,'' said 20-year-   old Christopher Buckland, looking very happy indeed, as his teacher interpreted rock lyrics in sign language.

headline: Reagan Begins Using A Second Hearing Aid
abstract: President Reagan, who has worn a hearing aid in his right ear for the last 18 months, has begun using a similar device in his left ear ''to achieve balance,'' Dr. T. Burton Smith, the White House physician, said today.   The second hearing aid first became evident at a White House state dinner Tuesday night for President Raul Alfonsin of Argentina.

headline: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
abstract: A MAJOR effort is under way in New Jersey to develop signs to help the Jewish hard of hearing and deaf understand the Hebrew language. More than 5,000 people are expected to take advantage of the new program.    The universal sign language now being used was invented in Paris in the 17th century by Abbe de L'Epee, but it has never been converted to foreign letters. Now, the Jewish Deaf and Hearing Impaired Council, a nonprofit organization, is attempting to make Jewish cultural, educational and religious events accessible to the deaf.      Toby Marx of Cranford, an interpreter for the deaf at Temple Emanu-El in Westfield, said that the principal problem was developing signs for general religious words, such as temple and rabbi. For example, Bible is signed as Jesus's Book, she said, making it necessary to develop a new sign for Jews.

headline: CASE OF MINISTRY STUDENT IS ACCEPTED
abstract: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state can constitutionally refuse to provide state funds to assist a student in becoming a minister.    The case is an appeal by a blind college student in the state of Washington, which provides vocational assistance funds under a state-Federal program to help handicapped students further their education.   The Washington State Supreme Court upheld the refusal of the state's Commission for the Blind to grant the student's request for money to study for the ministry at the Inland Empire School of the Bible. The court ruled that use of the vocational program for that purpose would impermissibly involve the state in advancing religion.

headline: A LESSON FOR FUTURE TAXPAYERS
abstract: SANDWICHED between classes in English and American history, Barry Wages is learning how to fill out his income tax return. This year his father helped him with the forms, but next year he plans to do it himself.    ''I thought that filling out taxes would be very difficult, but now that I've learned how to do it, I find it's not so hard,'' said Mr. Wages, an 18-year- old from Bloomfield who is a senior at the American School for the Deaf in West Hartford.    Mr. Wages was required to file an income tax return this year because he worked after school in a grocery store and also at a print shop. A classmate, Michael Fiorino,a 20-year-old from Hartford, said that by next year he planned to be working and filing his own tax return, as well.

headline: Advertising;   Campaign Set to Aid Disabled
abstract: LAST year Delano W. Ladd Jr.,   chairman and president of the   Edwin Bird Wilson agency, which specializes in advertising for financial institutions, decided that since the company was just short of 70 years old it might be nice if it volunteered to do its first Advertising Council campaign.    The assignment it got was for the National Organization on Disability. And it was turned over to John H. Lambert, senior vice president and creative director.

headline: THE MATCHMAKER OF SEEING EYE DOGS AND MASTERS
abstract: Richard Krokus is a compassionate man with an inexhaustible well of patience. Thus, it is somewhat of a surprise to hear him wisecrack, ''Doctors who go blind often continue to practice, although, of course, they don't do surgery.''   Richard Krokus is a clever man. He uses humor like a crude club to bludgeon the sighted free of misconceptions. Blindness, he says without equivocation, ''is more of a nuisance than anything else.''

headline: BLIND SKATER AIMS FOR THE TOP
abstract:
TO Ann Wasserman of Long Branch, ice skating and skiing have long been two of life's greatest pleasures.

And now Miss Wasserman, who was born legally blind, is training for what is believed will be the world's first competitive speed-skating event for the blind and visually impaired.

The event will take place at the 1986 Winter Sports Championships of the United States Association for Blind Athletes, tentatively scheduled for Vail, Colo. The dates are to be announced soon.

headline: BLIND TREASURER IS ISSUE IN MT. KISCO
abstract: THE request by Mount Kisco's treasurer, Carmen E. DeFrancesco, who is blind, to relinquish his duties as receiver of taxes has prompted a Village Trustee to call for his resignation. But the Mayor and the three other trustees have expressed their ''full confidence'' in Mr. DeFrancesco, who oversees investments of $14 million a year and a payroll for 90 employees.   ''The person signing the checks should be able to see them,'' Trustee Sarah Wuchinich said in a recent interview, adding that the treasurer ''has a support system and the taxpayers are paying for it.'' She called for Mr. DeFrancesco's resignation and suggested that he could serve as a consultant.   Mr. DeFrancesco has been village treasurer and receiver of taxes for 14 years. The post is filled by appointment by the Village Board, which is composed of the Mayor and the four Village Trustees. Mr. DeFrancesco lost his sight seven years ago as a result of diabetes.

headline: GIVING DEAF ACTORS A SPOT IN FOOTLIGHTS
abstract: AN unusual summer school in Connecticut not only offers intensive theater training to deaf actors, directors and playwrights, but also helps bring their skill and style to hearing audiences around the world.   The school is the Professional School for Deaf Theater Personnel at the National Theater of the Deaf in Chester. On a recent day, its director, Andrew Vasnick, was looking over the students, faculty and staff members, interpreters and visitors having lunch.   ''The most important thing about the school is this: where else in the world could you get all these people together in one place?'' said Mr. Vasnick, a 59-year-old teacher and actor who is deaf.

headline: House Cuts Off Fund For Playboy in Braille
abstract: The House of Representatives says it will no longer pay for Braille editions of Playboy magazine stocked at the Library of Congress.

headline: The Bland for the Blind
abstract: Tough luck, blind folks. For you there will be no more Playboy magazines in Braille from the Library of Congress.   Congressman Chalmers P. Wylie has caught you. And put a stop to it.  With the consent and approval of the entire House of Representatives of the United States.

headline: Explaining Blindness
abstract: Ten actors - five blind and five sighted - rehearsed in a small, sparsely equipped West Side studio. They were preparing for ''On Sight,'' a Theater by the Blind production that is to open tonight at the Douglas Fairbanks Studio, 432 West 42d Street.

headline: Remarkable Skaters
abstract: A very special group will be in the audience at the matinee performance today by the John Curry Skaters in the Kennedy Center Opera House: a dozen children from the Tyler School for the Visually Impaired, fresh from the ice themselves. Under arrangements made by the National Committee, Arts with the Handicapped, the young people will come to the theater in midmorning, be fitted with skates and given instruction by the Curry troupe on the rink on stage. Then they will have a box lunch in the theater's green room before going to the matinee.

headline: DIET DEFICIENCY OF VITAMIN A IS REVEALED AS A MAJOR KILLER
abstract: DIETARY deficiencies of vitamin A, long implicated as a cause of blindness, have now been linked to hundreds of thousands of deaths of children each year in Africa, Asia and Latin America.   New findings, described by one expert as ''electrifying'' in their implications, are galvanizing international efforts to combat the deficiency. The studies indicate that the vitamin deficit, which is widespread in the third world and a major cause of blindness there, is also responsible for significant increases in measles, diarrhea and other potentially deadly diseases among tens of millions of children.   International health officials are developing a plan they hope will eliminate the deficiency worldwide and, in the process, reduce childhood deaths. Experts said the findings had already rejuvenated flagging vitamin therapy programs in Bangladesh and other Asian countries.

headline: LIBRARY USES ITS OWN STUDIO TO ADD MORE BOOKS FOR BLIND
abstract: The New York Public Library has installed a new recording booth to increase its selection of books for blind and other handicapped patrons in the New York area.   Volunteers at the library's two-year-old audio-book studio, in an office above the 58th Street branch library, have already produced 15 titles for the collection of tapes and disks, according to the director of the studio, Winifred Messe.   Fifteen more tapes are in production. They are part of about 34,000 titles in the library's collection, most of which are produced by the Library of Congress.

headline: PERSONAL HEALTH
abstract: IF a tree falls in the forest and no one is around to hear it, does it make any noise? The answer to this perennial puzzle is yes. Sound is generated when molecules of air are displaced, setting up a gradually widening series of ripples that resembles a wedge cut from the ripples on a lake after a fish jumps.   But while sound does not depend upon someone hearing it, people depend on hearing sound as an aid to survival: the honk of a horn, the ring a telephone or doorbell, the buzz of an alarm, not to mention the voices of other people, both live and electronically transmitted.   Thanks to modern technology, most of the nation's 17 million hearing-impaired individuals can now be helped to hear better through a variety of sophisticated devices, ranging from hearing aids custom-designed to the person's particular hearing problem to a still-experimental implant that can take over for the damaged cells that cause most cases of so-called nerve deafness.   And for those who cannot conduct conversations by telephone, special typewriters and minicomputers are now available that can transcribe phone messages both to and from the hearing-impaired.

headline: Police in Wyoming Seek Clues to a Boy's Identity
abstract: The police searched today for clues to the identity of a teen-ager who can neither hear nor speak and who arrived at a bus station here with no identification. The youth carried a five-page letter apparently written by his mother urging him to seek a better life.

headline: AROUND THE NATION;Mystery Youth Is Man With a Past, Police Say
abstract: A young man who had arrived at a bus station with a note signed ''Mommy,'' indicating he had been abandoned, and who convinced experts he could neither speak nor hear has been identified as a convict, the police said today.         He was identified through fingerprints as Gordon Vanderberg, a 22-year-old man with a criminal record in New York and New Jersey, said Lieut. Jim Barker. The man who arrived here Saturday carried a letter saying he had lost his hearing as a baby. He was thought to be 17 and was sent to stay with a foster family in Cheyenne.

headline: THE VISUALLY IMPAIRED WILL GET MORE TO READ
abstract: MANY of America's 11 million visually impaired people, who are incapable of reading the print of the typical hardcover or paperback book, have had few alternatives to giving up reading altogether. The growing number of books on tape has helped somewhat, but until recently, few bookstores have carried large-print books; libraries that do carry them usually have a limited selection, and none of the 140 or more adult book clubs, which cater to everyone from nurses to chemical engineers to organic gardeners, have catered to people with poor eyesight.   But help is finally on the way. Doubleday recently started a Large Print Home Library, offering the visually disabled a broad range of hardcover novels, mysteries, romances and how-to titles. And a number of others in the book industry are moving to cater to the small but growing large-print segment of the market:    * Waldenbooks recently agreed to stock in 350 of its stores the large-print books from G. K. Hall, the Boston company that has been a pioneer publisher of such books.

headline: Hearing Problems
abstract: TO THE LIVING SECTION:   I wish to respond to the letter of Raymond G. Kuntz, which appeared Sept. 4. It referred to the Amy Rowley case and was a response to the story ''Faces Behind Famous Cases'' on June 19. Mr. Kuntz described Amy Rowley's hearing in a way that is clearly confusing to an uneducated person and I think misrepresents the situation.

headline: Jurors Acquit a Blind Couple In Dispute Over Airline Seats
abstract: A blind couple have been acquitted of misdemeanor charges for refusing to move from airline seats near an emergency exit.

headline: BLIND READERS FILE LAWSUIT OVER U.S. BAN ON BRAILLE PLAYBOY
abstract: A group of blind readers, complaining of what they called ''blatant, paternalistic censorship,'' filed a lawsuit today in Federal District Court here seeking to overturn a Congressional ban on publishing a Braille edition of Playboy magazine at the Government's expense.   The target of the suit is an amendment approved by the House on a 216-to-193 roll-call vote last July 18 intended to halt the Library of Congress' publication of Braille editions of Playboy, one of 36 magazines distributed in Braille under its 54-year-old National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped.   Representative Chalmers P. Wylie, an Ohio Republican who sponsored the amendment, complained in the floor debate of ''talk about wanton idleness, of wanton and illicit sex and so forth'' in Playboy articles.

headline: 'LOVE IS NEVER SILENT,' ON DEAFNESS IN A FAMILY
abstract: WE have come to expect certain values in a ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' production: fine actors, lavish sets with scrupulous attention to detail, and what must be called, until a better phrase comes along, family entertainment. We get all this in ''Love Is Never Silent'' on NBC at 9 P.M. tonight.   To be sure, ''family entertainment'' has a slightly pejorative connotation. We think of sentiment and uplift. Actually, there's nothing wrong with either of these qualities, and they're present in the production tonight. The sentiment, however, isn't saccharine, and the uplift isn't cloying. ''Love is Never Silent'' is tough-minded.

headline: THEATER GROUP ADDRESSES THE DEAF
abstract: MARK TWAIN'S Captain Stormfield, and tales of some wriggling crabs and a man who turns outer space green are being performed this month in Connecticut -and in India and Nepal, too.   Portraying these and assorted other characters are members of the Chester-based National Theatre of the Deaf, who have split for most of December into two troupes to perform for young audiences. While one group travels through India and Nepal, the other is visiting schools in Connecticut.   For 18 years, the company, most of whose members (are deaf, have toured the United States and other countries with performances that blend sign language, body movement and the spoken word.

headline: Instant Announcer
abstract: Because he liked basketball, and because he also liked Rhonda Woodruff, who played guard for the women's team at Walters State Community College in Morristown, Tenn., Darren Allen used to hang around the gym while the Lady Senators practiced.   During one such drill last year, Allen, then a Walters State freshman, suddenly began calling out the players' names at random, replete with the crispness he had heard coming over so many public-address systems at so many arenas. ''He sounded good,'' recalls Coach Dave Kragel, ''and we needed an announcer.'' After practice, Kragel asked Miss Woodruff if she thought Allen would mind filling the job. They weren't sure what his answer would be, because Darren Allen is blind.

headline: Art of Sign Language
abstract: Sign language is usually thought of as the means of communication for the deaf.

headline: CLOSED-CAPTIONING FOR BOSTON NEWS
abstract: Two Boston television stations will begin offering closed-captioning for hearing-impaired people on their local evening news programs next year, becoming the first stations in the country to offer the service for such programs, the stations said.   Starting in March, WCVB-TV and WGBH-TV will offer live closed-captioning - data included in television broadcast signals that can be translated by a special decoder into words at the bottom of the television screen.   WCVB-TV, an ABC affiliate, will follow the lead of its network, which has included closed-captioning on its network news and much of its prime-time programming for several years.

headline: NEW JERSEYANS
abstract:
THE road to Mark S. Hurvitz's career as a rabbi to the Jewish deaf began with the sounds of music.

Rabbi Hurvitz, a 40-year-old Teaneck resident, grew up in a secular (cultural) Jewish family in Los Angeles. His interest in playing the recorder led him to a music education at California State University in Los Angeles.

''I became involved in composition that enabled groups of people to experience music communally,'' the clergyman recalled.

headline: 'COSBY' CAPTIONING SPARKS DISPUTE
abstract: ''The Cosby Show,'' the highest-rated show on television, brings NBC an estimated $1.5 million every week in advertising revenues and holds the promise of record earnings for the show's producers when it is sold into syndication.   But NBC and the ''Cosby'' producers are engaged in a dispute over who should pay the weekly tab -$1,250 - for captioning the hit series for deaf viewers.   ''It's a very small amount of money,'' said Annette Posell, manager of marketing for the Caption Center, a Boston-based agency that produces captions for television shows and commercials. ''But as everybody says, 'Somebody else should pay for it, it's not in my budget.' ''

headline: Braille Banking Machine
abstract: Some of the most mundane conveniences - street signs, banking machines, building directories, elevators and menus - have become standard fixtures of modern life. But not for the blind, who, for the most part, are not served by them.   Margarine G. Beaman, who had never met a blind person until a few years ago, began thinking about this inequity after eavesdropping while a man was describing how he had learned Braille after having been blinded.

headline: Jockey Fights Vision Ruling
abstract: When he was 8 years old, Charles Fletcher caught a dart in his right eye and permanently lost vision in it. But he's long since grown used to that handicap, which wasn't an issue when Fletcher, now 19, set out last summer to become an apprentice jockey. Having been granted a license by the State of Ohio, he rode in some 25 races at River Downs in Cincinnati.

headline:
PATENTS;
Audible Sound Identifies $1 to $20 Bills for Blind
abstract: An audible security validator for use by the blind was patented this week. It identifies bills from $1 to $20 and reports the amount by recorded sound.

headline: Lighthouse Benefit
abstract: The soprano Linda Skroski and the pianist Valerie Capers, who are both blind, will be the featured artists in a concert Sunday to benefit the Lighthouse Professional Musicians' Fund, an annual event sponsored by the Lighthouse Music School to showcase the work of established blind musicians and to raise funds to support performance opportunities for other professional and aspiring blind musicians.

headline: HIGH COURT REVERSES RULING ON RELIGIOUS STUDIES
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the First Amendment does not necessarily bar use of state vocational rehabilitation money to finance religious studies by a partly blind student at a Christian college.   The Court reversed a Washington Supreme Court ruling that it would be an unconstitutional ''establishment of religion'' for the state to grant the request of Larry Witters of Spokane for vocational rehabilitation assistance.   But it rested today's ruling on such narrow grounds that it neither guarantees that Mr. Witters will ultimately win the money nor clarifies substantially the confused state of constitutional law as to various forms of government aid to religious education. Four Opinions Written    Underlining the Court's continuing fragmentation over this politically charged issue, four of the nine Justices wrote opinions, each giving somewhat different reasons for reaching the same result.

headline: DEAF COUNCILMAN'S BUSY ROLE IN A HEARING WORLD
abstract: Kevin J. Nolan is unabashed about comparing himself with Ronald Reagan. ''We have four things in common,'' he says. ''We are both fans of Calvin Coolidge, we both enjoy jelly beans, we both were actors, and we are both hearing-impaired.''   Mr. Nolan, who was born deaf, understates his condition to make a point: He is handling his new political office without much difficulty. After a campaign against William C. Ames, a Republican who had been on the Northampton City Council for 20 years, Mr. Nolan, a Democrat, was elected to the City Council Nov. 5.

headline: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
abstract: TWENTY-eight years ago, a Short Hills woman with a severe congenital hearing loss underwent what was then radically new middle-ear surgery called a stapedectomy. The operation was a success, and a world of sound suddenly opened for her.   Overjoyed, the woman, Collette Ramsey, took out her checkbook and looked for a charity that could benefit from her gratitude, but could not find one. However, she was not easily discouraged; if there was no such organization, she would form one.   Thus was the Deafness Research Foundation born in midtown Manhattan, and with it a Short Hills connection involving successful business executives that continues to this day.

headline: DOG DOES THE LISTENING FOR DEAF OWNER
abstract: AS the telephone rang, a light above it flickered on and off. That was Radar's cue. But instead of swinging into action, the mini-Pinscher jerked his head in confusion as he stood among a group of people in Judy Williams's living room in Bridgeport.

headline: FROM THEOLOGICAL MALPRACTICE TO WRESTLING ON '20/20'
abstract: WHAT makes a successful magazine show? Diversity, for one thing; a little of this, a little of that, and a balanced texture of sincerity, worry and charm. One story may leave a viewer cold, but another story is coming up soon. ABC's ''20/20'' is a successful magazine show. Consider the program on Channel 7 at 10 tonight.

headline:
PATENTS;
SENSOR ON ARM AIDS LIP-READING BY DEAF
abstract: A device to be worn on the arm can provide a profoundly deaf person with tactile sensations that represent voice pitch and intonation patterns.

headline: THEATER OF DEAF TO TOUR CHINA
abstract: NEXT month the National Theater of the Deaf, based in Chester, will become the first theater company from the United States to tour China since cultural relations between the two countries were resumed in the 1970's. Aided by two Chinese performers, the troupe will introduce Chinese audiences to its unusual performance style.   ''We're the first American company to go, and we'll bring a kind of theater developed here,'' said David Hays, founder and artistic director of the theater group.   The National Theater of the Deaf, which now has eight deaf members and two hearing ones, has toured the United States and abroad for nearly 20 years with productions that blend sign language with the spoken word, which is provided by the hearing actors. Audiences are comprised mainly of hearing people who both hear and see every word.

headline: HELPING CHILDREN TO COMBAT DEAFNESS
abstract: A year ago, 2-year-old Adrienne Thal was diagnosed as having profound loss of hearing.   Since then, two mornings a week, still wearing pajamas and carrying her breakfast cereal, the little girl has been bundled into an automobile for a two-hour drive from her grandmother's home in southern New Jersey to the League for the Hard of Hearing in Manhattan.   At the league, she spends hours in speech therapy sessions, learning simple words like mommy, daddy, baby, nose and hand. She wears a lightweight hearing device that amplifies the therapist's voice. The goal is to prepare her to enter a nursery school for normal children, a goal not all handicapped children can achieve.

headline: Advertising; TV Spot For Deaf Viewers
abstract: APPARENTLY aware of the notion that good deeds are best measured by the amount of publicity they amass, the McDonald's Corporation is promoting a TV commercial for the deaf and starring the deaf. It will begin to air on network television tomorrow.   Roy T. Bergold, vice president, advertising, in the company of Beth Ann Bull, one of the spot's stars, and several other interested parties showed up for a screening at Carl Byoir & Associates, the public relations firm, Monday morning.   The 30-second commercial itself is about an engaging couple of college students who, at the urging of the young man and despite the fact that it is exam week, decide to go to McDonald's and get some takeout for a picnic on the beach. The dialogue is conducted in sign language against a background of a fairly muted musical score.

headline: TEEN-AGE PITCHER STRIKES OUT ANGER
abstract:
IN a sense, the pitcher's mound has become the main vehicle in Buffy Spezzano's pursuit of life.

On it, Miss Spezzano, the 18-year-old starting pitcher for the Andrew Ward High School softball team in Fairfield, has achieved a level of consistency and excellence that has left her with few peers.

After 17 games, Miss Spezzano, a junior, had a record of 12 victories and 5 losses. She has pitched every inning of every game and has also pitched a no-hitter and two one-hitters. She is one of the reasons the school clinched the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference eastern divison title, after being picked to finish anywhere from second to fourth in most preseason polls.

headline: After 6 Years, Deaf Juror Takes Her Place
abstract: Mary Beth Miller tried to suppress a smile as she made her way to the jury box in a robbery trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan last week. She did not want the judge to think that she was not serious about her civic responsibilities.

headline: Too Much Sun Can Cause Night Blindness
abstract: To the Editor:   It's now universally recognized that overexposure to the sun's ultraviolet rays could conceivably trigger the formation of cataracts (''Consumer Saturday,'' May 10, and ''In Sunglasses, Darkness Is Not Enough,'' letter, May 26). Overexposure produces another - but less obvious - danger, a form of temporary night blindness called ''transitory nyctalopia.''

headline: DEAF IN MAINSTREAM
abstract: Deaf and hearing-impaired students will be an integral part of one nearby college community next fall, a goal difficult if not impossible to attain in the past.   Several deaf students at Lehman College in the Bronx will have a better chance than others at reaching that goal in public colleges in the New York City area, according to Deborah Copeland, director of the Program for Deaf and Hearing-Impaired Students.   ''This will enable deaf students to succeed in whatever careers they choose from and not be limited,'' said Miss Copeland, herself deaf and speaking through an interpreter. Lehman College is the only public four-year institution in the area to offer the program, which will enable the students to take any course they wish and will provide oral and sign-language interpreters, counseling, tutoring and note-taking services to students who need help.

headline: Award for a Blind Student Of Music and Literature
abstract: When Orlando Fiol sits down at the piano, he plays Chopin, Bach, Debussy or Vivaldi. On an electric piano, he leans to pop music and jazz.   When not making music, he might be found immersed in Shakespeare or in the French and Russian classics, writing fiction of his own or teaching himself Hebrew.

headline: Elderly and Blind Are Tax Reform's Losers
abstract: To the Editor:   One of the most widely hailed features of tax reform is the near doub-ling of the personal exemption to $2,000. Regrettably, the least discussed feature is the proposed repeal of the long-held extra exemption for the elderly (65 and over) and the blind.   The loss of the extra exemption at the $2,000 level means a difference of $300 a year to each elderly and blind taxpayer in the 15 percent bracket. Under the House and Senate bills a $600 standard deduction reduces this $300 to $210 for nonitemizers.

headline: A BOVINE DRUG THAT HELPS PEOPLE SEE
abstract: DR. JOHN M. BOWEN, director of the Veterinary Medical Experiment Station for the University of Georgia's College of Veterinary Medicine, calls it a ''wonder drug.'' David K. Crossen, a drug analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, says it is ''the best anti-parasitic ever developed.'' And now another superlative is on the way: It may join the tiny number of animal drugs adapted to human use.

headline: WOMAN, 67, AND BLIND WOMAN ARE RAPE VICTIMS
abstract: An 18-year-old delivery boy was arrested yesterday and charged with beating, raping and robbing a 67-year-old Brooklyn woman in her Borough Park apartment where he also attempted to drown her by pushing her face into a toilet, the police said.   The Brooklyn attack occurred yesterday afternoon, 12 hours after a 37-year-old legally blind Manhattan woman was bludgeoned with a hammer, raped at knifepoint and robber in her East Side apartment by an unknown assailant who fled with her fur coat, video casette player and $80 in cash.   The suspect in the Brooklyn attack, Derrick Benjamin, of 180 Troy Avenue, Brooklyn, was being held on charges of first-degree rape, first-degree assault and second-degree burglary, according to Ronald Severin, a spokesman for the Police Department.

headline: Suspect May Face New Rape Charge
abstract: A 26-year-old man who was charged Thursday with a series of burglaries and sexual attacks in Brooklyn is also a suspect in the rape and robbery this week of a legally blind Manhattan woman, the police said yesterday.   Fingerprints found in the East 77th Street apartment of Eileen Musumeci Ross, 37, who was raped and bludgeoned with a hammer early Monday, matched those of Tyrone Graham, who was arrested late Wednesday in the attacks in the Crown Heights section, the police said.

headline: TAPES SURPASS BRAILLE IN POPULARITY FOR BLIND
abstract: In 1934, the Library of Congress made its first recording for the blind, ''The Rime of the Ancient Mariner,'' produced on a wax disk. More than 50 years later, the cassette tape, a descendant of that effort to harness sound for the education of the blind, has grown so popular that it has surpassed the use of Braille in the library, home and classroom, according to academic experts.   Braille, in which raised dots representing letters are read with the fingertips, has dwindled in use. In large part that is because its primary use was as an early learning tool for blind children and fewer children are being born blind than ever as a result of dramatic developments in prenatal care.

headline: PLAYHOUSE INTERPRETS SHOWS FOR DEAF AUDIENCE
abstract:
MARY SILVESTRI has seen ''West Side Story'' many times. But last week she ''heard'' the show - the plaintive love songs, the taunting of the warring street gangs - for the first time at a Candlewood Playhouse production that was interpreted for the deaf.

''Oh, what a difference it makes,'' Mrs. Silvestri said during an intermission. ''I'm enjoying it so much.''

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: An article last Sunday on the growing use by blind people of tape recordings instead of Braille misidentified the director of the Library for the Blind and Physically Handicapped, a division of the Library of Congress. He is Dr. F. Kurt Cylke, not Dr. Kurt Silke.

headline: Blind but Mobile
abstract: A guide dog lay under the piano.   White canes were leaning against the warm-up room wall. And instructors guided the arms, legs and bodies of 12 students into various dance positions.

headline: BRIEFING; All Ears
abstract: Washingtonians have been telling affectionate Averell Harriman stories since the distinguished diplomat and public servant died 10 days ago at 94 years of age. One of them involves the fact that the former New York Governor had suffered a correctable hearing loss for years and recently got a new hearing aid that used a separate, hand-carried radio to pick up and transmit sound to the ear device.

headline: Rape Suspect Pleads Innocent
abstract: The man accused of being the ''Spiderman rapist,'' who scaled apartment buildings and a private house to get at his victims, pleaded innocent yesterday to raping, robbing and beating with a hammer a legally blind woman.   Tyrone Graham, 26 years old, also under indictment for three sex assaults in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, appeared briefly in state Supreme Supreme Court in Manhattan for arraignment before Justice Jerome Hornblass.

headline: World's Largest Taped Library for the Blind
abstract: To the Editor:   In an otherwise instructive news article about recorded material for the blind (July 20), you failed to mention Recording for the Blind Inc., a nonprofit organization that has put on tape more titles than all other recording organizations in the United States combined.   Through 4,500 trained volunteers working in 29 recording studios across the country, Recording for the Blind has recorded, since its founding in 1951, over 65,000 titles, which now make up our master tape library in Princeton, N.J.   These titles, which constitute the largest and most comprehensive taped library in the world, can be quickly duplicated, and they are lent free to blind students in all 50 states.

headline: TV Networks Shortchange the Hearing-Impaired
abstract: To the Editor:   In researching the number of hours of prime-time television programming on the four major networks that is closed-captioned for the hearing-impaired, I have come up with the following disappointing results:   Of the total of 143 programming hours, Saturday through Friday from 5 to 9 P.M., only 53 hours are closed-captioned, which represents 37 percent of the hours researched.   Of those 53 hours, 52 percent are movies, 8 percent are news shows, 25 percent are educational programs and 15 percent, or the balance, are series shows, such as ''The Cosby Show'' and ''Family Ties.''

headline: Banning Playboy In Braille Editions
abstract: THE literary merit of Playboy was weighed on the floor of the United States House of Representatives last year, and opponents, led by Chalmers P. Wylie, Republican of Ohio, found the magazine ''wanton.''   The House voted to withhold $103,000 from the Library of Congress to produce Braille editions of Playboy.

headline: Legally Blind Man, 85, Killed In Fall Into Sidewalk Opening
abstract: An 85-year-old retired textile executive who was legally blind stepped into an open basement entrance on West 86th Street and fell 30 feet to his death, the police said.   The man, Marcel Friedmann, of 241 Central Park West, at West 84th Street, who used a metal cane, was walking alone just after 9 A.M. Monday when he fell through the opening in front of 40 West 86th Street, the police said.

headline: BLIND WIN RULING ON BRAILLE PLAYBOY
abstract: A Federal District judge ruled today that the Library of Congress violated the First Ammendment rights of blind people by eliminating Braille editions of Playboy magazine.   The Library of Congress ceased production of Braille editions of Playboy last December, after Congress withheld $103,000 in library funds, the exact amount it costs to print 1,000 copies of the magazine for the blind.   The Braille edition of the magazine, which comes in four volumes, contains no pictures or advertisements.

headline: OUTSIDER IN A SILENT WORLD
abstract: WHEN I WAS born, the obstetrician looked at my mother and traced the hourglass figure of a woman. It was his way of telling her she had had a baby girl. The doctor then walked over and clapped his hands near my head to see if I would respond. He went back to my mother and, smiling, pointed to his ears and nodded. Everyone in the delivery room was relieved I was a ''normal'' baby.   Dad passed out cigars to the men at work and cradled his arms to let them know his wife had given birth. He pulled out the small white notepad he always carried and wrote ''girl.''   I was their first child. It was 1952, in Blackford County, Ind.

headline: Prime-Time Closed Captioning on the Networks
abstract: To the Editor:   Laurie Emery (letter, Aug. 23) speaks of ''researching the number of hours of prime-time television programming on the four major networks that is closed captioned for the hearing-impaired.'' Her research, she notes, covered ''Saturday through Friday from 5 to 9 P.M.'' But those hours are, for the most part, not programmed by the networks and are not prime time.

headline: Drug for River Blindness
abstract: A new drug may be an important breakthrough in the treatment of river blindness, a tropical disease that now impairs or destroys the sight of 40 million people in Africa and South America, scientists report. River blindness, or onchocerciasis, is caused by a parasite that is spread from person to person by blackflies that breed in rivers and streams.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: An article in Metropolitan Report on Aug. 27 about Marcel Friedmann, a retired textile executive who died when he fell through a basement opening on West 86th Street, gave his address incorrectly. He lived at 275 Central Park West, not 241.

headline: GIVING MOBILITY TO THE BLIND
abstract: As 18-year-old Anthony Vega of the Bronx approached the curb at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue, tapping the ground with his ''long cane,'' as blind people call it, a young man took him by the elbow and asked if he could help. He could and did, escorting Mr. Vega to the nearby subway entrance.   ''In learning to deal with the public, you take the help you want, and don't if you don't need it,'' said Mr. Vega, a client in the orientation and mobility program operated by the Lighthouse, New York Association for the Blind. Founded 12 Years Ago    The program was founded 12 years ago to help blind people ''move through space in a safe fashion,'' said Bob Sunberg, its supervisor.

headline: Living In a Silent World
abstract: I question the implicit message that Lou Ann Walker's experiences were fundamentally different from others simply because her parents are deaf. For example, my grandmother, who raised me, was a native Italian living in a non-Italian section of New York.

headline: Living In a Silent World
abstract: Lou Ann Walker is perceptive about her deaf parents but, nevertheless, perpetuates myths that are all too common in articles about the deaf (''Outsider in a Silent World,'' Aug. 31). The troublesome thing about Ms. Walker's article is the pain it must have given to parents of young deaf children who are struggling with a very difficult problem.

headline: Living in a Silent World
abstract: Lou Ann Walker's article highlights the need to provide deaf and hearing-impaired people with the same opportunities as the non-hearing-impaired have.

headline: LOSS OF DRUG RELEGATES MANY TO BLINDNESS AGAIN
abstract: Thousands of patients with rare neuromuscular disorders are suffering renewed contortions of the eyes, face, neck and other parts of the body because their supply of experimental medicine was cut off when its only manufacturer was unable to obtain liability insurance.   Many who had been faring well are now reverting to functional blindness, unable to read, work, drive or venture outdoors. Others can no longer speak; some suffer debilitating muscle spasms that contort their faces or necks.   Desperate patients are traveling to Canada or England to obtain the experimental drug, made of botulinum toxin. It is the only medicine that gives them satisfactory relief. A few are already resorting to risky, disfiguring surgery as the only alternative to the missing medicine.

headline: They Truly Beat The Other Guys
abstract: On most college football sidelines, the drum is just another instrument in the band. At Gallaudet College, it's a 12th man.   Gallaudet, a private school in Washington for the hearing-impaired, replaces the quarterback's snap count with the beat of a bass drum, which the lesser-impaired players can hear. Those who can't hear the beat are able, because of their heightened tactile sense, to feel the vibrations from it, so that the offense moves as one, whether on the first pulse, the second, or the third.

headline: Consumer Group Asks F.D.A. To Take Sweetener off Market
abstract: A consumer group, citing more than 60 people who, the group says, have lost part or all of their eyesight after using products containing NutraSweet, has begun pressing a new petition that asks the Government to ban the artificial sweetener as a health hazard.   James Turner, a lawyer, and the Consumer Nutrition Institute, who have campaigned against the sweetener for more than a decade, filed their latest petition Thursday with the Food and Drug Administration.

headline: INSIDE IMAGES OF THE DEAF AND BLIND
abstract:
LIKE many people, Mathieu Roberts was ill at ease when he first made contact with the deaf and blind residents of the Helen Keller National Center in Sands Point.

His interest piqued from serving as cinematographer on the film ''The World at His Fingertips,'' a documentary about a man who loses both sight and hearing as an adult, Mr. Roberts had come to the rehabilitation center to do a photographic portrait series of the male and female residents.

That series, ''Without Sight and Sound: Photographic Portraits of Deaf and Blind Individuals at the Helen Keller National Center,'' is on exhibit at the Port Washington Library to commemorate the center's 10th anniversary. Eventually it will tour Long Island and the Northeast.

headline: MORRISTOWN WILL OFFER BALLOTS IN BRAILLE
abstract: ABSENTEE ballots in Braille will be available for the asking to blind and visually impaired Morris County voters for the Nov. 4 election.   The ballots are the first ''created anywhere in the country,'' according to Joseph J. Bell Jr. of Rockaway Township, the Morris County Clerk and originator of the idea.   ''In the past,'' he said, ''a blind individual, in order to vote, had to show up at the polls with a relative who had to enter the voting place and cast the actual vote. With the absentee ballot, the blind will be able to cast their own votes with a sense of pride and privacy.''

headline: The Uses of Lip-Reading
abstract: To the Editor:   I find it difficult to accept Hugh Kenner's statement in his review of ''A Loss for Words'' by Lou Ann Walker (Oct. 5) that for the deaf ''lip-reading is of little use. It relies heavily on contextual guessing, which in turn requires a good repertory of English structures.''   The great majority of the hearing cannot sign. All, however, can with a little acquaintance and practice read lips. It is true that very few of the profoundly deaf ever learn to speak well, but their lip movements grant visual access to those who make even the slightest effort to communicate with them. Those who are deaf and have been taught lip-reading have little fear of approaching anyone who has the patience to understand what they are saying. Further, it has been my experience that syntax is no problem: the deaf read and write as well as those who hear; they fully enjoy subtitled films and television programs that are captioned. Lip-reading ''socializes'' them.

headline: THE DEAF ARE DIVIDED ON THE FILM ''LESSER GOD''
abstract:
''CHILDREN OF A LESSER GOD'' is a film based on Mark Medoff's 1980 Tony-award winning play about deafness. The deaf have some things to say about it.

In fact, the love story about a deaf woman's struggle to communicate with a hearing man has been the subject of debate in the deaf community since the film's release last month.

Some scoff at the film's happy ending; others say the lovers can indeed bridge their worlds of silence and sound. There are those who think the characters in the movie are believable and those who say they are not.

headline: PERSONAL HEALTH
abstract: A TRAGEDY of modern medical care is that, even in an age of virtually instant communication, it often takes years to get the word out about new life- and limb-saving treatments to the people who could most benefit from them. One of these is laser therapy for an insidious disorder called diabetic retinopathy, the leading cause of new cases of blindness among American adults. Some 600,000 people already have early stages of this condition and could lose their sight if it is not detected and promptly treated.   Each year, diabetic retinopathy renders some 5,000 diabetics legally blind, at least half of them unnecessarily. When the disorder is diagnosed early and treated with laser therapy, useful vision can often be preserved.   Yet a study in Wisconsin two years ago found that 62 percent of diabetics never had the eye examination necessary to detect retinopathy. In 1979, two years after the benefits of laser therapy were clearly demonstrated in a well-publicized national study, two-thirds of family physicians and half of internists surveyed in Michigan were unaware of the study and its implications for the prevention of blindness in diabetics.

headline: Blind Passenger Ousted After Refusing Switch
abstract: A blind man was escorted off a USAir jetliner by the police and cited for defiant trespass after he refused to move from his assigned seat near an emergency door, the authorities said today.   The man, Terry McManus, president of the National Federation of the Blind of Pennsylvania, said he considered the request to switch seats discriminatory.   Airline officials ''will tell you it's a matter of safety, that they're afraid blind people can't exit, yet they will ply the people in exit rows with as much liquor as they can drink,'' Mr. McManus said.

headline: SCHOOL FOR THE DEAF HAS DANCE PREVIEW
abstract:
''IF I weren't dancing, I wouldn't feel good about myself -I can't go without dancing,'' said Alexandra Mendoza, a 15-year-old student at the Dance Theater in Westchester and a performer in the company's coming production of ''A Colonial Nutcracker.'' Alexandra, who is hearing impaired and lip-reads with the assistance of hearing aids, was meeting one recent morning with a group of students at the New York School for the Deaf, in White Plains.

The meeting was in preparation for the students' trip to see a school performance of the ballet, which is being presented by the Westchester County Historical Society at the Academic Arts Theater of Westchester Community College from Tuesday through Thursday, with two public performances on Saturday.

Alexandra's visit with about 45 students in grades five through eight came about as the result of talks between Madeline Reich, chairman of enrichment at the School for the Deaf, and Kathy Grantham, a member of the historical society's executive board and chairman for the ballet, which reflects Colonial history.
