abstract: Article on 71-year-old artist Matthew Feinman, who is legally blind; his latest works are on display at Blue Mountain Gallery in SoHo section of Manhattan; photos (M)

headline: Another Battle Begins Over Fire Boxes, as Critics Attack the One-Button System
abstract: Nearly seven months after Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani and City Council ended almost two-year battle with compromise to shrink city's fire alarm box system, administration's efforts to shape new system have started another fight; critics contend that new type of box being installed by Fire Dept--with single button that sends all calls to 911, instead of two buttons, one for police and second for fire dispatchers--has caused delays, some as long as 10 minutes in answering distress calls in some neighborhoods; lawyers for 65,000 hearing-impaired New Yorkers, who filed Federal lawsuit last year to block Giuliani's original plan to remove all boxes, say new boxes are discriminatory; photo (M)

headline: Blind Users Add Access On the Web
abstract: American Foundation for the Blind, New York, estimates that of 12 million Americans with visual impairments of some sort, 900,000 use computers; Larry Scadden, who works on technology issues for disabled at National Science Foundation, and is blind, says Internet has changed forever lives of blind people; National Federation of Blind's International Braille and Technology Center, Baltimore, is world's largest proving ground for products for blind and has worked to test accessibility of computer hardware and software; use of computers by people who are visually impaired depends on two factors: fact that text can be read aloud by speech synthesizer or can be output in Braille format and the user's ability to navigate screen with keyboard; photo; list of some Web sites for visually impaired (L)

headline: Paper Mill Playhouse Tries Captioning for the Deaf
abstract: Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, NJ, is experimenting with open-captioning system for deaf in which text appears on onstage digital screen (S)

headline: Eye-Closing Surgery Restores Vision
abstract: Dr Arthur Cotliar has used keratoprosthesis, rare and complicated surgical technique, to restore vision of Wlodzimierz Nazaruk, who was blinded by lye 45 years ago; surgery involves implantation of external tube, which acts like periscope, through cornea into eye; photo (M)

headline: Rwandan's Prize Is His Hearing Back
abstract: Gabriel Mazimpaka, who was alternate on Rwanda's Olympic track team, is deaf; Dr John T McElveen, ear specialist in Raleigh, NC, has performed two operations on Mazimpaka that are expected to restore about 90 percent of his hearing; photo (M)

headline: Disney Agrees to Help Hearing Impaired
abstract: Disney Company will add services for hearing-impaired visitors at its amusement parks; reaches agreement with Justice Department, which had approached Disney after receiving complaints (S)

headline: A Legally Blind Art Student Juggles Studies, a Job and Extra Activities
abstract: Profile of Elizabeth Castellano, sophomore at Manhattanville College, Purchase, New York, who is studying for bachelor's degree in studio art, works seven hours a week in campus art gallery and helps teach drawing class at Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York City; what makes her accomplishments distinctive is that she is legally blind; Prof Randy Willaims, chairman of college's art department and Castellano's adviser, comments on talents she brings to her work; photos (M)

headline: Mime Group Entertains Deaf Children
abstract: Dynamo Theater, Montreal-based troupe of mimes and acrobatic artists, performs play Mur-Mur at Emelin Theater, Mamaroneck; answers questions from audience composed mainly of deaf children; photo (M)

headline: Saturn Pulls Disputed Ad
abstract: Saturn division of General Motors Corp withdraws advertisements featuring a woman described as hearing-impaired Saturn owner after allegations appeared in publications for deaf that her hearing is normal; print and television ads, created by Hal Riney & Partners, have featured Holly Daniel, a woman from Baton Rouge, La, as part of series that centers on satisfied Saturn owners (S)

headline: Deaf Students Find Jobs With Internships
abstract: Group of students from New York School for the Deaf are working as rotating interns in various departments at Rye Town Hilton Hotel in Rye Brook, NY; as program enters second term, its success has led to commitment from school and hotel to expand it in 1998; photos (M)

headline: Studies for Living Designed for the Deaf
abstract: American School for the Deaf in West Hartford, Conn, will celebrate its 180th anniversary on April 15; school, the first for the deaf in the country and the only one in Connecticut, has become a model for 70 schools for deaf around the country; photos (L)

headline: Blinded Wife Testifies in a Twisting Trial
abstract: Linda Pugach defends her husband, Burton N Pugach, in Queens courtroom against charges that he threatened his mistress of five years; Mr Pugach was convicted of paying three men to throw lye in face of Mrs Pugach, then Linda Riss, in 1959 after she learned that he was married and broke up with him; Mrs Pugach, who was blinded in attack, married Mr Pugach in 1974; photo (M)

headline: Mystery Mother and Son Are Sent to New Hospital
abstract: Jose Gomez and his mother, Lydia Espina, who arrived at St James Hospital in Newark without identification or apparent ability to speak are transferred to Woodhull Medical Center, municipal hospital in Williamsburg, Brooklyn (S)

headline: The Blind, Like Others, Fish by the Sense of Feel
abstract: Members of Helen Keller Fishing Club, an offshoot of Helen Keller Services for the Blind in Brooklyn, enjoy a deep-sea fishing excursion from Sheepshead Bay; photo (M)

headline: Top Student Has to Share Top Honors
abstract: Our Towns column on Debra Pantina, who is legally blind, but has won battle to be valedictorian of graduating class at Newburgh, NY, high school; she will share honor with another student (M)

headline: Digital Hearing Aids Hold New Promise
abstract: New digital hearing aids, which can be programmed to meet individual needs and adjust automatically to changing levels of sound in environment, hold new promise for hearing impaired, but difference of opinion exists over whether they represent enough of improvement over conventional models to justify cost: between $2,000 and $3,700 each (M)

headline: Making a Nature Trail More Inviting to Everyone
abstract: Girl Scouts work developing interactive trail at Stamford (Conn) Museum and Nature Center to make trail appeal to, among others, blind visitors; Stamford trail is not the only one being developed right now for estimated 14,000 blind residents of Connecticut; other trails are also in various stages of completion in Fairfield and Vernon; photo (M)

headline: Back on the Course For a Blind Golfer
abstract: Profile of 38-year-old blind golfer Bill McMahon; he is one of best blind golfers in world, shooting around 100; photo (M)

headline: Accommodating Hearing-Impaired
abstract: Lurie Kraus letter on June 1 article about architectural designs to accommodate the handicapped; points out needs of the hearing-impaired, who comprise three-quarters of the disabled in US (S)

headline: Where the Touch Is Everything
abstract: Profile of Stewart Jones of Winsted, Conn, owner of Jaguar restoration and repair shop, who happens to be blind; photos (M)

headline: Personal Health
abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on macular degeneration, or loss of central vision, that is leading cause of legal blindness in US; offers advice on symptoms and on treatment to halt or slow disease; diagrams (M)

headline: Personal Health
abstract: Jane Brody's Personal Health column says even though thorough eye examination every two or three years is considered adequate for people under 50 with no known visual problems, and even though blindness is problem that frightens Americans most after cancer, surprisingly few people, including those who are otherwise health-conscious, get eyes checked regularly; about 1.7 million Americans are legally blind because of macular degeneration; more than 11 million have signs of disease, and about 200,000 cases are diagnosed each year; symptoms of disease and some forms of treatment discussed; photo; drawing (M)

headline: A Blind Rider Races Into the Nationals
abstract: Interview with Matt King, tandem bicycle racer who is first blind rider to compete in EDS national championships; photo (M)

headline: A Neighborhood Was Jarred By Cries of 'the Mute Ones'
abstract: Interview with residents of Jackson Heights, Queens, neighborhood where dozens of mostly deaf and mute Mexicans were discovered living in squalor in two crammed apartments as indentured laborers; co-owner of building says when she bought dwelling three months ago tenants were already living there, and that she did not know who was renting house; map (M)

headline: For Some Hispanic Immigrants, a Sense of Kinship With the Silent Laborers
abstract: Many Hispanic immigrants to New York City say discovery of 62 mostly deaf Mexican immigrants held virtually captive in two Queens apartments underscores just how deperately some of their compatriots want to get ahead; illegal immigrants comment on their exploitation in city's service economy (M)

headline: Man Relates Tangled Tale Implicating Deaf Ex-Wife
abstract: Frank Coenen, deaf Long Island man linked to trinket trade involving deaf Mexicans in Queens, says his ex-wife, Adriana Paoletti, was mastermind behind trade, interview; says they divorced because she used his status as citizen to bring dozens of people to their Queens apartment and put them to work selling trinkets; denies involvement in scheme (M)

headline: Dozens of Deaf Immigrants Discovered in Forced Labor
abstract: 62 Mexican immigrants, mostly deaf and mute, are discovered by police crammed into two small apartments in Jackson Heights, Queens, where they lived in virtual slavery, working 18-hour days selling $1 key chains in subways and airports; discovery comes after four walked into local precinct and described ordeal; police question man, identified as either Alfredo Paoletti or Alfredo Rustrian, whom others describe as 'the boss' who allegedly smuggled them through Newark International Airport and confiscated their personal documents; Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, Mexican consular and Red Cross officials, as well as agents from Immigration and Naturalization Service, visit police precinct; Giuliani deplores situation as horrible and disgusting; Queens Dist Atty Richard Brown says immigrants, including 10 children, will be taken into custody by immigration officials; residents of Jackson Heights neighborhood comment; photos (M)

headline: In Mexico, Tales of Deception Confirm the Fears of the Deaf
abstract: Arrest of seven Mexicans on charge of smuggling 57 deaf Mexicans into US and holding them in involuntary servitude in New York City arouses considerable alarm in Mexico City, confirming widespread rumors of ill treatment suffered by thousands of deaf who travel to US each year to sell trinkets on streets from Los Angeles to Queens; events transfix deaf people and make headlines in several of city's largest newspapers; photo (M)

headline: Neighbors' Response To Trouble Is Silence
abstract: Some residents of Jackson Heights, Queens, neighbors of deaf Mexicans immigrants rescued from force labor, indicate they were aware of darker details of their lives, but never called police; fear deaf Mexicans will now face even more serious problems; map (M)

headline: 7 Arrested in Abuse of Deaf Immigrants
abstract: Seven Mexican immigrants are arrested on charges of running smuggling ring that sneaked scores of deaf Mexicans across border, stashed them in safe houses in California and later flew them to New York, where they lived in servitude and terror in two crowded apartments in Jackson Heights; Reinaldo Paoletti, suspected ringleader, is being sought by authorities in US and Mexico; immigrants, almost all of whom are illegal, were forced to criss-cross city by train, beginning before dawn selling $1 key chains; say they often worked until midnight because they suffered physical abuse if they returned home without $100 in earnings; have been housed in motel at insistence of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, who says they must remain in city's custody as crime victims and witnesses; photos (M)

headline: An Array of State and Federal Charges
abstract: Seven people accused of holding deaf and mute Mexicans against their will in Queens face number of Federal and state charges; Adriana Paoletti, Raul Alanis and Adelja Paoletti face coercion and other state charges; Jose Paoletti Lemus, Refugia Santa, Alfredo Rustrian Paoletti and Rosa Beltran-Sanchez face Federal charges of smuggling, harboring and transporting illegal immigrants (S)

headline: Dollar Bills Laundered In Casinos, U.S. Says
abstract: People charged with overseeing illegal network of deaf Mexican peddlers laundered tens of thousands of $1 bills through casinos in Atlantic City, then smuggled cash to Mexico, according to Federal investigator and man who says he played minor role in operation; Brendan Coenen, former brother-in-law of Adriana Paoletti-Lemus--one of central figures charged in scheme--says group's network extended well beyond 57 illegal immigrants taken from two Queens apartments during police raids on July 19 (M)

headline: The Abuse of Illegal Immigrants
abstract: Editorial deplores abuse of illegal immigrants by smugglers, who kept 57 deaf Mexicans in virtual slavery in two cramped houses in Jackson Heights, Queens; says only practical answer to problem is tougher enforcement of laws against illegal working conditions, overcrowded housing and smuggling of illegal immigrants (S)

headline: Agencies Had Inspected Captives' Apartment
abstract: City officials say one of two apartments in Queens crammed with dozens of deaf Mexicans had become such neighborhood fixture and source of complaints that employees of several city agencies visited there over last several months to investigate overcrowding or to respond to medical emergency; say Buildings Dept inspector, after visiting site in Feb, reported that he found no violations of city code--finding that Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani says is hard to believe (M)

headline: Telling Tales of Hunger, Abuse and Forced Labor
abstract: Fifty-seven deaf Mexican immigrants, most of them in country illegally, are being held at motel in Elmhurst, Queens, until police and Federal immigration officials decide where they go next; authorities are still trying to understand scope of smuggling ring that they believe operated for nearly decade, promising new life to poor, mostly young deaf Mexicans who had little hope back home; photo (M)

headline: Prosecutors Offer a Chilling Story of Exploitation
abstract: Federal prosecutors offer grimly detailed account of smuggling of deaf Mexicans into New York City for nearly decade by band of illegal Mexican immigrants; say that smugglers ran efficient, organized criminal enterprise, complete with assigned roles as recruiters, money collectors and enforcers, and that some even went back to Mexico to recruit new workers; says group appears to have laundered money through casinos in Atlantic City and to have moved some back to Mexico; seven defendants are arraigned as search for suspected ringleader, Reinaldo Paoletti, continues; Immigration and Naturalization Service will assume custody of 57 people, who could eventually be deported; photos (M)

headline: Immigrants: In Plain Sight, But Not Seen
abstract: Clyde Haberman column contends that New Yorkers deplore plight of 57 deaf Mexicans who were smuggled into US and forced to panhandle in subways; maintains that New Yorkers who indulge in simple pleasures like going out to dinner once in a while have grown more dependent on immigration, legal or otherwise, than they care to admit (M)

headline: Immigration Angst
abstract: Prof Alan Wolfe Op-Ed article on illegal immigration in light of tale of deaf Mexican trinket sellers held in virtual bondage in New York City; holds such emotionally powerful anecdotes should not be allowed to influence immigration policy; drawing (M)

headline: Conflicting View Emerges Of Family Linked to Deaf
abstract: Officials say Jose Paoletti Moreda built family business over past decade based on work force of vendors recruited from Mexico's deaf population and allegedly forced to sell trinkets in New York City; Moreda, 59, his wife, Delia, and their three children, Adriana, Jose and Renato, all of them deaf, transferred to United States business plied by other deaf people in Mexico City for decades; neighbors, teachers and relatives of deaf workers dispute depiction of family as ruthless profiteers; photos (M)

headline: Suspects in Exploitation of Immigrants May Be Tied to Other Rings
abstract: Federal investigators believe that band of Mexicans accused of forcing dozens of deaf immigrants into virtual slavery as peddlers in New York City helped run similar operation in Los Angeles and perhaps in three other US cities; say leads about other possible operations have come through interviews with 57 deaf victims in New York and their relatives in Mexico; Five of seven suspects charged in New York are members of Paoletti family of Mexico City; photo (M)

headline: Do Words, Or Policies, Protect Immigrants?
abstract: Clifford J Levy column contends that while case of 57 deaf Mexicans who were living in virtual bondage in Jackson Heights, Queens, is allowing Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani to show once again that he is champion of immigrants, it is also opening him to criticism that his housing policies contributed to plight of Mexicans and that his own administration missed several opportunities to come to their aid (M)

headline: Agents Seek Associates in Smuggling Ring
abstract: Law enforcement officials in Los Angeles begin searching for associates of Mexican family accused of holding scores of deaf immigrants in virtual slavery in New York City, but they appear to find something less than satellite smuggling ring that officials feared might exist; people familiar with Paoletti family's activities in Los Angeles say operations seem far less extensive than those discovered in New York; photo (M)

headline: Bill Would Increase Penalties For Dividing Houses Illegaly
abstract: Giuliani administration and City Council respond to discovery of 57 deaf Mexican immigrants living in two Queens apartments by agreeing on bill that would sharply increase existing penalties on landlords who subdivide houses illegally; under agreement, city would increase fines on property owners from maximum of $5,000 to up to $10,000 and would attempt to strengthen enforcement of building codes (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of two July 23 articles about exploitation of deaf Mexicans in New York City illegally

headline: Poor and Deaf From Mexico Betrayed in Their Dreams
abstract: Interviews in New York and Mexico provide accounts of lives of deaf people who were brought to US illegally and kept as virtual indentured servants in overcrowded lodgings in New York City; photos; families at home received postcards describing supposed good life, but many feared their relatives had been all but kidnapped, although none of them took any action; Paoletti family of Mexico City, deaf as well, enticed them to leave Mexico, where many lived on fringes of society and pedled trinkets, as they were to do in New York; some of 57 now being held at Queens motel describe lives; photo (M)

headline: In Mexico, Deaf Find The Future Lies North
abstract: Conditions facing the deaf in Mexico are so grim that 80 percent of deaf adults go to United States; in eyes of Mexican law, deaf are considered incompetent; they cannot hold driver's license, nor can they buy house unless hearing person co-signs contract; there are only six Government schools for deaf in Mexico, all ending at sixth grade; if they can find work, deaf do most menial of jobs, cleaning floors or sanding wood; photos (L)

headline: Carolina Raid Finds Exploited Deaf Mexicans
abstract: Immigration and Naturalization Service agents raid two houses, Sanford, NC, and finds more than dozen illegal Mexican immigrants, most of them deaf; say 'bosses' held Mexicans in bondage and forced them to sell trinkets; prosecutors probe for link with similar New York City operation; Federal prosecutors arrest Frank Coenen on charges he helped bring illegal immigrants to NYC; he is former husband of Adriana Paoletti Lemus, whose family allegedly organized NYC operation; investigators probe for similar operations in Chicago, other cities; map; photo (M)

headline: New York Apathy
abstract: Rosalind Ellis letter on abuse of deaf Mexican immigrants; deplores apathy of their neighbors

headline: Too Many Immigrants
abstract: John L Martin letter holds what is more shocking thatn exploitation of deaf Mexican illegal aliens is fact that it might have gone on indefinitely if aliens had not complained

headline: U.S. Needs to Broaden Law Against Slavery
abstract: Joey Asher letter observes it would be a shame if people charged with holding deaf Mexican street peddlers in New York City escape punishment for enslavement because United States has not complied with human rights treaty

headline: Learning to Sign
abstract: Jane Allen letter on horrible story of deaf Mexican immigrants forced into virtual slavery in New York City; suggests that their plight might have come to public attention sooner if more people knew sign language

headline: World's 'Relief Valve'
abstract: Stjepan Balog letter on plight of deaf Mexican immigrants; questions US policy of allowing almost unlimited legal and illegal immigration

headline: Pair Arrested in Chicago In Smuggling-Ring Inquiry
abstract: Federal investigators broaden inquiry into smuggling ring that exploited deaf Mexicans; arrest Norma Alcantara and Frank Dueno, alleged leaders of trinket-peddling operation in Chicago similar to one recently discovered in New York City (M)

headline: What Modern Slavery Is, and Isn't
abstract: Slavery is older than recorded human history, but definition of 'contemporary forms' of enslavement is elusive; Mike Dottridge, director of Anti-Slavery International, says word slavery is abused, applied to so many conditions that there is danger that its meaning will be diluted or even diminished; says slavery is identified by element of ownership or control over another's life, coercion and restriction of movement; that fate appears to have befallen dozens of deaf Mexicans discovered in Queens, so they fit new definition of slavery; photo (M)

headline: For Deaf Peddlers, Both Opportunity And Exploitation
abstract: Paoletti family is notable for the scale of their operation and the extremes to which they are said to have gone in mistreating deaf people they lured from Mexico to sell trinkets in New York City; they are, however, only part of a byzantine economy of deaf immigrant peddlars in cities across the US, some of whom prosper and others of whom are abused; photos (M)

headline: Mexicans in New York Search for a Toehold on a Crowded Ladder
abstract: Plight of 57 deaf Mexicans held in servitude in Queens strikes common chord among other Mexicans living in New York, for whom indignities are accepted as unofficial price of undocumented life; these new arrivals are at bottom of ladder in community influence, living conditions and earning power; shun forming kinds of local associations to advocate for better jobs or housing, and they they do not seek help of older Mexican-American advocacy groups, probably out of fear of illegal status; hope hard work will prove redemptive, but changes in city's labor market have caused Mexicans, unlike earlier immigrant groups, to remain clustered in low-paying jobs in restaurants, delis and sweatshops that could thwart their progress into middle class; ; photos; map; charts (L)

headline: Man Held as Enforcer in Chicago Ring Exploiting Deaf Peddlers
abstract: Federal officials charge Juan Antonio Limon-Sosa, illegal immigrant from Mexico, with being enforcer of Chicago ring that was associated with New York City operation that exploited deaf Mexican immigrants (M)

headline: Judge Rules Fire Box Plan Denies Access To the Deaf
abstract: Judge Robert W Sweet rules that plan to shrink New York City's fire alarm box system violates civil rights of 65,000 deaf and hearing-impaired residents; ruling means that system, subject of three-year battle between Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani and City Council, will remain virtually unchanged (M)

headline: From Victim to Suspect for a Mexican Peddler
abstract: Prosecutors charge Ivan Gomez-Sanchez with being 'enforcer' in Jackson Heights, Queens, house where 44 of deaf Mexican immigrants were discovered by police on July 19 (M)

headline: 3 Charged With Smuggling Deaf Mexicans
abstract: Federal authorities charge three men with running an operation based in Southern California thorugh which possibly hundreds of deaf Mexicans were smuggled across border, kept briefly in house in Los Angeles, and then taken to New York City where they were held in virtual slavery and forced to peddle trinkets; United States Attorney in Brooklyn, Zachary W Carter, announces arrests of Andreas Pfeiffer and Hilario Pauletti, whom he identifies as leaders of Los Angeles smuggling ring, and Pauletti's son, Carlos Rivera, mid-level manager (M)

headline: 17th Arrest Made in Case Of Deaf Mexican Peddlers
abstract: Federal authorities charge 17th person with being part of cross-country ring that they say exploited and abused deaf immigrants smuggled from Mexico; latest man charged is deaf illegal immigrant himself; authorities say his job was to administer beatings to other deaf pepole at behest of group ringleader; authorities have not yet said how widespread, or lucrative, they think organization was (M)

headline: Deaf Mexicans Are to Remain As Witnesses
abstract: Immigration officials say some of deaf Mexicans found living in servitude in Queens will be allowed to stay in United States for at least three years to help in criminal cases against alleged enslavers; say they can apply for legal residency after special visas expire; Rep Charles E Schumer lauds plan (M)

headline: For Former Captives, A New Routine Begins
abstract: Deaf Mexicans who were allegedly exploited and abused by smugglers who brought them from Mexico have settled into dull routine at Queens motel in Immigration and Naturalization Service custody; are heavily guarded by police and immigration officials and barred from press contact; three social workers communicate with them through interpreters; photo (M)

headline: So a Sound Unheard Can Still Be Sensed
abstract: Variety of new products featuring flashing lights or vibrations help the hearing impaired perceive important sounds such as doorbells and telephones; photos (M)

headline: 2 Held as Leaders of Ring Involving Deaf Immigrants
abstract: US and Mexican law enforcement officials arrest Jose Paoletti Moreda and his son, Renato, in Mexico City and charge them with leading operation that smuggled dozens of deaf Mexicans across border and forced them to live in virtual slavery by peddling trinkets in New York City, Los Angeles and Chicago (M)

headline: Charges Detailed in Case of Mexican Peddlers
abstract: Law enforcement officials in Mexico City and Washington begin preparing criminal charges against two men arrested and accused of smuggling dozens of deaf Mexican immigrants into United States and forcing them to sell trinkets in New York and other cities; Mexican officials say they plan to charge Renato Paoletti Lemus and his father, Jose Paoletti Moreda, with organized crime; photos (M)

headline: Deaf Immigrant, Once Classified As a Victim, Is Now a Suspect
abstract: Federal authorities, in complaint filed in Federal District Court, Brooklyn, accuse Juan Contreras Rauda of helping to smuggle deaf immigrants from Mexico, shuttling them from Chicago to New York City; say he collected their earnings at end of each day and beat them if they did not bring back enough money (M)

headline: Arrest in Dallas Widens Inquiry Into Immigrant Smuggling
abstract: Victor and Maria Estela Cervantes of Dallas, Tex, have been arrested for harboring and transporting deaf Mexican immigrants, and Government agents say they are trying to determine whether their case is connected to scores of deaf Mexicans who were found living in virtual slavery in New York City last month; in court papers, one Federal agent says that one deaf Mexican reported that other Mexican immigrants were auctioned off to bosses who then forced them to peddle trinkets (L)

headline: U.S. Indictment Describes Abuses Of Deaf Mexican Trinket Sellers
abstract: Federal indictment paints most complete picture yet of what prosecutors say was cross-country operation to force deaf Mexican immigrants to sell $1 trinkets, including disclosures that ringleaders used electric shocks on one peddler who did not sell enough trinkets, slammed another's head against a wall and chained third to bed for week; operation's techniques are described in indictment against 20 people; prosecutors estimate that ring earned $1 million a year over five years; indictment is significant because it seems to indicate that operation, which prosecutors say was run by extended clan of deaf people from Mexico City, was not as widespread as initially feared when it was uncovered in Queens in July; ring appears to have been limited to New York City and Chicago, with separate group in Los Angeles of people who smuggled deaf immigrants into US; indictment says Paoletti family, which ran NYC operation, forced peddlers to take day trips out of town to work; photo (M)

headline: Deaf Woman Wins Suit Against Two Hospitals
abstract: Federal jury awards Susan Lamonica, elderly deaf woman, total of $250,000 from North Shore University Hospital and Southside Hospital because it failed to provide her with sign-language interpreter while she was hospitalized for bypass surgery and rehabilitation (S)

headline: 'Pictures' Bring Books Alive for the Blind
abstract: Article on not-for-profit Creative Adaptations for Learning of Great Neck, NY, which develops illustrated educational material for children and adults who are blind or visually impaired; photo (M)

headline: In School for Deaf, America's Promise to Immigrants Is Kept
abstract: Article describes services available to legal deaf immigrants at Lexington Center and School for Deaf in Jackson Heights, NYC; photo (M)

headline: 2 Indicted in N. Carolina in Deaf Immigrant Case
abstract: Federal grand jury indicts deaf Mexican immigrants Marcos Campos Sanchez and his wife Guadalupe Palencia Moises on charges of running operation in North Carolina similar to one uncovered in July in New York City, and forcing other deaf immigrants to sell cheap trinkets for virtually no wages; investigators say they believe operations in North Carolina in New York are separate (M)

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of August 24 picture caption accompanying article about educational materials for blind (S)

headline: Some Fear That Fleets of Watchers May Harm Mammals
abstract: Researchers say noise from whale-watching boats could be damaging whales' hearing; Peter M Scheifele, bioacoustic researcher at University of Connecticut, says 'deaf whale is a dead whale'; Scheifele and researchers from several institutions are planning project to determine effect of underwater noise created by engine-driven vessels on whales; National Marine Fisheries Service has set guidelines recommending that boats stay at least 100 yards from whales; map; photo (M)

headline: This Justice Is Blind but He's a Great Listener
abstract: Profile of Civil Court Judge Peter J O'Donoghue of Queens, NYC's only blind judge and one of only 13 nationwide; photo (M)

headline: Bridge
abstract: Bridge column on Michael Levinson, former Life Master Men's Pair Champion, who continues to play despite being nearly blind; diagram (M)

headline: A Chief Banker for Nations At the Bottom of the Heap
abstract: Article on World Bank president James D Wolfensohn; says Wolfensohn wants the bank to be known for programs like one that is eradicating river blindness, which afflicts millions of Africans, not simply for dams and highways that were long World Bank's signature projects; Wolfensohn comments; map; photos (L)

headline: Representative Plans Bill To Aid Deaf Immigrants
abstract: Rep Nydia M Velazquez will introduce legislation to temporarily bar deportation of deaf Mexican immigrants who were found living in virtual servitude in Queens in July (S)

headline: Metro Business; Suite for the Blind to Open
abstract: Hotel Delmonico on Sept 17 will open new suite for people who are blind or visually impaired (S)

headline: Device Opens the Theater to the Deaf
abstract: Theater Development Fund's Theater Access Project will offer caption screen for playgoers with hearing loss for first time at performance of Barrymore; will use captioning when it takes school groups and others to performance of other plays; photo (S)

headline: Couple Plead Guilty To Smuggling Immigrants
abstract: Marcos Campos-Sanchez and his wife, Guadalupe Palencia-Moises, deaf illegal immigrants, plead guilty to conspiring to smuggle other deaf Mexicans into United States to peddle trinkets in Sanford, NC, Federal court (S)

headline: Connecticut Q&A: Tommy Edison; On the Air About Traffic, and Blind
abstract: Excerpts from conversation with Tommy Edison, radio traffic reporter in Bridgeport, Conn, who is blind; photo (M)

headline: Guiding Eyes for the Blind Is Sponsoring a Walkathon
abstract: Guiding Eyes for Blind in Yorktown Heights, NY, which breeds, trains and provides free guide dogs nationwide, schedules annual fund-raising walkathon for October 12 (S)

headline: White House Misses on Children and Health Care
abstract: Billie M Spaight letter asks if Pres Clinton will rethink his opposition to including hearing aids and testing in health care plans, now that he has had to buy hearing aid himself (S)

headline: Suspect in Peddling Ring Is Said to Aid Prosecution
abstract: Frank Coenen, one of suspects charged with holding deaf Mexicans in servitude and forcing them to sell trinkets, pleads guilty to involvement in conspiracy; Federal Judge Nina Gershon indicates that he is cooperating with prosecutors; Coenen, who is deaf, is former husband of Adriana Paoletti Lemus, member of family of deaf Mexicans that investigators say organized and ran operation; he is one of 20 people who have been indicted in case, which is centered in New York City but has included operations in Chicago and Los Angeles (M)

headline: Two Plead Guilty in Case Involving Deaf Mexicans
abstract: Raul Alanis and Alfredo Rustrian Paoletti, two of 20 people charged with holding deaf Mexicans in servitude in Queens and Chicago, plead guilty to criminal conspiracy in plea bargains in which other charges against them are to be dismissed (S)

headline: Deaf, Not Disabled
abstract: Interview, conducted in writing, with Margie Glendenning, Atlantic City native who is deaf and has worked for Trump Casino Services since 1988; she comments on upcoming performance of Gallaudet Dance Company at Trump Plaza, Atlantic City; photo (M)

headline: Deaf Peddlers Were Tortured With Stun Guns, Enforcer Says
abstract: Brother and sister, said by officials to be leaders of ring that forced deaf Mexican immigrants to peddle trinkets in subways and streets, used electric stun gun to torture some who did not sell enough or who tried to escape; account comes from deaf Mexican immigrant who admits to being a ring enforcer himself (S)

headline: 'Peer Gynt,' With Sound and Without
abstract: National Theater of Deaf presents New York premiere of Peer Gynt at Kaye Playhouse, Hunter College; production tells well-known tale in fusion of sign language, voice and physical movement; photo; Anna Kisselgoff review (M)

headline: Deaf Students Face Lack of Interpreters
abstract: Article discusses case of Ruth Farias, deaf teen-ager who came to United States from Mexico seeking a better education; her family contends that New York City schools are inadequate in providing interpreters for her daughter and other hearing impaired students as dictated by Federal Government; school officials have decided to send Ruth Farias temporarily to New York School for the Deaf; photo (M)

headline: To Speak to the Deaf
abstract: Judy Cohen letter contends that shortage of sign language interpreters affects not only students but also businesses that want to accommodate deaf employees and others who want to see deaf people participate in their activities and use their products and services

headline: Slowed by the Weather
abstract: Results for several marathoners profiled by Times; Abraham Weintraub, 87, finishes with time of 6:26:05; Dana Andrew Jennings finishes in 6:19:56; Allison Bloom finishes in 4:50 and Jillian Walker, blind runner guided by another runner, crosses line in 3:49:58 (S)

headline: Opening of Guide Dog School Is Delayed
abstract: Zoning dispute with officials of Old Westbury, New York, delays opening of Praise Guide Dog Center and Mobility School for Blind Children; zoning board does not recognize center as school, and refuses to approve site (S)

headline: Discovery of Gene Offers Clues on Deafness
abstract: Large extended family in Cartago, Costa Rica, has strange and incurable form of genetically caused deafness; children born into family have 50 percent chance of becoming deaf; scientists have traced cause of family's affliction to previously unknown gene, which helps operate delicate hair cells in ear that respond to sound vibrations (M)

headline: Woman Pleads Guilty in Case Of Deaf Mexican Peddlers
abstract: Rosa Maria Beltran Sanchez, who prosecutors say helped lead Queens branch of operation that forced deaf Mexican immigrants to peddle trinkets in subways, pleads guilty to conspiring to violate constitutional ban on slavery; Norma Alcantara, who authorities say was leader in Chicago branch of ring, refuses to enter guilty plea (M)

headline: A Map for the Blind
abstract: Steven Landau letter reports that New York City Transit Authority has commissioned computer-generated raised-line and textured maps for use by the blind

headline: Doctors for the Deaf
abstract: Letter from Joan F Peters says Nov 23 article on language barriers that hinder health care did not mention communication barriers suffered by people who are deaf; many medical facilities do not have sign language interpreter available, even though they are required to under Americans with Disabilities Act (S)

headline: Fee Threatens Blind Newsdealers
abstract: New city law sharply raising license fees could put many of New York's sidewalk newsstands out of business, and will hit already dwindling number of blind newsdealers particularly hard; photo (S)

headline: Guilty Plea in Smuggling of Immigrants
abstract: 29-year-old Adriana Paoletti Lemus, who is deaf and communicates through sign language, pleads guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to charges that she conspired to bring dozens of deaf Mexicans to United States to be part of what amounted to lucrative, often brutal slavery ring selling trinkets in streets and subways of New York City, Philadelphia, Chicago, Boston, Baltimore and Washington; also acknowledges laundering money, and trying to intimidate victims into not telling truth to investigators (M)

headline: Signs for the Hearing, Lessons From the Deaf
abstract: American Sign Language course for the deaf and hearing is offered at University of Connecticut at Storrs; photos (L)

headline: MR. SNAFOO
abstract: National Federation for the Blind protests that Mr Magoo, a new Walt Disney film, perpetuates idea that lack of sight means incompetent (S)

headline: Passing as a Person Who Can See
abstract: Michiko Kakutani reviews Stephen Kuusisto's Planet of the Blind, memoir of coming to terms with being blind and beginning new life at age 39 with seeing-eye dog; photo (M)

headline: On Drinking and Health
abstract: Letter by John W Corwin of Glaucoma Foundation says older people who want to keep on driving should have regular eye exams; warns that glaucoma, world's leading cause of preventable blindness, has no early symptoms (S)

headline: Seeing What Really Matters; Weak Eyes but a Strong Will Put Wall St. in Perspective
abstract: Profile of and interview with Paul Karos, who has been afflicted with degenerative eye disease called retinitis pigmentosa; disease has slowly robbed him of his sight, but he has compensated through hard work to become a success; he is presently head of institutional sales at Piper Jaffray, securities brokerage firm in Minneapolis; comments on challenges of dealing with retinitis pigmentosa, stressing difficulty of adapting to a certain level of lost vision, only to have one's sight worsen; photo; chart shows percentages of Americans with various disabilities who are able to work (M)

headline: The Neediest Cases; Their Joy Louder Than Silence, Deaf Children Frolic at Center
abstract: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund appeal; describes how nine-year-old Joella Bailey, who was born deaf, receives special programs at Rhinelander Center, which is run by Children's Aid Society, one of seven charities supported by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund (M)'

headline: Blind Newsdealer Could Use Training for Wider World
abstract: Letter by Betty Bird of The Lighthouse discusses other work options for Jose Rivera, blind newsdealer profiled Dec 14 (1997)

headline: On Sign Language In Public Schools
abstract: Letter by Bruce and Rosine Mims on Dec 21, 1997 article on American Sign Language course for deaf and hearing offered at University of Connecticut at Storrs (S)

headline: Were the Guns Too Loud? Irish Soldiers Take Issue to Court
abstract: Approximately 3,000 Irish soldiers are locked in dispute with Government, claiming that they should be compensated for hearing loss; say hearing has been impaired by boom of cannons, albeit during practice, and by stutter of automatic weapons fire; Government says most of claimants are malingerers, who have hired smart lawyers (M)

headline: Separate Jobs for Blind Spur a Spirited Debate
abstract: Article discusses debate over whether blind are better served by jobs that are tailored for them or by mainstream employment; various opinions discussed; photo (M)

headline: Look and, Yes, Touch
abstract: Christopher Roule's jewelry designs are inscribed in Braille; photo (S)

headline: A Fool for a Client? Take a Closer Look
abstract: Joe Sharkey column on Leila Laufer, who is blind and acting as her own attorney in effort to overturn 1995 court decision that dismissed medical malpractice claim she filed against her former lawyers; Laufer claimed her blindness resulted from improper medical treatment for Lyme disease and says her lawyers failed to adequately seek redress (M)

headline: Blind Man Charged In a Rape Case
abstract: Norris Burton, blind Harlem beggar, is arrested afer homeless woman who was staying in his apartment accuses him of raping her and stabbing her with scissors (S)

headline: Darkness at Home for Blind
abstract: Selis Manor, a residence for the blind in Chelsea section of Manhattan financed by Housing and Urban Development Department, faces possible loss of social and recreational services long provided by the nonprofit Associated Blind Inc; photo (S)

headline: At Westminster, Picking Among the Pack
abstract: Dr M Josephine Deubler, 80-year-old hearing impaired veterinary professor, will make Best in Show selection at upcoming Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Madison Square Garden; photo (M)

headline: Q&A/Michael Amoruso; Disabled Lawyer Chisels Away at Limits
abstract: Interview with Michael Amoruso on working as lawyer despite being hearing and sight impaired; he cites aid he got from Lighthouse in assessing his needs and helping him find job; photo (M)

headline: New York to Teach Deaf in Sign Language, Then English
abstract: New York City Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, in what is being hailed as landmark change in education of deaf students, says Junior High School 47 in lower Manhattan, city's only public school for deaf, will be overhauled so that all teachers will teach primarily in sign language based on symbols and gestures, rather than English-like sign language based on sounds, or other methods like lip reading and pointing; photo (M)

headline: Closed-Captioning Opposed for 'Springer'
abstract: Sens Daniel R Coats and Joseph I Lieberman, who are known for crusading against what they call trash television, are urging Secretary of Education to stop using Federal money to underwrite closed-captioning on The Jerry Springer Show, which they describe as closest thing to pornography on broadcast television (S)

headline: Educating the Deaf
abstract: Kim Sweet/Barry Schuindler letter comments on March 5 article on special education for deaf students in New York City (S)

headline: Teach English to Deaf
abstract: John K Duffy letter deplores abandonment of English for American Sign Language at New York City's only public school for the deaf (S)

headline: Sign Language for Deaf
abstract: Leila Monaghan letter disputes John K Duffy March 10 letter opposing introduction of American Sign Language at New York City public school for deaf

headline: Sign Language: It's the Talk of the Town
abstract: Photos of Pat Massey's classes in sign language, in Teaneck, New Jersey

headline: To a Boss, Disability Is No Barrier
abstract: Priscilla Daniels, head of volunteer services at Bellevue Hospital in New York, says she is glad to have Sharada Veerubhotla, who is blind, and her guide dog working in program; photo (S)

headline: Teachers Reject Bilingual Education; Each Student's Needs
abstract: Laurie E Kraus letter advocates 'total communication' approach to teaching the deaf, which incorporates English, Sign Language, speech reading and residual hearing (S)

headline: Teachers Reject Bilingual Education; What's Best for Deaf?
abstract: Maria Zachmanoglou letter says adoption of American Sign Language by Junior High School 47 in New York is unfair to children from Spanish-speaking countries who speak only Spanish or can speech-read Spanish (S)

headline: Out of Servitude, Deaf Mexicans Languish in Limbo of Motel
abstract: Forty-eight deaf Mexican men and women, along with their 11 children, are still being held by Immigration and Naturalization Service in a New York City motel eight months after they went to police to seek relief from bosses who had smuggled them into US and kept them in virtual slavery; INS is not expected to rule on whether they can stay in US until sentencing hearing is completed for the 18 people who have pleaded guilty in case (M)

headline: Making the Web Speak
abstract: Phil Hall letter comments on Mar 26 article on making Web pages accessible to the blind; recommends Web Speak technology available from Productivity Works (S)

headline: 2 Sentenced in Mexican Peddling Ring
abstract: Federal District Judge Nina Gershon sentences Adriana Paoletti Lemus to 14 years in prison for being leader of ring that forced deaf Mexicans to peddle trinkets in New York City; sentences her mother, Delia Paoletti Lemus Ruiz, to five years in prison and orders both of them to pay $1.5 million in restitution to about 50 of exploited workers (M)

headline: Families Joined or Divided by Silence; Film Shed Light on Emotional Issues of the Deaf
abstract: Interviews with director Caroline Link and deaf actors Howie Seago and Emmanuelle Laborit on highly charged issues in deaf culture addressed in film Beyond Silence; photos (M)

headline: Family Communication
abstract: Lila W Miller letter on June 11 article holds hearing children of deaf parents need both oral and sign communication

headline: Sips; Labels for Rhone Wines Communicate in Braille
abstract: Michael Chapoutier, well-known vintner of Rhone Valley wines, has put Braille labels on all premium wines; photo (S)

headline: Blind Golfers' Tournaments Increase
abstract: Article on US Blind Golfers Association circuit notes that Keith Melick won recent Ken Venturi Guilding Eyes Classic at Mount Kisco Country Club; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Permits Deaf Mexicans, Forced to Peddle, to Remain
abstract: Federal officials say 49 deaf Mexican men and women whose ordeal as virtual slaves shocked New York last year, will be allowed to stay in United States; illegal immigrants were forced to peddle trinkets in subways and turn over their earnings to bosses who beat and abused them; they will be permitted to remain because of their help in convicting their tormentors; Federal criminal case against men and women who victimized them ends with sentencing of last of 18 bosses; Mike Wishnie, lawyer with American Civil Liberties Union who represents detainees, says several non-profit organizations are willing to pay for whatever training they need to become self-sufficient; photo (M)

headline: Feel the Burn, Don't Hear It
abstract: Erlinda McGinty of North Quincy, Mass, fearing that ear-splitting music accompanying aerobics sessions at her health club was damaging her hearing, persuaded her state senator to file legislation requiring health clubs in state to post warnings about dangers of exposure to loud music and provide earplugs if volume exceeds 90 decibels; most gym owners feel she has protested too much but audiologists say she has called attention to widespread hidden health menace (Sepcial Section: Women's Health) (S)

headline: A Taxi Rider and Her Personal Commissioner
abstract: RoseMarie McCaffrey, advocate for blind, is credited with forcing installation of plaques, in Braille, identifying NYC taxi drivers and giving phone number for complaints; photo (M)

headline: Patents; An inventor says a bracelet with a computer chip embedded in it could help cut crime rates.
abstract: Stephen Heiser patents tracking technology that uses computer chip embedded in bracelet to enable authorities to constantly monitor location of paroled felon; radio signals relayed every 30 seconds to central computer would identify parole violations and presence of felons at crime scenes; Dr Patricia Bowling patents contact lens that focuses and intensifies light on remaining retinal rod and cone cells of people suffering from retinal diseases to improve their vision; 125th anniversary of writer Mark Twain patenting self-pasting scrapbook recalled (M)

headline: Once Held in Servitude, 13 Mexicans Go Home
abstract: 13 deaf Mexican men and women, along with four babies born to them while they were in US, return to Mexico for first time since they were discovered living in virtual slavery year ago; say they decided to return to Mexico because of brutal way they were treated by leaders of smuggling operation who forced them to sell trinkets in New York City subways; officials say there are still 35 deaf adults and six children remaining in New York, as well as two more adults who will leave shortly; photo (M)

headline: Enslaved Deaf Mexicans Tell of Life in City Shadows
abstract: Plight of dozens of deaf Mexicans who were smuggled into US and put to work selling trinkets in subways and airports of New York and other cities became public year ago; their tale of abuse and enslavement shocked city and attracted national attention; several of immigrants, in interviews conducted with help of sign-language interpreters, say they lived in crowded houses and were watched by abusive bosses who punished them if they did not make enough money; Mexican workers have been kept by Immigration and Naturalization Service in Astoria, Queens, motel; 35 have asked for permission to stay in US, and 14 have voluntarily returned to Mexico; 18 of their bosses have pleaded guilty and have been sentenced to prison or deported to Mexico (M)

headline: For Deaf Mexicans, Freedom After Slavery and Detention
abstract: Thirty-seven deaf Mexicans and their six children are set to be freed from hotel in Queens where they have been detained since they were discovered a year ago living as virtual slaves to the people who brought them illegally into US; they will move to a city shelter, have right to work and receive special visas granted to people who make significant contributions to criminal cases; city will provide for their training and education (M)

headline: For the Blind, a Camp Leader Who Can Relate
abstract: Article on activities at Camp Helen Keller, camp for blind children on SUNY's Farmingdale, NY, campus, and its first blind counselor, Elizabeth Wurzer; photo (M)

headline: Garden Notebook; A Braille of Buds, Stems and Flowers
abstract: Remarkable garden in Shelter Island, NY, is work of William Price, 84, who has been blind for 50 years; despite his disability Price gardens every day, raising plants from seed, laying out rows, planting, weeding, watering and picking vegetables and flowers in his 45-by-50 foot plot; photos (M)

headline: Police Shoot Man Holding Machete; Family Says They Broke In Like Robbers
abstract: Police shoot and seriously wound Watson Chin Young, legally blind 65-year-old man who allegedly wielded machete as they searched for guns and explosives in Staten Island apartment of his son, Leighton Chin Young; police later find AK-47 rifle, ammunition and handgun (M)

headline: F.D.A. Approves a Drug That Blocks a Gene
abstract: Isis Pharmaceuticals Inc says it received approval from Food and Drug Administration for its drug, fomivirsen, for treatment of CMV retinitis, virus that can cause blindness in AIDS patients; it will be made by Isis and marketed as Vitravene By Ciba Vision Corp; Vitravene is based on technology known as antisense, which holds great promise for harnessing genetic information to make potent drugs with few side effects; it is first drug that works by blocking action of gene (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Aug 16 article on Camp Helen Keller, summer program for blind children in East Farmingdale, LI

headline: Applause For Paper Mill
abstract: New Jersey Division of Deaf and Hard of Hearing advisory council member Arlene Romoff letter on September 20 article on Paper Mill Playhouse; notes its commitment to provide full access to people with hearing loss (S)

headline: Another Round in Blind Tenants' Fight for Services
abstract: Blind tenants at Selis Manor, NYC, stage rally and file lawsuit in effort to keep social service staff members at the home (M)

headline: The View From/Yorktown; When a Dog Is Not a Pet But a Partner in Life
abstract: Sighted and blind people attend Guiding Eyes for the Blind fund-raising walkathon at Franklin Delano Roosevelt State Park in Yorktown, NY; photos (M)

headline: Seeing the Vacuum Roar
abstract: Jenna Fischtrom Beacom letter on Oct 13 article on placebos; describes how she relates placebo effect to her deafness

headline: A Therapeutic Twist For the Game of Golf
abstract: Article on Gaylord Golf Club, group of disabled golfers who play golf every other Monday during season at Farms Country Club in Wallingford, Conn; photos (M)

headline: F.Y.I.
abstract: FYI column answers questions on reason for pictograms mounted above NYC intersection that spell out School for the Deaf in sign language, route of New York to Paris auto race and location of old US Assay Office; photo (M)

headline: Effort to Halt Blinding Disease Worldwide With Single-Dose Drug
abstract: Pfizer Inc, which makes long-acting antibiotic that can effectively treat trachoma, leading cause of preventable blindness worldwide, with single dose once a year, and Edna McConnell Clark Foundation begin $66 million program to eliminate disease in Ghana, Mali, Morocco, Tanzania and Vietnam; help implement World Health Organization strategy to end disease as major cause of blindness by 2020; Pfizer says it will donate enough of antibiotic azithromycin, called Zithromax, to treat three million people over next two years at cost of about $60 million; Clark will pay added $6.5 million (M)

headline: The View From/Mount Kisco; On the Road Again: Putting a Price on a '68 Dream Machine
abstract: Joe DeFrancisco of Mount Kisco, NY, who lost sight to diabetes eight years ago, is conducting essay contest whose prize is his 1968 royal blue Mustang convertible; photo (M)

headline: After Tragedies, Some People Rise Up to Find Their Calling
abstract: Profiles of Long Islanders who have risen above their afflictions and diseases to help other Long Island residents: Mitchel Shapiro, who is legally blind and severely hearing impaired, gives speeches about Foundation Fighting Blindness; Celia and Marvin Strow, whose daughter was killed by drunken driver, started Mothers Against Drunk Drivers chapter; Jill and Stuart Gleiber, whose son survived car crash with severe head injuries, who helped form Long Island Head Injury Assn; AID S patients Louis Wiese and Lisa Landi give speeches to AIDS educators; Geri Barish, breast cancer survivor and Long Island breast cancer research advocate; photos (Special Best of Long Island Issue) (L)

headline: Gene Identified as Major Cause of Deafness in Ashkenazi Jews
abstract: Scientists have identified gene that is major cause of inherited deafness among Ashkenazi Jews, group that includes 90 percent of six million Jewish people in US; study was conducted by scientists from National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders, Louisiana State University, Michigan State University, University of Antwerp and New York University (M)

headline: The Neediest Cases; For Holiday, Deaf Teen-Agers Share Cooking and a Table
abstract: Work of New York Times Neediest Cases Fund during holidays discussed; Thanksgiving party for Rhinelander Children's Center's Program for Deaf and Hard of Hearing Teenagers discussed; photo (M)

headline: Roman Roost for the Rich and Famous
abstract: Geraldine Fabrikant article on Rome's Hassler Hotel, sitting famously at top of Spanish Steps for 120 years; hotel of choice for international celebrities is now run by Roberto Wirth, who overcame limitations of deafness to take over family business; photos; map (M)

headline: Web Access for the Blind
abstract: Bob Brummond runs one of about 150 services in United States which allows blind listeners who own specialized radio receiver to listen to newspapers and magazines being read and to hear exercise programs; if they have computer with Internet capability, screen reader and speech synthesizer, they can also listen to news off Web page Brummond set up; photo (M)

headline: Blind Piano Teacher Goes Beyond Routine
abstract: Interview with Sharin Duffy, blind pianist and composer who teaches piano at All for Arts center, Bedford, NY; photo (M)1

headline: Dogged Pursuits
abstract: New York City police officer use 'sting' team to go after taxicab drivers who refuse to pick up blind people and their dogs (S)

headline: Media Talk; Writer Finds No Room at the Library
abstract: Ved Mehta, prolific author and recipient of MacArthur grant and two Guggenheim fellowships, says he will sue New York Public Library for discrimination if it does not provide him with one of 15 private rooms being created as part of library's renovation; Mehta is blind; Carolina Oyama, manager of public relations for library, says private rooms are open only to scholars who apply for specific study projects and are not intended as long-term private offices; photo (S)

headline: Internet for the Blind
abstract: Blind students throughout nation can study via Internet, and at reduced cost, through Purdue University service that lets them or their institutions download scientific and mathematical images, print them on special paper and feed them through machine that raises lines and dots to form images and Braille characters; photo (M)

headline: Technology for Blind Users Even Reads the Internet Ads
abstract: IBM Corp begins selling technology that allows blind users to hear the World Wide Web; software, Home Page Reader, which costs $149, uses a speech synthesizer not just to read the text on a given Web page but also to describe graphics and advertisements (S)

headline: The View From/Yonkers; Priest Pushes His World Beyond One of Silence
abstract: Article on Rev Thomas Coughlin, Catholist priest who is deaf and recently opened House of Studies for Deaf Seminarians in Yonkers, NY; photos (M)

headline: Horowitz Gift

headline: A Tight Little Island In the World of Deafness
abstract: To many people it's an unexpected viewpoint. ''When all three of my children were born deaf, too,'' says Peter Artinian early in the film ''Sound and Fury,'' ''I thought, 'Great.' '' And he is not being ironic.    A documentary about cochlear implants, the relatively new devices that allow many deaf people to hear, may not sound like anyone's idea of compelling filmmaking, but Josh Aronson's ''Sound and Fury'' -- which follows two branches of a Long Island family through the decision-making process about the implant's use -- is powerful, insightful, important and emotionally wrenching.
