abstract: Profile of Harvey J Corson, who is deaf, and who has been chosen from field of 11 candidates as new director of American School for the Deaf in Hartford, Conn; photo (M)

headline: Gains From Hearing Tests Are Disputed
abstract: New study finds little evidence that detecting deafness in newborns helps with child's later language skills; calls into question value of requirement in 30 states that hospitals test newborns for hearing problems (M)

headline: CLASS-ACTION STATUS IS GRANTED IN U.P.S. BIAS SUIT
abstract: Federal Judge Thelton E Henderson, grants class-action status to discrimination suit against United Parcel Service Inc by five hearing-impaired workers (S)

headline: A Struggle to Keep Up For TV Caption Writers
abstract: Errors in real-time on-screen television captioning increased noticeably after Sept 11 terrorist attacks as stenographers race to keep up with high volume of live news evenets; Holli Miller, who transcribes from home in Des Moines, became hero to her company, National Captioning Institute, when she kept working for many hours without break on Sept 11; photo (M)

headline: FAMILY FARE
abstract: Roselle, Labrador retriever who safely led her blind master Michael Hingson down 77 flights of stairs in North Tower of World Trade Center on Sept 11, will be honored at Liberty Science Center in Jersey City; photo (M)

headline: Sands Point Center Introduces Deaf-Blind to a Wider World
abstract: Article describes some of activities and services offered at Helen Keller National Center for Deaf-Blind Youths and Adults in Sands Point, Long Island, which is celebrating its 25th anniversary; photos (M)

headline: Needless Silence for Hearing Impaired
abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on dealing with hearing loss, one of most prevalent chronic health conditions in United States; notes some 20 million people with serious hearing deficits fail to use hearing aids; quiz to help in recognizing hearing loss (M)d

headline: By Land and By Sea: All in a Day's Lesson
abstract: Article on Classroom of the Sea, innovative program developed by American School for the Deaf and University of Connecticut's National Undersea Research Center in Groton that stresses hands-on activities and teams students with marine scientists for work on real-life research projects; program's first live broadcast from research vessel off Long Island Sound, in which students tested water samples, described; photos (M)

headline: What They Were Thinking
abstract: Alain van den Broek and Marie Jeanne Ameels Planchon comment on Dec photo in which he was trying to familiarize her and another blind woman with new euro currency; photo (S)2

headline: When Botox Treatments Are Medically Necessary
abstract: Roxanne Kiefer Mollo letter on January 13 article notes real purpose for botox treatments is to treat blepharospasm, which results in blindness

headline: Learning to Navigate Where the Invisible Clues Have Changed
abstract: Article in series on workaday objects that resonate in unusual ways in aftermath of Sept 11 focuses on canes; describes problems of Eddie Montanez, blind man who used to walk streets around World Trade Center, finding them rich with invisible clues about where things stood, how people moved, when traffic surged; long before Sept 11, Montanez's cane served as antenna that sent and received messages; now it connects him to drastically changed city; photo (M)

headline: For Those With a Disability, The Word Made Digital
abstract: Bookshare.org, Web database that contains thousands of books, is designed for those with visual or reading disability; photo (M)

headline: From Top Teenage Scientists, Topics You've Never Heard Of
abstract: High school seniors from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut capture 4 of top 10 prizes in Intel Science Talent Search; top prize goes to Ryan Randall Patterson of Grand Junction, Colo, for his work on glove that converts American Sign Language to written text on portable display (M)

headline: Teacher's Aide Charged With Raping Student
abstract: Kathy Tuifel, 44-year-old teacher's aide at middle school in Hicksville, NY, is charged with raping blind 11-year-old student she tutored; case reviewed; photo (M)

headline: Dogs Helping People
abstract: Alice Laby letter on report (March 29) that seizure-alert dogs may get seeing-eye status in Florida; questions what it is in American culture that makes us suspicious of helper dogs

headline: Hong Kong Journal; Workplace Cacophony Leads to Compensation
abstract: Hong Kong Government will make employees of colony's many mahjongg parlors eligible for compensation for loss of hearing, suffered on job from incessant and noisy clatter of mahjongg tiles; workers will be able to draw from $250,000 fund that compensates people in 25 noisey occupations; photo (M)

headline: Gene Study Caught in Mideast Divide
abstract: Article on difficulties Israeli researcher Karen Avraham and Palestinian collaborator Moien Kanaan face in joint graduate program between Tel Aviv University and Bethlehem University of genetics of hearing loss; program, which has isolated three genes involved in deafness in its first four years, has been delayed indefinitely by political turmoil; photos (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Blind Audience Is Aided By Audio Technology
abstract: Major television networks have rolled out video description technology for blind on which narrator describes program action on secondary audio channel during pauses in dialogue; Federal Communications Commission rules require network-affiliated broadcasters in top markets to begin providing service some four hours a week; Fox was first to comply, adding description to The Simpsons; photo (M)

headline: Terminal Phones
abstract: Joseph Grigely letter on March 10 article notes lack of phones for hearing-impaired people in new terminal at Detroit Metro Airport; Wayne County Airports director Lester W Robinson responds

headline: Ideas & Trends: Written Notice; Another Language for the Deaf
abstract: System of graphic symbols based on dance notation is being used to create written version of American Sign Language used by the deaf; Valerie Sutton, creator of SignWriting, comments; photos; diagrams (M)

headline: National Briefing | West: California: Disabled Sue San Francisco Airport
abstract: Disability Rights Advocates and California Center for Law and the Deaf file class-action lawsuit charging that San Francisco Airport fails to meet needs of the deaf and hard of hearing (S)

headline: Girl, 9, Dies From Injuries In 4-Story Fall
abstract: Unidentified deaf and blind 9-year-old girl dies after plunging four stories from window of Chicago apartment where police said she had been left home alone, tied to bathroom radiator; police question mother and her boyfriend (S)

headline: New Economy; Eye-popping graphics can spice up Web sites, but they also create barriers.
abstract: Web designer Sarah Horton article admits fancy graphics and page designs are often barriers between people and information they seek; notes graphic text used for navigation links cannot be read by screen-reader software to blind or enlarged by people who need large type; notes video provided without captions or text transcript is not accessible to blind or deaf; proposes sites design in features that accommodate all users; drawing (M)

headline: For a Scout on a Mission, a Good Deed Blossoms
abstract: Article on sensory garden outside state Library for the Blind and Physically Handicapped in Rocky Hill, Conn; teenager Jimmy Dosset developed idea and solicited monetary, plant and other donations in order to earn his Eagle Scout rank; photos (M)

headline: Technology Eases the Way for the Visually Impaired
abstract: Dozens of students gather at retirement party in Queens honoring their middle school teacher, Betty Salz, who has taught blind students in New York City for more than 40 years; they remark on how personal data assistants, word processing and Internet have altered ways blind students do schoolwork (M)

headline: An International Gathering For the Deaf in the Arts
abstract: Gallaudet University sponsors Deaf Way II, week-long Washington, DC convention on issues confronting the deaf in all creative fields; actor-playwright Willy Conley is one of 400 artists whose works are featured; sign-language productions explained; photos (M)

headline: Defying Hardships, British Minister Is in Spotlight
abstract: British government's 'two-man' show of Prime Min Tony Blair and his strong-willed treasurer Gordon Brown has been joined by Home Sec David Blunkett, who generates speculation that he, not Brown, could succeed Blair; remarkable element is that Blunkett, 55, is blind, which he refers to as 'an inconvenience, not a disability'; photo with his guide-dog, Lucy (M)

headline: Making Theater Accessible to People With Trouble Hearing
abstract: Mervyn Rothstein discusses special open-captioned performance of musical The Music Man sponsored by Theater Access Project of Theater Development Fund; photo (M)

headline: Subway Announcements
abstract: Letter from Joseph Gordon (Self-Help for Hard of Hearing People) on July 19 article calls for captioned announcements on subway cars

headline: Drug Agency Is Studying Ear Implants' Links to Meningitis
abstract: Food and Drug Administration probes apparent increase in meningitis among deaf patients who have had cochlear implants surgically inserted in their ears to help them hear; reports there have been about 25 confirmed cases of meningitis worldwide, 9 of them fatal, among people with implants in last 18 years; recently advised those with implants to weigh being vaccinated against bacteria that can cause disease; says Advanced Bionics Corp, which removed one of its models from some markets abroad after concerns were raised about possible link is now discussing with FDA whether to do so in United States; diagram (M)

headline: Goo Goo in Sign Language? Gestures Are Now Baby Talk
abstract: Lora Heller's Baby Fingers class on Manhattan's Upper West Side is one of handful in area teaching parents and infants as young as 6 months to use rudimentary elements of sign language to hearing babies; some experts believe babies who use signs may get head start in learning, not to mention enhanced interactions with their parents; study by Profs Linda P Acredolo and Susan W Goodwyn shows that second graders who learned signs as babies had intelligence-test scores that were, on average, 12 points higher than those who did not; others look at baby signs as little more than pediatric equivalent of stupid-pet tricks; photo (M)

headline: For a Blind Sailor, It's All About the Wind
abstract: Blind daysailer Matt Chao uses wind to guide him through races like Sail Newport Blind National Championship Regatta and World Blind Sailing Championships (M)

headline: New Drugs Show Signs of Helping Vision Problem for Elderly
abstract: Scientists attending Retina Congress 2002 in San Francisco say experimental drugs show preliminary signs of improving eyesight in elderly people who suffer from macular degeneration; in 64-patient trial, 26 percent of patients treated with one drug, rhuFab V2, had improved vision (S)

headline: Jarred by Noise, in So Many Ways
abstract: Jarred by Noise, in So Many Ways To the Editor:.

headline: Step-by-Step Prompts Put the Blind on Track
abstract: Interactive personal navigation system developed at University of Florida could someday guide blind people through corridors and along busy city sidewalks; communicates wirelessly with widely available databases of detailed geographic information that can quickly be updated to reflect changing conditions; began as master's thesis project for Steve Moore, computer science student; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Judge Rules On Web Sites For the Disabled
abstract: Federal Judge Patricia A Seitz rules Web sites do not have to be designed to provide easier access for blind; says Southwest.com, site of Southwest Airlines, is not 'place of public accommodation' covered under Americans with Disabilities Act; decision dismisses case brought by Access Now Inc, nonprofit advocacy group in Florida (S)

headline: Knicks Banking On Chaney This Season
abstract: Bicyclists will trail legally blind runner Marla Runyan in New York City Marathon, to audibly point out course hazards, water stations and her cumulative time; photos (M)

headline: Runyan Finds 'Fun' In Her First Marathon
abstract: Marla Runyan, who is legally blind, finishes fifth in her first New York City Marathon; photo (M)

headline: Court Says Broadcasters Don't Have to Offer Technology for Blind
abstract: Federal appeals court overturns Federal Communications Commission rules that would require broadcasters to adopt technology to let blind people follow action on television by listening to narrator describe physical movements; finds Congress did not authorize rules; Jack Valenti, president of Motion Picture Association of America, which challenged rules, says group and its member back video description on voluntary basis (M)

headline: Theater; In This Musical, Some Sing, All Sign
abstract: Deaf West Theater in Los Angeles performs musical Big River with integrated deaf and hearing actors, production now transferred to Mark Taper Forum; director Jeff Calhoun and producer Ed Waterstreet, who is deaf, discuss collaboration that melds music and sign language; photos (M)

headline: The Lighthouse Focuses On Donors New and Old
abstract: Lighthouse International undertakes aggressive aggressive strategy plan that relies on innovative tactics, such as splashy, three-day sale of donated designer clothes and formation of insider club for major donors; targets older givers as most sympathetic to problems with vision; photos (M) (Special sections, Giving)

headline: Even Blind People Can Draw
abstract: Review of year's notable ideas and developments comments on new understanding of how blind create realistic drawings of everyday objects; says emerging idea is that picture-making is cognitive ability so deeply embedded in our brain that it flourishes even when our eyes fail us; photo (M)

headline: Pfizer Agrees to Buy Rights To Drug to Treat Blindness
abstract: Pfizer Inc agrees to pay $100 million now and as much as $645 million later for rights to drug Macugen being developed by Eyetech Pharmaceuticals to treat age-related macular degeneration and diabetic macular edema (M)

headline: Morphing Subway Signs
abstract: Joseph Gordon letter says electronic signs in subway cars visually announcing stops are vital for deaf riders (Dec 12 article)

headline: Executive Life; Seeing Shadows, Deciphering Speech
abstract: Profile of Barry Honig, president of executive-search and consulting firm Honig International; Honig, who is blind, uses high-tech gadgets and has sharpened his other senses to navigate successfully in business world; photo (M)

headline: Inside Megan's World
abstract: Marek Fuchs County Lines column on Megan Stanger, 9, who, because of Charge syndrome, confluence of birth defects, has only slight peripheral vision and is deaf; drawing (M)

headline: Changing Assumptions
abstract: Letter from Carl J Augusto, president and chief exective of American Foundation for Blind, urges more employers to give blind or visually impaired people a chance to demonstrate their capabilities (Jan 26 article)

headline: Trial Begins in Bias Suit By Deaf U.P.S. Workers
abstract: Lawyers for 900 deaf workers at United Parcel Service argue in discrimination suit that company excluded them from numerous job categories and generally limited them to bottom-rung positions (S)

headline: Fire at a Russian School Kills 28 Deaf Boys
abstract: Fire at boarding school for deaf in Makhachkala in Russian republic of Dagestan kills 28 boys asleep and unable to hear frantic shouts of adults; at least 106 other boys are injured, 22 critically; this is second major school fire in four days, coming after blaze in Siberia that killed 22 children in gymnasium dressing room; latest disaster leaves average Russians stunned and enraged over perilous state of poorly maintained school buildings; map (M)

headline: Fire and Silence: Children's Terror in Russia
abstract: Fire at boarding school for the deaf in Makhachkala, Russia, kills 28 of its 166 students; 22 others are still in intensive care; one child uses gestures to describe his escape; Russians are stunned by fire, which comes less than week after fire kills 22 schoolchildren in wooden schoolhouse in remote Siberian village; photos; map (M)

headline: A Braille Phone Organizer Connects the Dots and the User
abstract: Alva Mobile Phone Organizer is set to introduce combination cellphone, note-taker and wireless Internet device with eight-button Braille keybord; photo (M)

headline: Qwerty for the Blind
abstract: Sarah Van Oosterwijck letter contends keyboard type is matter of personal preference for blind people, but that output is most important

headline: Countering The Darkness
abstract: Nasir A Ali describes development of LaserCane, cane for the blind that uses three laser beams to detect dangers that conventional canes cannot, such as tree branches or dropoff from subway platform; photo (M)

headline: At Their Fingertips, Tabletop Gardens
abstract: Article on horticultural recreation program at Guild Home for the Aged Blind in Yonkers, NY; participants and therapists comment; photo (M)

headline: Saudi Arabia Awakes to the Perils of Inbreeding
abstract: Several serious genetic disorders are common in Saudia Arabia, where women have average of six children, and marriage between close relatives is common; Saudi government says rate of marriage among blood relatives, particularly in south of country, ranges from 55 to 70 percent, among highest rates in world; Saudi public health officials say this widespread inbreeding has produced several genetic disorders, some of them potentially fatal; one Saudi researcher has found links between inbreeding and deafness and muteness; Saudi health authorities have quietly debated what to do for decades; now, for first time, government has started nationwide campaign to inform related couples who intend to marry of risk of genetic disease; it plans to require mandatory blood tests before marriage and pre-marital counseling; tradition of marrying relatives is deeply embedded in Saudi culture, although among more educated Saudis it has become less common; photos (M)

headline: Changing Cues For Copiers
abstract: Responsible Party article on Bill Loughlin, who led development of new Xerox software that helps blind and visually impaired use copiers; text-to-speech software that 'reads' what is on copier touch screen to user is embedded in PC attached to copier; photos (M)

headline: Four Men Rape Deaf Woman In Brooklyn
abstract: Brooklyn woman who is deaf and mute is dragged to empty apartment building in East New York and raped by four men (S)

headline: Senator Clinton Addresses Students at Pace
abstract: Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton addresses graduating seniors at Pace University's Westchester campus, Pleasantville; photo of Nicholas M Esposito, who became blind while attending college and still graduated with honors (M)

headline: Making History: A Black Man's Hands Speak Eloquently
abstract: ROCHESTER, May 24  When Brian Jenerson was a child, he was fascinated by the way his grandmother communicated through sign language. She had lost much of her hearing as a child and taught her family how to use their hands in place of their voices.

headline: It Takes a Special Dog For a Needy Elder
abstract: Article on increasing number of blind people 50 and older who are using seeing eye dogs; focuses on Seeing Eye of Morristown, NJ, which is breeding gentler, quieter and smaller dogs for older clients; photos (M)

headline: Missing Cellphone Feature
abstract: Robert Lapollo letter bemoans lack of hearing aid compatibility in cellphones, which leaves large segment of population unconnected (Jun 5 article)

headline: No Vision, but Better Memory
abstract: Amir Amedi, Hebrew University in Jerusalem research fellow, publishes study performing magnetic resonance brain scans on individuals blind from birth and sighted individuals; study shows reassignment of primary visual cortex to abstract verbal tasks in blind subjects; drawing (S)

headline: A New Lens Restores Vision and Brings Relief
abstract: Development of Boston scleral lens enables many people stricken with painful and debilitating eye-surface diseases to regain vision and reduce corneal pain; unlike traditional contact lenses, this lens sits on white of eye, known as sclera, rather than cornea and provides cushioning through layers of fluid built in lens itself; Dr Perry Rosenthal, corneal specialist in Chestnut Hill (Mass),is one of only two doctors prescribing and fitting scleral lens and he hopes, with help of $240,000 grant from Johnson & Johnson Vision Care Inc, to expand usage through training and establishment of clinics; story of Joe Zienowicz, who contracted and was blinded by Stevens-Johnson syndrome, recalled; drawing; photo (M)

headline: For Pride, 'It Was Like A Dream'
abstract: New York Yankees outfielder Curtis Pride, who has bounced around Majors and minors since 1986, hits home run in game against Boston Red Sox and receives multiples ovations from fans; Pride, who is deaf, had to be told to go out for curtain call; photo (M)

headline: Seeing Life In the Light Of Blindness
abstract: Richard Lane Cases column on his personal journey from partially sighted teenager to blind man in his mid-twenties; his positive outlook for future remains buoyed by his lingering visual impressions from his youth (M)

headline: No Hits, But Pride Does Job
abstract: New York Yankees outfielder Curtis Pride, whose first hit as Yankee was dramatic home run, hits game-winning grounder in next game against Boston Red Sox; is deaf and wears hearing aid (M)

headline: 'Big River' Sings (and Signs) on Broadway
abstract: Article on American Sign Language adaptation of 1985 musical Big River, employing 7 deaf and 11 hearing actors; discusses performances of Troy Kotsur and Lyle Kanouse, who both play single role of Pap; complicated interweaving of singing and signing required much longer rehearsal period than that normally allowed for Broadway show; photos (L)

headline: U.P.S. Settles Bias Lawsuit Brought by Deaf Workers
abstract: More than 1,000 current and former deaf employees at United Parcel Service settle discrimination lawsuit, with company agreeing to pay $10 million and to take steps to accommodate deaf workers; company pledges to provide deaf workers with effective communications, including interpreters, for interviews, orientation, training, safety meetings and disciplinary sessions (M)

headline: Where Dreams of Speed Meet Reality
abstract: Long Island Journal column; Mazda Rev It Up, three-day performance driving school and competitive driving event, draws 2,001 motorsports devotees to Belmont Park, last stop in 15-city tour; Alexandra Lynn, 8, of Manhasset, who has been fitted with cochlear implants, is starring in No Limits Theater production of Believe It or Not, culmination of five-week theater program for children with hearing impairments; photo (M)

headline: What Makes Dogs Tick? The Search for Answers
abstract: Ability of dogs to provide comfort, security, and guidance has made them more useful than ever to humans, generating more interest in understanding behavioral and physical traits of dogs than ever before: Dr James Serpell, University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine animal welfare associate professor, has utilized questionnaires and statistics to identify eight general behavioral traits in guide dogs, some of which are sociability, trainability, agression, fear and anxiety and excitability; similarly, ethologists Dr Kenth Svartberg of Stockholm University and Dr Bjorn Forkman of Royal Veterinary and Agricultural University have standardized five basic behavior traits for 164 breeds belonging to Swedish Working Dogs Association and developed what they call shyness-boldness continuum; Journal of Applied Behavioral Science report on findings defines characteristics of personality traits and, in agreement with Dr Serpell's tests, holds that bold dogs are highly trainable; chart of dogs and their traits; photo (M)

headline: A German Voyager's Bold Vision for Tibet's Blind
abstract: Profile of Sabriye Tenberken, blind German who founded school for blind children in Tibet, where blindness carries terrible stigma; she cites plans to extend her Braille Without Borders program to northern India and other developing nations; photo (M)

headline: Photographers Make Art As Another Way of Seeing
abstract: Seeing With Photography Collective is group of blind and visually impaired photographers who rely on concepts they have already visualized and on other senses to create photographs; collective has put together exhibition that will run at Hudson Guild's Gallery II, NYC; photos (M)

headline: Budget Problems For a Radio Station Helping the Blind
abstract: Connecticut Radio Information System (CRIS), radio station for blind, reports it is operating with $40,000 deficit and may have to close by next summer (M)

headline: Closed Captions, Refreshed Without a Racing Typist
abstract: AOL introduces closed captioning for some multimedia programming it offers; expects services to appeal to deaf users and office workers who want to view streaming video without sound; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Sept 20 profile about Sabriye Tenberken, founder of school for blind in Tibet, regarding some biographical information

headline: Blind Jews Accuse a Publisher of Discontinuing Braille Texts
abstract: Jewish members of National Federation of the Blind charge that their ability to worship has been undermined by JBI International, the major producer of Jewish texts and scriptures for the sight-impaired, which they say has stopped publishing new titles in Braille and turned its 70,000-volume library over to Library of Congress; JBI rejects criticism, saying it is producing more Jewish Braille books than ever and has merely expanded operations to provide more materials for the partially sighted; one source of dispute is divide in world of advocates for blind: one side committed to Braille literacy and view that sightlessness is merely human characteristic, not disability, and another side comprising people with impaired vision who do not identify themselves as members of blind community, particularly when blindness comes in old age, and who do not know Braille (M)

headline: Thinking With the Hands
abstract: Susan Goldin-Meadow book Hearing Gesture: How Our Hands Help Us Think explores use of gesture to aid language; cites use of gesture by individuals blind since birth and holds that gestures help people express complex or confusing ideas by reducing cognitive effort of speaker; photo (S)

headline: School Board Candidate Making a Historical Run
abstract: Commission on Deaf and Hearing Impaired says Laurie Meotti, single mother of two children who is running for spot on Board of Education in Hebron, Conn, is state's first deaf candidate for public office; Meotti says she hopes to inspire deaf children to be all they can be (M)

headline: Sports of The Times; Too Famous To Suffer Unnoticed
abstract: Marla Runyan, who is legally blind, finishes 20th in New York City Marathon women's division; Runyan, 34, has hereditary condition called Stargadt's disease; now she has aspirations of being long-distance medalist in her athletic old age; photo (Sports of The Times column) (M)

headline: Good Hands At Work
abstract: Article profiles Long Islanders whose work involves their hands, including orthopedic surgeon Dr William Facibene, Linda King, teacher who is deaf and uses American Sign Language to teach students math, dentists Mark and Debra Weinstein, master puppeteer Carol Fijan and watchmaker Howard Crofoot; photos (Special Issue: Long Island at Its Best) (L)

headline: Drug Shows Promise Against Vision Loss
abstract: Results of trials of drug Macugen, developed to treat wet form of macular degeneration, leading cause of blindness among elderly, are inconsistent with initial promising reports; large trial shows no meaningful improvement; there is only one drug, Visudyne, on market for macular degeneration and it is approved for treatment of only one subtype that represents minority of cases (M)

headline: Praying Hands, Wringing Hands; Deaf Congregation on East Side Fears for Its Future
abstract: Deaf worshipers at St Elizabeth of Hungary Roman Catholic Church worry that Archidiocese of New York will close church down as it reorganizes parishes; archdiocese says small congregation in Manhattan falls short on all of their criteria for keeping churches open, but will take other factors into account; Patrick P Cahill, church's pastor, is one of only two priests in archdiocese who signs Mass (M)

headline: The Neediest Cases; Blind Liberian Immigrant Is Undaunted by Challenges
abstract: Catholic Charities Guild for the Blind helps Liberian immigrant learn to travel and live independently; is securing $450 from New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for computer voice program; photo (M)

headline: Helping Deaf Investors
abstract: Christopher D Sullivan III writes The Boss column on growing up deaf and his work helping deaf investors as manager of special needs financial services at Merrill Lynch; photo (M)

headline: For the Deaf, Communication Without the Wait
abstract: Videophone and relay service from Sorenson Media enables deaf users to sign with each other and provides translations for those who can hear; other providers include AT&T, Sprint and Hands On Video Relay Services, which use programs like Microsoft NetMeeting; photo (M)

headline: Kitchen Fire Leaves Pillar Of Harlem Dead at 71
abstract: Shirley Hargrove, 71-year-old pillar of Harlem community, who did not let creeping blindness stop her from cooking, dies in fire that apparently started in kitchen of her apartment; photo (M)

headline: Blinded Veterans
abstract: Bruce Rider letter sympathizes with Sgt Jeremy Feldbusch, who lost eyesight in Iraq, and recalls own ordeal after being blinded in Vietnam, and years it took to get compensation from Veterans Administration

headline: After Deaf Man Is Fatally Shot, Grieving Family Wonders Why
abstract: Kevin Lazare, 24-year-old construction worker, is fatally shot at deserted bus stop in Brownsville section of Brooklyn; family suspects that Lazare's deafness may have played role in his death; photos (M)

headline: A New Cellphone Nods to the Needs of the Disabled
abstract: New technology to ease use by blind, prompted by complaint to Federal Communications Commission, includes voice prompts for information on screen; first model is developed by Toshiba; photo (M)

headline: For Africa's Deaf and Blind, AIDS Is an Unknown Language
abstract: Deaf and blind Africans often have very limited information about AIDS as result of discrimination or inability to communicate; rape of disabled women is significant problem in parts of Africa, aggravated by belief that sex with virgins cures disease; advocacy groups in Uganda and Ghana seek to draw attention to problem; Peace Corps has program in Kenya to educate deaf children about AIDS through signing; Kenyan government AIDS council last year gave money to hold AIDS seminars for disabled people, and has made sign language commercial to reach disabled; photo (M)

headline: For a Few Birders in Texas, The Victory Is in the Trill
abstract: Gladie Cruz and Raul Reyes lead Blind Birders, group in Texas that revels in hearing variety of bird songs and calls; group will be included for first time in annual Great Texas Birding Classic, one of pastime's biggest events; participants who tally most birds get to allocate more than $50,000 in prize money to conservation causes of their choosing; Roy J Rodriguez, leading bird-watcher, works with Blind Birders as project of Rensselaerville Institute, which sponsors people like Cruz and Reyes to be 'spark plugs' for others in their community; photos (M)

headline: In a Realm of Blind Fish, Mr. Right and Mr. Big Are One and the Same
abstract: Zoological Institute in Hamburg, Germany, houses oddities of fish world; Martin Plath, Hamburg graduate student, and behavioral biologists Dr Jakob Parzefall, Dr Kay E Korner and Dr Ingo Schlupp, are studying sightless Atlantic mollies taken from darkened, sulfuric caves in Mexico; research, published in Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology, focuses on mating habits; suggests that females, who are blind, determine size of male fish using lateral line, sensory organ; sighted mollies do not use lateral line and have been observed to use sight alone in determining suitable mate; photos; map (M)

headline: A Dream, Multiplied by Three
abstract: Identical triplets Chris, Curt and Craig Kuhn, who were born deaf, try out for St Paul Saints; photo (M)

headline: Summer Sun Can Put Older Eyes at Risk, Study Says
abstract: National Eye Institute predicts that as population ages number of people who are blind or have impaired vision will increase sharply; Sandra C Tomany, University of Wisconsin Medical School researcher, directs study linking extended exposure to sunlight to eye damage later in life; age-related maculopathy is leading cause of vision loss in United States (M)

headline: 9 Students at School for Deaf Say They Were Abused by Nuns
abstract: Nine former students of now-closed Massachusetts school for deaf file lawsuit saying they were sexually, physically and emotionally abused by Roman Catholic nuns who operated institution; plaintiffs, all of whom are deaf and mute, say they were raped, fondled, beaten, stuffed into lockers and had their heads submerged in toilets by nuns; plaintiffs were ages 4 to 18 at time, specified in lawsuit as 1944 to 1977, while they were students at Boston School for Deaf in Randolph; school was operated by Sisters of Joseph of Boston; photo (S)

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Settlement For Deaf Patients
abstract: Parkway Hospital in Queens agrees to implement step to communicate better with deaf patients after being sued by federal government and New York Lawyers for the Public Interest (S)

headline: Habitats/East 91st Street; Vision, Even Sightless, Helps Pick an Apartment
abstract: Interview with Alexandra Elman Singlevich, who is blind and has guide dog, and husband, Paul, on finding their East 91st Street, Manhattan, apartment; photos (Habitats column) (M)

headline: On the Tee and Blind, Hitting the Ball to Cues
abstract: Article on Pat Browne Jr, 71, who lost his sight at age 32 in car accident and is now 17-time winner of Corcoran Cup Championship, widely considered Masters of blind golf; photo (M)

headline: Weapons in the War on Glaucoma
abstract: Dr Mae O Gordon, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, researcher, leads study on glaucoma; research, published in Archives of Ophthalmology, shows that reduction of elevated blood pressure within eye can cut in half risk of African-Americans developing glaucoma; glaucoma is leading cause of blindness among blacks in United States (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: AOL To Offer Messaging Substitute For TTY
abstract: America Online will offer instant messager relay service for users who are hard of hearing or whose speech is impaired; AIM Relay Service will permit users to place relay telephone calls using their AOL Buddy List or AIM Buddy List (S)

headline: As Gene Test Menu Grows, Who Gets to Choose?
abstract: Increasing availability of more and more genetic tests raises issue of which ones to offer routinely to pregnant women and parents of newborns; Karen Coveler of Houston, whose son was born deaf, recalls taking 10 DNA tests, all negative, before becoming pregnant, but not being told about one that would have shown her risk for genetic form of deafness; critics say too many health care providers have not educated themselves about testing or do not volunteer information, in effect making value judgments about abortion, disabilities and risk that patients have right to make for themselves; medical societies also may not endorse scientifically valid testing for fear of litigation, or objections from those who say conditions like deafness are not diseases; American College of Obstetricians recommends test for cystic fibrosis, but not Fragile X, most common inherited form of retardation, risk for which is much higher; Angela Ross, whose son is affected, says she was never told about that test; Drs James Goldberg and Ronald Librizzi and others in field discuss ethical issues; photos (M)

headline: Bursting With Functions, A Slimmer Braille Organizer
abstract: BrailleNote PK from Pulse Data is multi-function device for the blind that communicates with phone line, Bluetooth and WiFi wireless technology; photo (S)

headline: The Right Ear Is From Mars

headline: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dispute Over Voice-Dialing
abstract: Betsy Gotbaum, New York City Public Advocate, calls on Verizon to reverse plan to discontinue voice-dialing service that helps visually impaired use telephone; Verizon says similar equipment can be purchased; photo (S)

headline: New Tools to Help Patients Reclaim Damaged Senses
abstract: Sensory substitution devices can help handicapped individuals regain some lost sensorial abilities and help them lead more normal lives; story of balance-impaired Cheryl Schiltz and her use of BrainPort technology to stabilize her world discussed; Dr Paul Bach-y-Rita, University of Wisconsin Medical School orthopedics and rehabilitation department neuroscientist, developed BrainPort, portable sensory substitution device; process in which tongue, ear or skin can help blind people see is described; brain function changes can occur after using BrainPort, encouraging researchers to continue development; potential applications discussed; photos; drawings (L)

abstract: Nassau County Comptroller Howard S Weitzman audit finds that county is wasting tens of millions of dollars year in excessive spending on home care for elderly, blind and disabled; says Nassau spent nearly $87 million year in 2002-03 for Medicaid clients, almost quadruple $23 million spent in Suffolk County; state imposed $2.4 million in penalties on Nassau because it failed to economize (M)

abstract: Pulse Data myReader allows visually impaired users to scan printed text and displays it in large format on monitor; photo (S)

headline: Upgrade for Blind Borrowers of Audiobooks
abstract: National Library Service for the Blind and Physically Handicapped, part of Library of Congress, is upgrading audiobook service from cassette tape to digital format; conversion technology described; photo (M)

headline: Patient, Heal Thyself
abstract: Biomedical engineers have raised expectations that they can provide technological cures for people afflicted with paralysis, deafness and other disabilities; many of bionic visions have not been borne out; other technologies offer signs of success by exploiting body's own abilities; latest 'cures' for blindness, deafness and paralysis are successful because they work with body's own efforts; drawing (M)

headline: Shop Smart, to Hear What You Want to Hear
abstract: Without his hearing aids, Dr. Don Thaler has trouble holding a conversation in a crowded restaurant. With the devices in, however, the ambient noise -- the clinking of dishes, the shuffling of feet, the drone of table talk throughout the room -- can be intolerable.    ''I just hate them,'' Dr. Thaler, a retired dentist in Amagansett, N.Y., said of his hearing aids -- digital ones that fit completely inside the ear canal and cost more than $7,000 for the pair. He wears them only when going out with company. Even then, he said, ''I always carry a leather pouch because inevitably I end up pulling them out of my ears.''

headline: Police Say Man They Shot Terrorized 2 Co-Workers
abstract: Police say Brian Allen, man they shot and killed in fusillade of over 40 bullets in Hollis, Queens, shot and wounded deaf co-worker Clard Coleman at LaGuardia Community College and kidnapped and raped another deaf co-worker before fatal confrontation; photo (M)

headline: MoMA Visitors Use Ears to See
abstract: Article on Museum of Modern Art's new electronic auditory tour guide that not only offers erudite commentaries from curators, conservators and artists but descriptions of paintings and sculptures for visitors with visual impairments; photos (M)

headline: Hearing Impaired, but Ready to Work
abstract: Article on on-the-job training program offered by five Westchester County businesses for high school students at New York School for the Deaf in White Plains, NY; program includes working at veterinary clinic, children's center and other job sites, first with and then without supervision, using individual educational plans to help shape curriculum and classroom discussions about practical problems students encounter; photos (M)

headline: For Disabled, It's Hooray for Hollywood
abstract: Clyde Haberman, in NYC column, notes that Jamie Foxx received best-actor Oscar nomination for his mesmerizing portrayal of blind Ray Charles in movie Ray; holds that this is good news for New Yorkers with disabilities and for people who help them; maintains that when Hollywood turns its klieg lights on illness, disorder or handicap, public has way of paying attention; says that makes life easier for those who treat problem, and it can pry money loose from donors; photo (M)

headline: A New Language Arises, and Scientists Watch It Evolve
abstract: Dr Wendy Sandler, University of Haifa researcher, leads study on Al Sayyid Bedouin Sign Language, which was developed by isolated village in Israel's Negev Desert 70 years ago; asserts that language developed spontaneously and autonomously; community, which is descended from single founder who had two deaf sons, has around 150 deaf persons within total population of 3,500; offers opportunity for linguists to better understand evolution of language; photos (M)

abstract: Cochlear Ltd, maker of inner-ear hearing devices, agrees to buy Entific Medical Systems of Sweden, hearing-implant maker owned by Nobel Biocare Holding and other Swedish investors, for $153 million (S)

headline: George Scott Is Dead at 75; Gospel Group's Baritone
abstract: George Scott, who in 1939 with other blind youths formed exuberant gospel group that earned raucous renown as Blind Boys of Alabama, dies at age 75; photo (M)

headline: As Town for Deaf Takes Shape, Debate on Isolation Re-emerges
abstract: Plan to create town expressly for people who use American Sign Language spurs debate; advocates of technologies that help deaf people use spoken language wonder whether such a town would merely isolate and exclude deaf more than ever; nearly 100 families have publicly declared their intention to live in town to be called Laurent, in South Dakota; planners, architects and future residents are gathering at camp center to draw detailed blueprints for town, which could accommodate at least 2,500 people; founder Marvin T Miller, who is deaf, envisions town where teachers will sign, town council will hold its debates in sign language and restaurant workers will be required to know how to sign orders; developers say there are deaf enclaves in country, but this would be first town expressly created for people who sign; say location, in sparsely populated South Dakota, was selected with intent of rapidly building political strength for nation's millions of deaf and hard-of-hearing people, group that has won few elected offices around country; photos; map (M)

headline: When the Orphans Saw 'Annie'
abstract: Debra West Cross Westchester column; Janet Angier, orphaned as infant and placed in foster homes before being adopted, donates 170 tickets to her production of Annie at middle school in Chappaqua, NY, to foster children and foster parents from Abbott House, a social services agency in Irvington that arranges foster care and high-risk adoptions for children from New York City and Hudson Valley; Lighthouse International in White Plains runs Saturday cooking and baking program for blind and visually impaired children in White Plains; Scenic Hudson's 8th Annual River Sweep will take place this weekend along river's edge from Manhattan to the Adirondacks; photo (M)

headline: Buffalo Fireman Regains Long-Lost Memories
abstract: Firefighter Donald Herbert, 44, who apparently suffered brain damage after burning roof collapsed on him in Buffalo in 1995 has swift and unexplained recovery; has been nearly blind and silent since fire, but suddenly starts speaking to family and friends at nursing home where he has been since 1998; in 1996 he awoke from coma with blurred vision, slurred speech and little memory or motor skills; has been bedridden since then (M)

headline: Theater by the Blind Fashions Its 'Oedipus'

headline: At Synagogues, Services Open Doors for the Deaf
abstract: Before she joined a synagogue for the deaf where services are conducted in sign language and two of the five choir members cannot hear, Roz Robinson found herself lost, unable to follow the cantor in her former synagogue as he chanted the prayers that had once been so familiar.     ''I remember feeling very embarrassed to have my family tell me that the tunes I knew to various prayers were not being used,'' Mrs. Robinson said in an interview conducted by e-mail because it was the easiest form of communication. Though she had hearing loss in childhood, Mrs. Robinson, a 55-year-old resident of Woodland Hills, Calif., was not profoundly deaf until her late 30's.

headline: Young Sailors, Making Their Way by Touch and Sound
abstract: The Pioneer, a two-masted schooner, pulled out of Pier 16 in Lower Manhattan last week, creating soft ripples as it glided into the Hudson River. The 18 students aboard took up positions on either side of the boat and prepared for action.     ''Reach! Pull!'' several instructors cried in unison. ''Reach! Pull!''

headline: Flying Blind and Deaf but Not Alone
abstract: WHEN you are deaf-blind, technology is an ever-present companion. I travel with a laptop for e-mail, phone and Internet access. I use a G.P.S.-equipped Braille Note note-taker to get information about my surroundings. To communicate with others, I have a Screen Braille Communicator with two sides: one in Braille, which I can read; the other an L.C.D. screen with a keyboard, for someone who is sighted.     My other traveling companion is my guide dog, a yellow female Labrador retriever named Dinah.

headline: Blind Woman Is Scolded, Bad Girl!
abstract: WHATEVER else you want to say about the uplifting neighborhood spat involving Edith Kling and the Northgate Commons condominium board, one thing is beyond dispute: If the board was looking for an elderly blind woman to pick on, it definitely found the wrong one.     A few weeks back, the board of Northgate Commons, a 26-unit complex in Rockland County, told Mrs. Kling that she had a problem: She was violating the association's rules by allowing her guide dog, a yellow Lab named Frances, to relieve herself on the street within the complex, instead of on the roads outside.

headline: On This Team, Good Hands Are a Given
abstract: IN a high school gymnasium where youthful exuberance is more felt than heard, the visiting team gathers at one end of the basketball court to stretch before the game. ''One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten,'' they chant, then clap, clap, clap. One, two, three, clap, clap, clap.     At the other end, the home team, the American Sign Language and English Secondary School warms up in silence. Only the basketball talks, pinging off the floor, slapping against the backboard, making that whisper-grunt sound, whup, when meeting a bed of soft hands.

headline: Preventable Disease Blinds Poor in Third World
abstract: Mare Alehegn lay back nervously on the metal operating table, her heart visibly pounding beneath her sackcloth dress, and clenched her fists as the paramedic sliced into her eyelid. Repeated infections had scarred the undersides of her eyelids, causing them to contract and forcing her lashes in on her eyes. For years, each blink felt like thorns raking her eyeballs. She had plucked the hairs with crude tweezers, but the stubble grew back sharper still.      The scratching, for Mrs. Alehegn, 42, and millions worldwide, gradually clouds the eyeball, dimming vision and, if left untreated, eventually leads to a life shrouded in darkness. This is late-stage trachoma, a neglected disease of neglected people, and a preventable one, but for a lack of the modest resources that could defeat it.

headline: Protests Continue at University for Deaf

headline: A Home Where the Walls Have Ears
abstract: A home that uses cutting edge technology to help a family with disabilities.

headline: A Home Where the Walls Have Ears
abstract: FOR the second ''Extreme Makeover: Home Edition'' episode in New Jersey in a month, ABC-TV producers found another family with extreme difficulties and another builder willing to go to extreme lengths to provide a new house within seven days -- this time, with an extreme helping of high technology.     At their new home in Bergenfield, the Llanes family will live like the Jetsons. Its features will permit them to talk to wall monitors throughout the home to ask questions that can be looked up on the Internet and receive spoken answers, or to adjust the temperature or run the vacuum with a spoken command. Four family members are blind or nearly so, and they will all be able to operate the household systems.

headline: 'Hamlet' Is Performed by Theater by the Blind

The audience can understand the meaning of every word. headline: Three Tales Revolving Around a Real Life
abstract: Although four stories, three fictional and one real, are folded together in Eric Khoo's elliptical film ''Be With Me,'' the tale that gives this delicate, melancholic movie its backbone is the true one of its courageous central character, Theresa Chan. A deaf and blind Singaporean woman in her early 60's who plays herself in the movie, Ms. Chan is an indomitable life force and charismatic screen presence. Even after she concludes her account of transcending the ''silent, dark prison'' of her disabilities with the help of gifted teachers, you are left wondering how she did it.     Remarkably self-sufficient, Ms. Chan is shown carefully washing her own dishes at home and teaching pottery to children at a school for the blind in Singapore. Although she can't hear, she occasionally speaks intelligible sentences in a rough, loud voice.

headline: The Visage Problem
abstract: In August, Mary Ann Sieghart, a columnist for The Times of London, described her battle with the disorder prosopagnosia, also known as face-blindness. She can spend an hour and a half with a new acquaintance at lunch, furiously trying to imprint his features on my memory, she wrote. Yet the chances are that the next time I bump into him, I wont know who he is. Like other prosopagnosics, Sieghart finds most human faces to be about as distinguishable as stones in a driveway. The disorder was first fully described in the medical literature in the 1940s and has long been viewed as an exceedingly rare, baffling derangement.

headline: Friends Who Share a Language
abstract: Christine Sun Kim: Growing up, I struggled to communicate and develop friendships with hearing peers, but then I went to college and became more comfortable with my signing and myself. Then I went to grad school, and my A.S.L. bubble popped. I learned I had a skill with strangers. I realized that small talk with hearing strangers was an opportunity for them to see me. And if I saw that they werent interested in me, I knew they werent worth my time, and it didnt hurt my feelings  it was the filter I needed. Now when my friends and I are together, we communicate using a combination of American Sign Language (A.S.L.), German Sign Language (D.G.S.), international signs and [the messaging app] Cardzilla.
